1451629184|5.0|This is a beautiful book.    What I have come to understand is that this is not a book about a kidnapping. This is a book about a spiritually gifted woman navigating her way through a life marked by deeply moving events. I am humbled by what I have read.    Ms Dugard is able to continue down a path of personal growth under the most constrained circumstances. The journal entries from her captivity, both as a child and later as an adult, reveal the amazingly positive energy she carries within her. She has the capacity for self-reflection at a young age, even though she is denied any personal autonomy. Later, she is able to build a semblance of a normal life for her children, home schooling them with her own curriculum despite only having a 5th grade education. She plants a garden, cares for her animals, even manages a business. All of this while enduring the constant abuse of a hyper-controlling, drug-addicted psychopath.    I am deeply inspired by her ability to keep pouring love out into the world despite being treated so horridly. Rather than turn away to some dark place, Ms Dugard performs a kind of spiritual judo, reflecting back love and compassion on the animals in her care, the children she's struggling to raise and the distant memory of her mother. She is able to resist the temptation to spew forth hatred upon the perpetrators of her abuse. Instead, she lets it go and moves on to a better place.    Frankly, I'm a bit ashamed that my initial interest in this book was based on sensationalist media coverage of the events surrounding her rescue. I was expecting to learn more about her captors and what kind of person would commit such a horrendous crime. After finishing the book, I've realized that don't care about them. Instead, I've learned something about myself: that I never need give up hope. No situation requires that I compromise myself or my beliefs. I can see now experiences in my own life where I was sucked in by the spiritual traps that Ms Dugard successfully navigated around for 18 years. I have a new role model to look up to.    Ms Dugard is living proof that \\"life can start over.\\" I am indebted to her for a new understanding of those words.    Thank you.

B004WKOCP8|1.0|I've been listening to Incubus for many many years now, I have all their albums and can respect each one to a certain extent. I'm not going to say I've liked each album equally, because that would be foolish. I'm also a big fan of music in general and I fully understand that groups want to branch out and make something new. But never have I seen such a drastic change take such a bad turn for the worst. It's almost as if Incubus decided that they were going to scrap their entire fanbase and try to create a new one when making this album . It seems preposterous that any group would ever do this, but after listening to this album multiple times all I can say this is not Incubus. When listening to this entire album I think the main keypoints one can gather is that Brandon Boyd, as usual, is a great singer and the music is very slow with no standouts. Yes, Brandon sounds wonderful in the songs but it actually means nothing. There are more parts to the \\"music equation\\". You need a composition that is interesting and the vocals should compliment this composition and give it life. All the songs are dead. The compositions are so bland, I can't even begin to imagine how this CD came together. It's as if the entire group was replaced and Brandon Boyd was the only constant remaining. Almost like a Brandon Boyd solo CD gone wrong. Incubus has been known to give you catchy bass lines, guitar solos, a nice drum beat, and of course Brandon's voice to bring it all together. It's not as if when making \\"slower\\" and \\"darker\\" music that you can't compile these elements into your songs, but that's exactly what Incubus did in their cd \\"If Not Now, When?\\". Nothing musically significant was gained from this cd. Nowhere in the CD did I say to myself: \\"Wow, that's a very nice bass line that they developed\\" or \\"The guitar rhythm in this song is very catchy\\".    I think it would only be right if I tried to relate what another group did to change their style 360 degrees with great success. Pretty similar actually what Incubus tried doing with the CD, a dark and slow CD. If you've never heard of them, check out the group Opeth. Opeth can be categorized in many different genres, but they came to fame with their \\"death metal\\" style. Brutal and vicious screams, very fast paced rhythm, but brought together beautifully with a sense of musical genius. The singer of this group (Mikael Ã…kerfeldt - extremely gifted as a singer and guitar player) would in many cases break out of his \\"death growls\\" and bless you with angelic vocals. They had a huge \\"death metal/Progressive metal\\" following and all of a sudden in 2003 they decided to make an album that was entirely different than ANYTHING they had ever done. They decided to create an album without any death growls by Mikael, the musical composition would involve much more acoustic guitars, and everything would be slowed down almost to an extreme measure (compared to their past music). So what happened to this CD? Well, check the review for it here on amazon: [[ASIN:B00008OLYN Damnation]]. Quite frankly, if you have any passion towards music, it can only be described as a \\"masterpiece\\". To bring this all together, the point I'm trying to make is that groups have changed their style in the past and have succeeded by making something significant. \\"If Not Now, When?\\" leaves nothing significant and leaves me highly disappointed.     It's depressing to think that I will have to wait a few more years for Incubus to release a new album. I just hope they decide to dig down deep and make something significant musically. Significant like S.C.I.E.N.C.E., Make Yourself, and Morning View was.    That's just my two cents. If you'd like, reply to my review and give me and everyone else your opinion.    -Cheers and Godspeed-

I still regret losing the pre-K pics...just my warning for you!

0545259088|5.0|This is the third and final book in the Wolves of Mercy Falls series by Stiefvater.  I was very excited to get an Advanced Reading Copy of this book at Book Expo America.  This book did an excellent job of wrapping up this series. It is a bit slow, like all of the book in the series have been, but if you liked the previous books in the series you will love this one.<br /><br />As Spring slowly creeps into Mercy Falls, MN things are on the cusp of changing.  Sam still doesn't know if his cure is for real.  Grace is lost in the woods as a wolf, just waiting to change back to a girl.  Cole is still desperately trying to find a cure for their curse.  Meanwhile Isabel's father is out for the wolves' blood; he has a manhunt planned soon for these wolves.  What will happen next is anyone's guess.<br /><br />As with all the books in this series the writing style is beautiful but slow.  There are long periods of time where Stiefvater is just following the characters around in their day to day life, then suddenly BOOM!, tons of stuff happens.  Then it is back to a slower pace again.  If you have already read the rest of this series you know that's how these books are, and if you like that you will love this book.<br /><br />This book focuses on Isabel and Cole almost as much as Sam and Grace.  In fact there isn't a ton of romantic tension between Sam and Grace; they love each other and know it.  The other thing that really propels the book forward is their race against time to save the wolves.  They are trying to save the wolves somehow, before Isabel's father hunts them down.  To add to this you have the temperature uncertainty that makes various characters randomly revert to wolf form.<br /><br />There is a lot of tension in this book and a lot of uncertainty.  Things are tied up nicely in the end.  Although there are a couple things that could have been tied up with more definition...who knows maybe those things will be part of a spin-off series or something.<br /><br />The characterization in this book is perfect; these are wonderful characters that I really enjoy reading about.  It was torture to watch them go through some parts in this book, but in the end that made the resolution all the sweeter.  The book is hard to put down and incredibly engaging.<br /><br />There are some additional things I really enjoyed about this book.  I really enjoyed Cole's experimentation with cures, he was a great character and so fun to read about as he dabbled in science.  I also enjoyed that the book takes place in my home state of MN!  I love how spot on Stiefvater is in her description of Minnesota springs.<br /><br />Overall I absolutely devoured this book.  I loved it to death.  Great resolution to the series, wonderful characters, engaging plot, and beautiful writing.  The pace is a bit slow for me, but that just seems to be Stiefvater's writing style and I have slowly grown to enjoy it.  Definitely read this if you had read the previous books.  I recommend this series if you are looking for a young adult paranormal series that doesn't mind dwelling on the beauty of its surroundings and on the little things that make love tick.ct; these are wonderful characters that I really enjoy reading about.  It was torture to watch them go through some parts in this book, but in the end that made the resolution all the sweeter.  The book is hard to put down and incredibly engaging.    There are some additional things I really enjoyed about this book.  I really enjoyed Cole's experimentation with cures, he was a great character and so fun to read about as he dabbled in science.  I also enjoyed that the book takes place in my home state of MN!  I love how spot on Stiefvater is in her description of Minnesota springs.    Overall I absolutely devoured this book.  I loved it to death.  Great resolution to the series, wonderful characters, engaging plot, and beautiful writing.  The pace is a bit slow for me, but that just seems to be Stiefvater's writing style and I have slowly grown to enjoy it.  Definitely read this if you had read the previous books.  I recommend this series if you are looking for a young adult paranormal series that doesn't mind dwelling on the beauty of its surroundings and on the little things that make love tick.

B00000I41J|5.0|If you know and love Miles Davis from the late 1950s `Kind of Blue' period but haven't heard anything recorded under Julian `Cannonball' Adderley's own name, you're likely to love and appreciate `Somethin Else.' It's the perfect Blue Note companion to KoB and in the same groove, with superlative playing throughout from Adderley on alto sax and Miles on trumpet together with Hank Jones on piano, and a rhythm section made up of Art Blakey on drums and Sam Jones on bass.<br /><br />It's difficult to pick out highlights on a collection so uniformly excellent, but the 11-minute opener `Autumn Leaves' is a true jazz classic which you'll think you've always known, so recognisably familiar is the melody. The title track, showcasing the horn interplay between Miles and Cannonball chasing each other all over the scales in an exuberant and up-tempo duet sounds like a cut which escaped from the KoB sessions, and `One for Daddy-O' with its slower tempo and stand-out uncomplicated melody also shines. In the sparse, clean and bluesy `Dancing in the Dark' we hear Cannonball at his soulful best, his horn soaring with a long, slow-tempo solo over a perfectly understated rhythm.<br /><br />The music here is instantly accessible, with nothing unnecessarily complex or jarring. You can listen to the album again and again, no matter what you're doing, though one or two of the numbers are perhaps a little up-tempo for dinner-party background ambience. Overall `Somethin Else' is an indispensable jazz classic which stands shoulder-to-shoulder with the very best of Miles, Trane or Charlie Parker.<br /><br />The nickname `Cannonball' BTW came from a corruption of `Cannibal' due to Adderley's huge appetite for food and habit of eating absolutely everything available at every opportunity, the result manifest in his generously proportioned, rotund and substantial physique. But boy, can he play that horn.

0061784788|4.0|It's been a long time since I've read Rollins and I haven't kept up with the Sigma Force series since Black Order, but The Devil Colony sounded too intriguing to resist.  The premise involves various components:  the founding fathers, Mormonism, the Lewis & Clark expedition, American Indians, and nanotechnology.  The connections Rollins makes between all of these things should be taken at face value.  He presents American lore as pure entertainment to weave a good conspiracy.  The author's note at the end was helpful in separating fact from fiction and the small grains of truth he does extract from American history are developed into an entertaining novel.  This was an altogether fun book that illustrated amazing scenes and sights unique to the U.S.  Rollins effectively manipulates aspects of modern technology and a few long standing mysteries to create a fast-paced and engaging adventure.

142311339X|4.0|The Lost Hero is the first novel in Rick Riordan's Heroes of Olympus series. It's a companion series to the Percy Jackson & the Olympians series, taking place shortly after The Last Olympian. The novel focuses on Jason, Piper and Leo and their quest to rescue Hera, Piper's dad, and stop the powerful titan Gaea from rising and destroying the world.<br /><br />The book is just as good as Riordan's other novels. The characters are clever, funny, and well thought out. The plot is interesting, and he introduces new ideas that are very compelling. The novel is in 3rd person (as opposed to Percy Jackson's 1st person) and the novel switches between the points of view of Jason, Piper, and Leo, in that order. This makes the book a great deal longer than any of the others, but it lets the reader see inside the minds of the three main characters, not just the one.<br /><br />The best part about this novel is the introduction of the Roman mythology. The last twenty pages were fantastic when it was revealed that there are as many Roman demigods as there are Greek ones, and they have their own camp too. I'm definitely excited to see where this goes. However, I don't like that Percy's memory is gone! He definitely better get that back, and I do not want to see any confusion on his part about Annabeth. Nuh uh.<br /><br />Piper is probably my favorite character. She's awesome. She's completely opposite from the stereotypical child of Aphrodite, and she's powerful and smart. I liked her chapters the best, but that might also have to do with the fact that I am a girl.<br /><br />Jason needs to get his memories back. Characters aren't really interesting or emotional unless you know their past. Riordan gave a lot of wonderful information about Piper's and Leo's childhoods, but obviously we know nothing about Jason, and even after he starts to remember things, we still don't know much. Piper's and Leo's backstories were some of the best parts of the book.<br /><br />And of course, we have all the same elements that made Percy Jackson so great. Important figures from Greek mythology are introduced, like Midas and Medea. The writing is clever and funny. The book is fast paced, although the length does make it difficult to follow the story. I can't remember things that happened in the beginning of the book so well, and it seems like the story didn't quite flow.<br /><br />Overall, it's a good start to a new series. I am hoping that the next books are better, and I don't think I'll be disappointed. The next book has chapters from Percy's POV, and I'm very excited about this. I'm hoping Annabeth gets a few chapters too. I wonder if Jason, Piper, or Leo will get their own chapters in the upcoming books, or if Riordan will do different characters each novel. I'm not sure what he's going to do.<br /><br />If you like Percy Jackson, I definitely suggest this book. It keeps the story and the world alive, and it adds more knowledge about Roman mythology that you can learn about. Riordan is wonderful.Jackson so great. Important figures from Greek mythology are introduced, like Midas and Medea. The writing is clever and funny. The book is fast paced, although the length does make it difficult to follow the story. I can't remember things that happened in the beginning of the book so well, and it seems like the story didn't quite flow.    Overall, it's a good start to a new series. I am hoping that the next books are better, and I don't think I'll be disappointed. The next book has chapters from Percy's POV, and I'm very excited about this. I'm hoping Annabeth gets a few chapters too. I wonder if Jason, Piper, or Leo will get their own chapters in the upcoming books, or if Riordan will do different characters each novel. I'm not sure what he's going to do.     If you like Percy Jackson, I definitely suggest this book. It keeps the story and the world alive, and it adds more knowledge about Roman mythology that you can learn about. Riordan is wonderful.

1423101499|5.0|Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Battle of the Labyrinth is Rick Riordan's fourth Percy Jackson novel. Grover is still searching for the lost god Pan, but there are bigger issues at hand. The crew decide to enter Daedalus's labyrinth to try to find the creator before Luke and his crew do. Whoever gets to him first will control the Labyrinth, and unless Percy, Annabeth, and a mortal can find him, the forces of Kronos will attack Camp Half-Blood, and then Olympus itself.<br /><br />Battle of the Labyrinth is, of course, just as great as the first three Percy Jackson books. Riordan focuses mainly on the story of the inventor Daedalus and his infamous maze, now located below the United States. He draws on famous myths, like the stories of Icarus and Calypso, and some lesser known ones, like the cleaning of Geryon's stables. The book is a collection of adventures set underground, with the character's trying desperately to save their friends and the world.<br /><br />Let's just get this out of the way: Percy and Annabeth are the cutest couple in the world. I definitely died when she kissed him, but then they fought the whole rest of the book! Annabeth is jealous of Rachel and Percy is jealous of Luke, and they never talk about how they feel, and it sucks. But they're still perfect.<br /><br />Rachel Elizabeth Dare came back. I liked her a lot. She was almost like a non-half blood Annabeth. She's smart and feisty, but there's a barrier between her and everyone else because she isn't a demigod. She has the Sight, but she can only lead them. She can't follow. Also, Percy can't seem to sort out his feelings for her. Rachel shows yet again that anyone can help the world, no matter how insignificant they might think they are.<br /><br />\\"As I sailed into the lake I realized the Fates really were cruel... For the rest of my life I would be thinking about her. She would always be my biggest what if.\\"<br /><br />Riordan deals with love quite a bit in this book. Grover has a girlfriend! You go, Grover. Percy spends two weeks on Calypso's island, growing more and more fond of her. But in the end he has to leave her because he needs to help his friends. He knows that he could stay with her forever and never have a burden, but he can't do it; he has too many responsibilities. However, he'll always be thinking about how he could have lived with her carefree forever, never fulfilling the prophecy or having to fight in the war. Percy is sent to Calypso's island right after Annabeth kisses him. This throws a wrench in their relationship, which they never talk about. Percy has this what if with Calypso, and Annabeth has this what if with Luke, and they both know that they won't ever be with them, but the possibility of it will always be there, hiding in the shadows.<br /><br />Then there's the unromantic love. Most of Nico's actions are motivated by his desire to retrieve his sister from the underworld. Minos manages to manipulate him because of this desire. In the end, Nico realizes she is gone, and they say goodbye. Percy loves his friends and will do anything to save them. He also loves his mother enough to tell Mr. Blowfish to marry her.<br /><br />But Percy loves everyone a bit too much. He would sacrifice himself to save pretty much anyone. He spares the life of Someone Nakamura, who ends up freeing Kronos. In Mockingjay, Katniss would have just killed him. But Percy's way too nice for that. That's definitely a disadvantage.<br /><br />Riordan deals with the issues of meeting your hero. Tyson meets Briares, a famous Hundred Handed One, who he has looked up to his whole life. But Briares lets him down by refusing to fight and running away. Annabeth meets her hero Daedalus, but he won't help them, and it's revealed that he murdered his nephew. Even Percy questions what he believes when he meets a half-brother of his who makes human sacrifices in Poseidon's name. These three were forced to face the reality that even heroes are not perfect, and they are disappointed.<br /><br />However, all of these characters came through in the end. Briares and Daedalus show up to help Camp Half-Blood fight Kronos's army. Briares tells Tyson that he helped him remember what it is to be a Cyclops, and he decides to go to the forges to help teach other Cyclopes. Daedalus gives up his life to destroy the labyrinth, and he gifts Annabeth with all his architectural ideas. Poseidon comes to Percy's birthday party and tells him that just because people make sacrifices in the name of the gods does not mean that the gods want them. Also, Percy is totally his favorite son.<br /><br />Riordan is showing the reader that it's possible to make amends for bad things. Daedalus killed his nephew and felt responsible for the death of his son, but in the end he fights for the right side and he gets to apologize to them in the Fields of Asphodel. Briares gave up, but he was inspired to fight and then give back to the Cyclopes. No character-or person-is perfect. Everyone makes mistakes. It's what you do after that mistake that counts.<br /><br />Then there's Grover finally meeting Pan, and it was everything Grover could have hoped for, except that Pan died. But before he did, Pan put a little of himself into each of them, and Grover knows that he has to carry on in his place, that they all do. Grover is the ultimate environmentalist. He met his hero, his hero died, and it inspired him to try to save the world, the way Pan would have wanted it. This shows that death can inspire.<br /><br />Luke is dead? It's unclear, I suppose. I'm holding out hope that Luke will be able to switch sides in the end. He gained a lot of sympathy from me last book. He's gotten in over his head, and it's like the themes of Daedalus and Briares; Luke can always make amends.<br /><br />Nico is an extremely interesting character. He started off as an antagonist to Percy and the gang, but he switched sides and joined them. However, it's clear that Nico has a nature derived from his heritage that he can't shake off. He has control of the dead, and even though he uses it to help the right side, he might still turn evil and fulfill the prophecy. I'm a bit wary about him.<br /><br />This was a fantastic book. The plot was interesting and meaningful, the labyrinth was fascinating, and the characters developed as they should. I am on to the Last Olympian. And I am nervous.e through in the end. Briares and Daedalus show up to help Camp Half-Blood fight Kronos's army. Briares tells Tyson that he helped him remember what it is to be a Cyclops, and he decides to go to the forges to help teach other Cyclopes. Daedalus gives up his life to destroy the labyrinth, and he gifts Annabeth with all his architectural ideas. Poseidon comes to Percy's birthday party and tells him that just because people make sacrifices in the name of the gods does not mean that the gods want them. Also, Percy is totally his favorite son.    Riordan is showing the reader that it's possible to make amends for bad things. Daedalus killed his nephew and felt responsible for the death of his son, but in the end he fights for the right side and he gets to apologize to them in the Fields of Asphodel. Briares gave up, but he was inspired to fight and then give back to the Cyclopes. No character-or person-is perfect. Everyone makes mistakes. It's what you do after that mistake that counts. 0786838655|5.0|Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief is the first of Rick Riordan's series about a 12 year old boy who finds out he is half human, half god. His mother is kidnapped, and he finds himself on a quest with his two friends to return Zeus's lightning bolt to him.<br /><br />The book is obviously meant for ages 10 to 14 ish, but I (being 19 years old) absolutely loved it. The Greek mythology is both accurate and clever, and the written is easy to read and hilarious. There are also great underlying themes of putting aside prejudices and fighting your own battles. Annabeth is very adamant that she shouldn't like Percy because their parents are enemies, but by the end of the book Annabeth tells Percy that she's on his side no matter what. Percy learns about sacrifice through his mother's past, and he learns about corruption through Luke.<br /><br />Overall, the book was seriously great. It was funny and clever, well written and interesting, and it teaches great lessons. I would love to teach this book if I was ever given the chance, and I look forward to reading the rest of the series.

0671027344|5.0|The Perks of Being a Wallflower is an epistolary novel by Stephen Chbosky. The letters are written by \\"Charlie\\" to an anonymous person called \\"friend.\\" Charlie tells the friend about his first year of high school as he makes friends and deals with family and personal issues. Charlie becomes best friends with step siblings Sam and Patrick, and he has an intellectual relationship with his English teacher \\"Bill.\\" Charlie has been told that he needs to be more active in his life, and that's what he tries to do.<br /><br />The novel is brilliant. The form is perfect because it's as if the author is talking to the reader. Charlie tells all his most personal thoughts, and it's as if the letters are helping him discover the meaning of the events in his life. The writing is funny and clever, but it's also clear that there's something not right with Charlie, but that's not divulged until the end. The plot is engaging and deals with many important issues, like homophobia and abuse, and also the struggles of just growing up and making friends.<br /><br />I'm definitely going to have to reread this book. It's definitely going to be a different reading the second time around. I didn't get any hint that Charlie had been abused by his aunt until the epilogue, and then once Chbosky said it, the hints became clear, but I'll still have to reread it to get them all. The way Chbosky dealt with all of the issues in this book was brilliant. Not only Charlie's abuse, but also his sister's abuse by her boyfriend and her abortion, and the abuse of many adults in Charlie's life. Chbosky lets the reader get inside the mind of Charlie and see just how traumatic the abuse was. I probably shouldn't be writing this right now because I haven't quite processed the whole novel, but oh well.<br /><br />Basically, there isn't much to analyze because if you read it yourself, you will get it. You don't need me to point out the meaning in any of this, because it's right there for you. Chbosky's writing is clear and concise, and while he doesn't at all explain his themes, you will get them effortlessly. The writing is easy to read and understand, and it allows the reader to get his or her own message from it.<br /><br />My only other thoughts really are, how will they make this into a movie? I can't really picture Emma Watson as Sam. I hope she's good. I'm sure Logan Lerman will be fantastic, because he's wonderful. I just really hope it's done tastefully and effectively. The one thing I don't want to see is some awful \\"trippy\\" scene when Charlie is on LSD, with the camera tilt and the blurry vision. I do not need that. But really, the movie can't be as good as the book simply because of the book's format. You can't make a movie comprised of letters, and that's the best part about the book.<br /><br />This book was fantastic, and if you haven't read it, you need to. Chbosky talks about issues that everyone might not have gone through, but he also deals with universal experiences, like making friends and graduation. I read the book in like two hours, and it may be short, but it's wonderfully meaningful and powerful.while he doesn't at all explain his themes, you will get them effortlessly. The writing is easy to read and understand, and it allows the reader to get his or her own message from it.    My only other thoughts really are, how will they make this into a movie? I can't really picture Emma Watson as Sam. I hope she's good. I'm sure Logan Lerman will be fantastic, because he's wonderful. I just really hope it's done tastefully and effectively. The one thing I don't want to see is some awful \\"trippy\\" scene when Charlie is on LSD, with the camera tilt and the blurry vision. I do not need that. But really, the movie can't be as good as the book simply because of the book's format. You can't make a movie comprised of letters, and that's the best part about the book.    This book was fantastic, and if you haven't read it, you need to. Chbosky talks about issues that everyone might not have gone through, but he also deals with universal experiences, like making friends and graduation. I read the book in like two hours, and it may be short, but it's wonderfully meaningful and powerful.

1423101502|5.0|Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Last Olympian is the fifth and final installment in Rick Riordan's Percy Jackson series. The book focuses on the final battle of the gods and demigods versus the evil titan Kronos, whose consciousness is in the body of Percy and Annabeth's old friend Luke. The good guys are required to fight a variety of powerful monsters, causing Percy to do some very dangerous things to try to save his friends.<br /><br />This book is really just a long account of a battle. They start the fighting a little over 100 pages into the 381 page novel. This book is a lot darker and scarier than the first fourth. I was constantly worried that Percy or Annabeth would die, and it wasn't clear what exactly would happen in the end. But there were still Riordan's classic moments of comedy and romance, and it was just as good as the rest of the series.<br /><br />I'm not sure what to say about this book. There isn't much to commentate about a collection of battles, but it was very interesting to read. It was action-packed, obviously, and all the old characters were there. I was very worried that Clarisse was going to die, but then it was Silena, and I actually saw that coming. She was my first thought as to who the spy could be, but then I figured it wasn't her because of Beckendorf. It was such a beautiful moment when Percy gave her the jar filled with hope \\"because Hope survives best at the hearth.\\" Take from that what you will.<br /><br />I was pretty pleased with the ending of the battle. I'm glad Luke got his redemption, because I'd been rooting for him pretty much since the beginning. Riordan obviously wants to convey that no one is beyond saving, like with the characters in Battle of the Labyrinth, and Luke made up for his mistakes in the end. The way Riordan made the Great Prophecy be fulfilled was amazing.<br /><br />A series can really only come to an end when either the bad guy has been defeated or there has been a change made to the world or to a way of living. This series accomplished both of that. Percy (but really Luke) beat the evil Kronos, and then he ordered the gods to claim all their children.<br /><br />Which is really the main theme of the books. Kronos never would have risen to power without the help of the half-bloods who felt dejected and unwanted. Because of that neglect, bad things happened, and Percy is determined that it doesn't happen again. The series is about acceptance and belonging, like all coming-of-age stories.<br /><br />The book was a brilliant end to the series. The only thing I'm not satisfied with is that Riordan never addressed Percy's Achilles's curse in the end of the book. Is Percy still invincible? Did it wear off? Maybe he mentioned it earlier in the book and I just didn't notice. But overall, everyone got a happy ending, and the very last sentence was just wonderful:<br /><br />\\"For once, I didn't look back.\\"The Last Hero and there's no Grover? Boo.)    The title of the book refers to Hestia, goddess of the hearth. It was such a beautiful moment when Percy gave her the jar filled with hope \\"because Hope survives best at the hearth.\\" Take from that what you will.     I was pretty pleased with the ending of the battle. I'm glad Luke got his redemption, because I'd been rooting for him pretty much since the beginning. Riordan obviously wants to convey that no one is beyond saving, like with the characters in Battle of the Labyrinth, and Luke made up for his mistakes in the end. The way Riordan made the Great Prophecy be fulfilled was amazing.    A series can really only come to an end when either the bad guy has been defeated or there has been a change made to the world or to a way of living. This series accomplished both of that. Percy (but really Luke) beat the evil Kronos, and then he ordered the gods to claim all their children.    Which is really the main theme of the books. Kronos never would have risen to power without the help of the half-bloods who felt dejected and unwanted. Because of that neglect, bad things happened, and Percy is determined that it doesn't happen again. The series is about acceptance and belonging, like all coming-of-age stories.    The book was a brilliant end to the series. The only thing I'm not satisfied with is that Riordan never addressed Percy's Achilles's curse in the end of the book. Is Percy still invincible? Did it wear off? Maybe he mentioned it earlier in the book and I just didn't notice. But overall, everyone got a happy ending, and the very last sentence was just wonderful:    \\"For once, I didn't look back.\\"
1933633867|5.0|Graeber's book elegantly places current-day debt crises in the context of the whole history of social and economic transactions. The intellectual range is incredible: from Graeber's own anthropological fieldwork in Madagascar to usury in ancient Mesopotamia to the Biblical notion of jubilee to the fallacies somehow perpetuated in nearly every college economics class. Tying all this disparate material together in a lucid political and ethical framework, Graeber highlights the absurd way in which we now treat debt, and what that means for the state of our democracies, where promises made by politicians to bankers are so often held to a higher standard than promises made to constituents.
038572179X|5.0|Atonement by Ian McEwan is a novel about, well, a lot of things. The novel is split into four parts, each of which focuses on a different character and experience. It is set in the 1930's and 1940's, dealing with World War II and its effects. Briony Tallis is a young girl who makes a mistake that changes the lives of everyone around her forever.<br /><br />This book is wonderful. McEwan is a fantastic writer, and the story is engaging. I already knew how the book would end because I've seen the movie, but it was still a shock. Much of the book isn't even dialogue, but it hardly matters. McEwan allows you to get into the mind of each character that he narrates without saying anything trite like \\"Briony felt afraid.\\" The story never drags, and each words has a purpose. The book was interesting, funny, heartfelt, and heart-breaking.<br /><br />Part One, in my opinion, is clearly the superior part, especially for people who aren't that interested in the WWII aspect of the novel. This part is the longest section of the book, and it switches from narrator to narrator, all in third person. The reader gets to see several different perspectives from each main character, and some minor ones, and the plot is very interesting.<br /><br />Parts Two and Three focus more on the war effort, with Two being an account of Robbie in the war, and Three being the details of Briony's career as a nurse, and then how she finally fixes the problems with Robbie. Part Two was less interesting because it was mostly just Robbie (or Turner, as he is called in this part only, clearly showing the difference between someone in a war and someone not) running around and trying to get home. I liked Part Three. But then we get to Part Four and it's Briony explaining that the entire beginning was a novelization of her childhood, and that, actually, Robbie died in France and Cecilia died in the hospital. They never got their happy ending.<br /><br />The book's main theme is quite obviously atonement. Briony accused Robbie of raping her cousin when she was a little girl, and she spent the next five years trying to undo it. Personally, the book made me want to forgive everyone. Briony is struggling with her life because she feels guilt and she needs to be forgiven, but they refuse to give that to her. Briony's novel (aka Parts 1 through 3) ends with the opptimism of Briony being forgiven sometime in the future, but in Part 4 we realize that she was never forgiven. She had to live with the guilt that she separated a couple and that they never got their happy ending. Cecilia and Robbie never forgave Briony for what she did, which I think was kind of unfair. She was a child. But anyway...<br /><br />The book also tells about misinterpretation. Briony wants to believe that it was Robbie who raped Lola because she thinks he is a madman. She didn't understand Robbie's letter or the scene in the library. She tells the lie for so long that she really does believe it was Robbie who raped Lola. Once she realizes her mistake, it's too late to recant; she would look like a foolish child and no one would believe her. There are also smaller instances, like when Robbie remembers Briony confessing her love for him and believes she might have been jealous of his affections for Celilia, when in actuality Briony never thought about her crush again.<br /><br />The structure of the novel is beautiful, because the reader gets to enjoy the fictionalized tale first before being crushed with the reality. You read Briony's fictional version and get to think that all was made right: Celilia and Robbie got to be together, and Briony eventually gained everyone's forgiveness. Part 4 is necessary because it is real. People die, and sometimes forgiveness is never given. People hold grudges for life, and there's nothing anyone can do about it. But this book serves as a warning. Forgive those you love for their mistakes, or they will live with that guilt for the rest of their lives. It also shows thatpeople have to atone for their mistakes. Briony became a nurse to give back to the world, and she wrote her story to give Robbie and Celilia a happy ending they didn't get in real life.<br /><br />There is no villain in this story. There are only real characters in real situations with real consequences. The trick is to realize that everything you do will affect someone else, and to know that you will always have to atone for it. This book is marvelous.riony became a nurse to give back to the world, and she wrote her story to give Robbie and Celilia a happy ending they didn't get in real life.    There is no villain in this story. There are only real characters in real situations with real consequences. The trick is to realize that everything you do will affect someone else, and to know that you will always have to atone for it. This book is marvelous.

B004UUKDNA|5.0|Five stars.  Ten stars.  A hundred stars.  I regret giving five stars to anything in the past, because none of it approaches how mind-blowingly awesome this album is. Those bands are midgets compared to this giant.  Every single song on this album is a hit, better than any hit by any band of this nature in recent memory.  Every.  Single.  Song.  The beats and hooks are simply unbelievable.    This album will make you dance until you pass out.  It will cheer you up when you are having the worst day of your life.  It will make you drive fast and scream along in public, embarrassing yourself.  If you listen to this in bed with headphones on, you will dance in your bed and wake up your significant other.    I am honestly grateful that this band exists and that I have found them.  I have not felt this way about music in a long time - possibly ever.  Buy this, and buy a copy for everyone you care about in the world.

B004WOS3P4|5.0|David Cook's appearances on AI were full of creativity, his amazing voice, and the artistic touches of someone with huge potential. I was interested to see what he'd do with this album, since his first one felt rushed and superficial compared to what it seemed he was capable of. \\"This Loud Morning\\" fulfills the promise by delivering an amazing set of songs. Cook's voice is quite an instrument, and he deploys it wisely and well throughout. It's a big voice, and sometimes his vowel sounds are stretched unnaturally by the scope of what he can sing, but that's also part of what makes him unique and identifiable, and I certainly don't object. \\"Goodbye to the Girl\\" is perhaps the song I'd recommend him to leverage into the future, with less stadium-sized singing and more intimate, careful navigation of a complex emotional terrain. He's proven his rock chops. Now, let's add more color and delicacy in future. But back to this album. It's a great listen the first time, and has gotten better with repetition. I find myself recalling the tunes throughout the day now. The arrangements definitely benefited from the extra work, and this is a theme album, as the repetition of the toy piano and glockenspiel as bookends attests. Great job, David Cook! And thanks!

B004Y1USV2|4.0|Okay, I'm sure you've read all the other reviews by now, so I'll try really hard not to overdo this since I pretty much agree with most of the positives that have been said. If you are open minded enuff to accept that this is NOT Fragile, or Close To the Edge, or even 90125, and you are not bitter about the departures of Jon Anderson or Rick Wakeman, then you are ready to see this album for what it is. A tight, well-produced, slice of Progressive Pop with definite undertones of its roots in the \\"Drama\\" era. And to my ears, that's GREAT. I always LIKED \\"Drama\\" personally (Especially after it was reissued with all of the 'BONUS' material) and I became a huge fan of the Buggles because of that. You can definitely hear bits & pieces that recollect not only \\"Drama\\" but the other Trevor Horn produced Yes albums, as well as both of the Buggles discs and Asia's early releases. But there is also a lot of maturity, or more of a mellowing of the sound. And I'm okay with that. Let's face it, these guys are getting older and so are we the fans. All I know is that, in my opinion, this is the BEST thing they have done in a LONG time ... at least as a whole. While there have been High Spots in alot of Yes' recent Albums, I wouldn't call any of the albums \\"Great\\" as a whole. That's not to say that this is \\"Great\\" either ... but it is damned good & deserves at least a listen before you write it off for what it isn't or who is NOT here. Just enjoy it for what it IS ....

B004EPYZP8|5.0|THE LINCOLN LAWYER is a classy, well-written (adapted from Michael Connelly's novel by John Romano), well-directed (Brad Furman) drama that benefits from the presence of a well chosen, first class cast. This is one of the stronger movies of the year, the kind of film that reminds us of the art of cinema.<br /><br />Mike Haller (Matthew McConaughey in a brilliant performance) is a money hungry smarmy defense lawyer whose brilliant mind is bent toward representing sleazy types who pay well.  He works out of his Lincoln automobile driven by his trusted ally Earl (Laurence Mason), lives in a dumpy apartment, works with a shoddy appearing detective Frank (William H Macy), and spars with the beautiful fellow lawyer Maggie McPherson (Marisa Tomei) with whom he has a daughter and an on again off again relationship. One of his fellow workers Val Valenzuela (John Leguizamo) tips Mike on a case of  wealthy realtor Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe) who is accused of beating a prostitute: the case smells of lots of money so Mike of course takes it on - along with Louis, wealthy mother Mary Windsor (Frances Fisher) and the family lawyer Cecil Dobbs (Bob Gunton).  Mike's investigation turns up evidence that suggests his client is not the 'presumed innocent' he appears and there are connections between this case and an old case Mike handled - Jesus Martinez (Michael Pe&ntilde;a) - and Mike's usual 'go for the money' attitude takes a turn toward actually seeking justice in the courtroom. A shady dealing lawyer does actually have a conscience and finds a way to prove the truth will out.<br /><br />There are many cameo roles worthy of mentioning - Josh Lucas plays the prosecuting attorney Ted Minton, Pell James is Mike's girl Friday Lorna, Margarita Levieva is the victim prostitute Reggie Campo, Trace Adkins plays the motorcycle gang head Eddie Vogel, and Shea Whigham inhabits the role of the jail snitch DJ Corliss.  But the major attraction here is Matthew McConaughey's Oscar worthy role: he is magnetic in his transformation from a lawyer you want to loathe to a victor you want to hail.  Marisa Tomei is once again given the opportunity to demonstrate just how fine an actress she is. This is a fast moving, well-scripted film that is simply one of the better moves to come out in a while.  Highly recommended.  Grady Harp, July 11s transformation from a lawyer you want to loathe to a victor you want to hail.  Marisa Tomei is once again given the opportunity to demonstrate just how fine an actress she is. This is a fast moving, well-scripted film that is simply one of the better moves to come out in a while.  Highly recommended.  Grady Harp, July 11

0679759328|4.0|Beautifully written, intelligent, reflective, understated and elegiac in tone, there is a pervading sadness that runs throughout this novella is the charming and thoughtful story about Edith Hope, a successful middle-aged novelist of romantic fiction.<br /><br />While she is pragmatic about the real world of the living, she never denies her fictional heroines the mythical joys of true romantic journeys and endings. She goes to stay at the genteel, select Hotel du Lac, an old world establishment in Switzerland, to reflect on recent events in her life. And, during her time there, Edith gets to know some of the hotel's colorful residents, all beautifully drawn.<br /><br />There's Monica, with her tiny dog that she passes her hotel food to. Monica has an eating disorder, and focuses mainly on cakes, coffee and cigarettes to keep her going - while vaguely thinking about her marriage that has come to an impasse.<br /><br />We encounter the relentlessly self-obsessed, rich, always-on-display and well-dressed, elegant Mrs Pusey and her shadow daughter, Jennifer (acting as truncated Greek Chorus to Mrs Pusey's endless exclamations about her own life and opinions).<br /><br />Then we have stalwart, sad, alone Mme de Bonneuil, dumped by her only son to live for part of each year at the hotel.<br /><br />And Mr Neville, charming, devilish, always insightful, but without sentiment or love, who intrigues Edith and is the catalyst for her to consider making fundamental changes in her life.<br /><br />He does this by questioning her mode of living and her way of thinking about love and relationships and self (he's an advocate of self-interested living only), and proposing marriage (but not love).<br /><br />Faced with a pattern and routine in her life that Edith finds both comforting and sad, including her affair with a married man, Mr Simmons, and for which she is typically pigeon-holed, she is regarded as less than she really is in terms of character and depth. Such conflicts act as catalysts that, combined, conspire to a decision that ultimately leads her to the Hotel du Lac.<br /><br />The dialogue and characterisation are consistently rich, entertaining and often provoke the reader into reflecting on his or her own approach to love and a life worth living, and what this says about ourselves. At the end of the novella, Edith's decision and next step, reflects her full awareness of her life to date, and the options available to her, including that of taking a radically different, perhaps more positive (self-interested) approach to her life, her decision is very much her own and true to who she is.<br /><br />A moving meditation on personal choices, love and life-changing decisions and ways of living. Highly recommended.t ultimately leads her to the Hotel du Lac. At the end of the novella, Edith's decision and next step, reflects her full awareness of her life to date, and the options available to her, including that of taking a radically different, perhaps more positive (self-interested) approach to her life, her decision is very much her own and true to who she is.    A moving meditation on personal choices, love and life-changing decisions and ways of living. Highly recommended.

B004LWZW2E|4.0|Let me start by saying I actually liked this movie, well I like most of this movie. The first 3/4 of this movie is genuinely suspenseful and at some points even scary. Unfortunately this movie, like many others in the genre, hits a major setback in the last act. It suffers an identity crisis! This movie becomes a huge mess of some of the best and mostly worst moments of Poltergeist, Nightmare on Elm Street, and Inception. I was disappointed with the way the movie turned out after such superb acting and the outstanding visuals throughout most of the film. Rose Byrne (I highly recommend two of her other movies Sunshine and Bridesmaids) who plays Renai did an excellent job making the fear believable which goes a long way in this kind of Paranormal Activity themed movie. These kind of movies are becoming more and more popular these days...you know the formula, 45 minutes of doors slamming unexplainably, dishes or other household items flying across the room or falling off shelves, strange voices being heard from upstairs, blurry or shadowy figures seen in windows or dark areas of hallways. Then there's the last 45 minutes where it gets more intense and things actually start happening. Overall, this method has proven effective and enjoyable.     Concering the technicle specs on the movie I have no complaints. The Blu Ray picture quality and sound on this movie is crisp and clear. The extras on the disc are worth watching.      Overall, I enjoyed this movie. I just had a tough time with the way the last 30 minutes went. It really dragged the movie down. The fire demon had a lot of potential, but ended up being comical rather than terrifying. I would suggest this movie to anyone that enjoys modern horror movies.
0226443221|5.0|In Heat Wave, the author presents a compelling and complex portrait of a natural and social disaster. Many of us might not think of a heat wave as a natural disaster in the way we think, say, of hurricanes or tornadoes or earthquakes. (I hadn't thought this way.) But in the U.S., as the author documents, heat waves have taken more lives than the other three events combined.<br /><br />The 1995 heat wave in Chicago was more than a natural disaster, it was a social disaster. It was social because many of the deaths could have been prevented, the author contends. Through a mix of historical research and interviews, the author shows how issues such as age, race, and economics affected those who lived, and those who died. The author is at his most compelling when he compares North Lawndale and South Lawndale. Although both communities are similar in terms of income, North Lawndale is primarily African American, while South Lawndale is primarily Hispanic. The death rates in North Lawndale were significantly higher than in South Lawndale during the heat wave, and the author presents an extensive study of what might have caused that. He even goes so far as to compare the abilities of small, independent churches (prevalent in North Lawndale) and large, Roman Catholic churches (prevalent in South Lawndale) to look after parishioners.<br /><br />What emerges from the author's extensive research is a complex portrait. Through his research, he brings in numerous players, not only community members but experts from the fields of medicine, politics, science, and journalism. This book is worth reading not only for understanding how a heat wave could kill over 700 people but also for understanding how citizens, politicians, scientists, journalists, and others are likely to react to natural disasters.

There is nothing inside the jacket, no booklet, papers, etc.  This was purchased for my daughter as part of her collection and she wasn't happy with the packaging.  All in all it's good for a copy just to view.
B004Y1USJE|4.0|Being a fan of the band since the early 70's, I pre-ordered a copy of \\"Fly From Here\\" when I saw the band was releasing a new album.  After two listenings (on a car audio system), I would have to say that I am not disappointed.   The album combines a pop-sensibility, influenced by Trevor Horn's production and writing style, with the longer song-style of the classic Yes era.  Don't expect a the same plunge into the enlightened world of \\"Tales of Topographic Oceans\\", though.  This album is different from the 70's Yes, yet still  combines crafty pop  songwriting style with the all the instrumental breaks that Yes fans have grown to enjoy.  The recognizable rhythm section of Alan White and Chris Squire and the texture of the layering of both electric and acoustic guitars by Steve Howe are all there.   Geoff Downes' although quite different in style from Rick Wakeman adds his own creative voice to the keyboard.       \\"Fly From Here\\", although a longer piece with six individual movements, has several parts that could stand up well as radio-playable singles.  Although I really do wish Jon Anderson could have contributed to this album, I think Benoit David's voice adds a new dimension to the sound which is not strictly a copy of Anderson's vocals.  The vocals actually remind more of the Drama-era sound of Yes when Trevor Horn was with the band.    I enjoyed this Album.  Maybe some Yes fans will not think it is as good as the classic  \\"Close to the Edge\\",  \\"Tales of Topographic Oceans\\", \\"Fragile\\" or \\"The Yes Album\\", but those were really monumental achievements of the prog-rock era that are really hard to surpass.  This new record stands well on it's own in a new time and a place.
0316098329|5.0|Wow. A desolating, overwhelming story, strangely uplifting at the same time.     Meet 5-year-old Jack. He lives in Room with his Ma and no one else. All the rest is... Outer Space. Except for Old Nick who comes by almost every evening to stay with Ma while Jack is sleeping in Wardrobe. Jack and Ma do not like Old Nick, but there is nothing to be done about that...     Little Jack's voice is poignant, almost funny at times and we read the story through his eyes, words, innocence and love for his mother. Innocence and ignorance are what protect him from the evil of his living condition, although his mother does her best to raise him in an impossible-to-imagine situation. \\"Room\\" is the only reality he has ever known.     And then... page after page I was eager to know what could possible happen, if at all possible, to change that kind of life... The author was just great to convey certain feelings and emotions and oh, what a lovely character Jack is. And his Ma. Courageous, tenacious, desperate Ma.     Every object in Jack's world has a capital letter (Room, Table, Chair etc) conveying the sense of belonging, and even contentment, to such place; the capital letters are a writing technicality that add depth to the story. Jack is a wonderful narrator and the story will keep you glued to the pages. Extremely well done to the author.
B004Y1USV2|4.0|Being a fan of the band since the early 70's, I pre-ordered a copy of \\"Fly From Here\\" when I saw the band was releasing a new album. After two listenings (on a car audio system), I would have to say that I am not disappointed. The album combines a pop-sensibility, influenced by Trevor Horn's production and writing style, with the longer song-style of the classic Yes era. Don't expect a the same plunge into the enlightened world of \\"Tales of Topographic Oceans\\", though. This album is different from the 70's Yes, yet still combines crafty pop songwriting style with the all the instrumental breaks that Yes fans have grown to enjoy. The recognizable rhythm section of Alan White and Chris Squire and the texture of the layering of both electric and acoustic guitars by Steve Howe are all there. Geoff Downes' although quite different in style from Rick Wakeman adds his own creative voice to the keyboard.     \\"Fly From Here\\", although a longer piece with six individual movements, has several parts that could stand up well as radio-playable singles. Although I really do wish Jon Anderson could have contributed to this album, I think Benoit David's voice adds a new dimension to the sound which is not strictly a copy of Anderson's vocals. The vocals actually remind more of the Drama-era sound of Yes when Trevor Horn was with the band.     I enjoyed this Album. Maybe some Yes fans will not think it is as good as the classic \\"Close to the Edge\\", \\"Tales of Topographic Oceans\\", \\"Fragile\\" or \\"The Yes Album\\", but those were really monumental achievements of the prog-rock era that are really hard to surpass. This new record stands well on it's own in a new time and a place.
B000F0UUIM|5.0|John Wayne, the duke. That really should say it all, but since that probably wont fly, I'll pontificate further. From the opening shot, a door being open and through it seeing the wide, open red desert, you know you're in for an old school western treat. I first saw this film not that long ago, probably around Christmas, 2010. It was AMC, and I decided to sit down with a pizza in the freezing cold and watch it. I was, to say the least, AMAZED. At sixteen, I'd never really seen a John Wayne film, as sad as that is, its true. My dad's always been a huge fan, but I was never able to get into the old westerns, that is, until I saw this one. Wayne's performance as the bigoted Ethan reminded me so much of the people I'd see and meet, hard shelled, soft centered. A real anti-hero, and a fabulous performance. I live in California by the way, Central Valley, Nor Cal, and what I mean by him reminding me of people I know if, is well, some of my fellow Caucasians are well-meaning morons, I've been around many that just constantly insult the Hispanic population around here, which just makes them dislike us in general even more, a vicious cycle if there ever was one. Anyway, I could relate to the young character of Martin, perhaps the moral character of the story, trying to hold back the old ways, trying to keep justice from becoming in-justice, just faced in the opposite direction. The characters all seem so real, even after fifty years, and many changes in the styles of film acting, John Wayne still holds his ground for me. And I have, yes, grown to love many a John Wayne film, from Rio Bravo to The Sons of Katie Elder, is, most definitely, in my top twenty favorite actors. The story itself revolves around Ethan and Martin trying for over ten years to find a girl who was kidnapped by a group of Comanche, who also slaughtered and raped the girls parents and siblings. The real greatness of this film is the interactions between Wayne and Jeffery Hunter(Martin), and how, at the endof the film, Wayne's character, Ethan, does change into a better, less bigoted and prejudiced man. The only thing that I could see from the film that could have been better, or perhaps just enhanced the film, would be the final act, I felt like it ended too quickly and happily, though I think it DOES work, I almost do wish that it ended more grimly, and that the film had more of the somber elements that are found through out, but, as it lies, it is a grand and wonderful film.

B000WC3864|5.0|I'm pretty sure I cant say anything NEW about this film that my drones of fellow horror film fanatics haven't already said, but heck, why not try? My dad first introduced me to the Evil Dead series when I was about ten years old, back in '04 or '05. I'd never seen a Sam Raimi film, except for the Spider Man films. Since I left the womb I'd been watching horror films, I remember being like eight years old and skimming the racks in my small video store for the weirdest, craziest horror film I could find, sometimes renting crap, and other times renting insane and awesome movies like Saw 1(I dont care for the other Saw movies) or stuff like Cabin Fever. Yes, I watched movies like this in my prime youth, well, maybe not eight, but like ten or eleven. But when my dad popped in his old VHS of Evil Dead 2, I didn't like it, in fact, I thought it was retarded. Wait! Dont pull those triggers yet, fire squad, let me explain. I was ten, okay? I didn't get, nor was I fan at the time of campy films. But then a year or two later, I saw Evil Dead on IFC. THAT changed my view FOREVER on horror films. I was amazed by it, the cinematography, its complete and absolute awareness of what it was, and what it wanted to be, Bruce Campbell, oh, what a sexy beast, and the forest rape scene! Come on! It was hilarious, out there, insane, crazy, scary, and just fun. It was a thrill ride, and I knew I had discovered something amazing. I went back and watched Evil Dead 2, and finally liked it. In fact, I loved *it* as well, not nearly as much as Evil Dead, but still loved it. Then I saw Army of Darkness, and well, lets just say when I first saw AoD, I crapped myself in the wake of its awesomeness. Evil Dead is one of those films that, if I'm having a late night horror film marathon, which I have like, once every four weeks or so, it has to go first, second, or last. In front, after Re-Animator, or just after Hills Have Eyes(original, remake sucked). Its one of those films thats not only just a grand tour de force in horror, but also inspiring, and lets you realize that you too could make films, you just need the right ingredients for the meal. :)

After watching her interview on ABC several days ago, I decided this book was a must read. The book is graphic, descriptive, and painful. That said, it is also beautiful in parts. Jaycee's experience is so horrific, it is almost unbelievable, and I can't even imagine the strength it must have required for her to put it on paper. I want to personally thank her for telling her story. She is an inspirational and amazing human being.

B000063DFS|3.0|I tend to praise this album pretty heavily when I talk about it.  Zakk Wylde was let off his chain much more, his hyper shredding, his pinch harmonic driven sound still haunts Ozzy to this day.  It's actually funny now to listen to new Ozzy albums, because even though Zakk has been long gone, Ozzy's writers and session guitarists are still trying to copy this sound on here.  That is actually quite an achievement when you consider the fact that the Randy Rhoads was the one that defined Ozzy Osbourne as a solo artist, and was essentially responsible for putting Ozzy back in the spotlight.  As for the quality of the songs on here, it is quite hit or miss.  \\"Mr Tinkertrain\\" has a whammy bar bending, squealing, intro and a powerful pinch harmonic driven riff.  \\"Mama, I'm Coming Home\\" displays Zakk's southern styled guitar wizardy to great effect.  \\"No More Tears\\" is quite literally one of the heaviest riffs known to man, which is ironic considering this is one of the most squeaky clean albums in the metal genre.  Why the three star rating after such praise you might be thinking?  After the riff filled \\"S.I.N\\", the album spirals downhill until the final track \\"Road To Nowhere\\" closes the album off in decent fashion.

B00005K9LK|3.0|Judas Priest were a bit of an enigma throughout most of the 80's.  They were equally repugnant and inviting in their song writing habits.  They had honed in the art of making successful commercial songs and were exploiting this tendency with mixed results.  \\"You've Got Another Thing Comin'\\" for me falls into the category of a tired and boring failure.  On the flip side of the coin the one two punch of \\"Hellion\\" and \\"Electric Eye\\" could easily serve as a noteworthy introduction to the band if you had never heard them before.  \\"Riding on the Wind\\" is a personal favorite of mind, a song that tends to get lost in discussions of great Priest songs due to the bands massive catalog.  \\"Bloodstone\\" has a really cool opening guitar riff.  Devil's Child even sounds a bit like an AC/DC song.  When speaking on behalf of the hit or miss nature of the band throughout the 80's songs like \\"Pain and Pleasure\\" and \\"(Take These) Chains\\" become perfect fodder.  Even the title track \\"Screaming For Vengeance\\" fails to inspire even a twitch of interest.  Once you have gotten your hands on all of the 70's Judas Priest albums, tread into the 80's with caution, they had already begun their descent from greatness.

B00006LLLN|5.0|I give this product full marks. AAA+ it was on my doorstep in less than a week. Thanks for your service.    Ross
0553801473|5.0|I loved reading A Dance with Dragons, but I certainly did not always enjoy it. In fact, certain parts of the book are so dark they defy the imagination. Defenders of the darkness of the A Song of Ice and Fire series have often compared the books' grittiness to the evil of our own reality. But the world that sprang forth from the mind George R. R. Martin is perhaps even darker than our own miserable planet. Various parts of the book brought forth to mind the horrors of events such as the pestilence of the Black Death, or the cannibalistic doom of the Donner Party, or the psychopathic serial killer Robert Hansen. Seemingly all of the misery that human minds can recall from our wretched history has been marshaled into this single tome.<br /><br />Fans of George R.R. Martin's entire oeuvre will recognize that Martin's hallmark is a fascination with broken, corrupt, and decaying worlds. Throughout his fiction are found worlds that have once tasted grandeur, but have rotted away through the efforts of both time and humanity. The world of A Song of Ice and Fire is no different. Its lands are filled with ruined cities, extinct civilizations, and scattered peoples who squabble over memories.<br /><br />Perhaps it is fair that some question why these books should even be called fantasy when they might just as well be labeled as horror? Some of the passages from A Dance with Dragons are far more horrific than anything Hollywood has produced, perhaps ever. But I totally disagree with the notion that fantasy cannot be horrific as well. Too long have we suffered fantasy literature that dwells endlessly in shining castles. Soon enough, the grand castles, gleaming swords, and sage wizards become bland without some truly horrific stuff to spice it all up. Martin provides us with the spices we all crave. They may burn our mouths when we eat them, but once we have tasted them, we crave them. Not everyone can handle spicy food, and not everyone can handle fantasy books filled to the brim with rape, torture, mutilation, cannibalism, and all the other unpleasantries of life.<br /><br />Even if it can be a little dark, A Dance with Dragons is definitely the most magical and fantastical of the books so far. Bran's portion of the story alone was wonderful to read and would probably have made for a great children's fantasy if not for all the the violence. With the return of dragons to the world, magic and sorcery have been let loose, but never do they overwhelm the human elements of the story. Even the sorceress Melisandre misinterprets her visions and resort to cheap tricks to fool her audience.<br /><br />Another valid criticism of A Dance with Dragons might be that it is not as tightly wound as the first three books were. But it is a criticism that is only valid if one does not consider the narrative structure of the series as a whole. The series began with almost every character of note gathered at Winterfell. Through the many infamous twists and turn of the books, the story has become shattered like a crystal vase smashed into the ground. One cannot give readers so much thrilling death and destruction as Martin did in the first three books without breaking a lot of vases. But what death caused, death can also cure. Many smaller characters died off in A Dance with Dragons, and the pace will probably accelerate through The Winds of Winter.<br /><br />It is valuable to remember that Martin has always loved telling short stories set in his broken worlds. And he could not resist inserting some small stories for secondary characters into A Feast for Crows and A Dance with Dragons. The skeptic will use these as evidence that Martin has \\"lost control of his narrative.\\" I prefer to describe this tendency as \\"just plain awesome.\\" The Chicago Sun-Times once said that A Game of Thrones is \\"an absorbing combination of the mythic, the sweepingly historical, and the intensely personal.\\" Where A Feast for Crows was abound with the personal, it lacked the epic portion of the formula. A Dance with Dragons made the personal stories epic in and of themselves.<br /><br />The book isn't perfect. Martin uses some phrases and words too freely and repetitively. I don't think we've seen the words niello, neeps, or serjeant before in the series, but they show up again and again throughout the book in multiple diverse contexts. The inner thoughts of many characters consists of the same phrases repeated many times over. It's effective but definitely not subtle.<br /><br />To be sure, those who scoff at the old chestnut that \\"The journey is more important than the destination\\" will surely dislike this book. A Song of Ice and Fire is in many ways like the river journey of Tyrion Lannister or that of Abner Marsh in Martin's own Fevre Dream or that of Charles Marlow in Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness. That is to say, it is a journey into the darkness of the human soul. A Dance with Dragons is but a leg of that journey, offering scant resolution, but heaps of oppressive doom. The coming winter described so vividly in the novel is but a reflection of the descent of the humans of the novel into a self-imposed hell of hatred, fear, hunger, and death.<br /><br />Those hoping for more resolution in The Winds of Winter may get some, but those hoping for some light at the end of the tunnel will be sorely disappointed, just as they were very likely disappointed in this book. This story can only grow even darker as winter comes in all its fury. I predict that those squeamish of reading about cannibalism will be made ill by the next book. We all know Martin loves detailed descriptions of foodstuffs, and eating each other seems to be the only hope of making it to A Dream of Spring for many of the people of Westeros. How do wights' livers taste? Probably not too bad with some neeps and a nice Arbor red.

B0000028WD|4.0|I'm was just poking around on the internet and ended up reading the reviews to a record (cd) that I own and enjoy listening to.  I agree with the favorable comments.  It's a pretty good little taste of legends in popular music covering a songwriter legend's stuff.    I was particularly in agreement with the several observations about everyone having different favorites on this cd.  Tom Petty and License to Kill stays with me for days after listening.  Willie Nelson is great.  Lou Reed, Johnny Winter, Colvin, Carpenter, and Cash....really good.  So are several others.    I like Bob Dylan.  I'm old enough to have been listening since he first started.  I own several of his vinyl albums and cds, going back a long time.  I know his place in history.  But I don't think he's always a great performer of his own music.  Listening to someone else cover his stuff, and enjoying it, helps me appreciate Dylan's talent.  He wrote some killer songs.
B001P9EQH8|4.0|______________________________________________________________<br /><br />UPDATE 23 Oct. 2013<br />Just revisiting my old reviews and I thought I'd share some new thoughts on this amplifier. I've since upgraded to the Fiio E17 for my Beyerdynamic DT 880s, as the E5 wasn't sufficient. But while I did use it, I was quite pleased with it.<br /><br />Maybe this will be most helpful. Who is this amplifier for?<br />-People who want more powerful sound from their satellite speakers (ex. Cyber Acoustics 3602, as mentioned below)<br />-People who have cheap-to-decent headphones; no, trendy fashion headphones are not decent, and this probably won't make much of a difference<br />-People who want to dabble in high quality audio without dropping loads of cash (for now...)<br /><br />_______________________________________________________________<br /><br />I purchased this headphone amp because I always felt that my music was kind of lacking. I'm only 15, and have no audiophile system or anything, I just use my iPod, so I'm sure anyone that listens with an iPod can relate. Anyways, I have Sennheiser hd203 headphones that I got for $20, and they're actually pretty great - it's just that the iPod couldn't push them at all. I had to really try to hear small details and the bass was weak.<br /><br />So out of the box, this thing's battery was charged, and I put it to use at once. I immediately noticed the warmer quality of sound, and could hear details without trying. I can distinguish the attack and decay of almost any bass, whether it's drum, guitar, or synth. It really is better sound quality, but remember it only improves the sound on higher quality headphones, not junky earbuds or headsets.<br /><br />It comes with all the cables you'll need, and a y-splitter that I can't get to work worth a crap. Which is my only complaint, but really, it was just a little extra thing that didn't even need to come with the amp, so I don't care. Some people say the bass boost switch is a little flimsy, and it sort of is, but I don't foresee any problems with it unless I try to break it. I usually just leave it on bass boost anyways, so there's no need to use it.<br /><br />All in all, if you use an iPod or other mp3 player to drive your high quality headphones and don't want to spend over $30 on some big, bulky \\"portable\\" amp (this one truly is portable, it even clips on to your pants or whatever), buy the fiio e5!<br /><br />UPDATE<br /><br />I've found that when I hook this up to my cyber acoustic 3602 speakers, it cleans up the sound a LOT! Especially the bass.. if I really turned up the volume on some hip hop songs with my iPod, the bass would get kind of muddy, but now the sub produces clean bass at really loud volumes, and I'm surprised at the sound that's now coming out of this 30 watt system.
