1586487981|5.0|The authors identify three major approaches to dealing with world poverty, suggest that whatever their virtues and faults, there is a very piecemeal and pragmatic approach through which significant gains can be made without addressing the systemic obstacles identified by the three approaches. Their analysis is brilliant, focused, rooted in first-rate data sets, yet rich in social detail and anecdotal vignettes. I believe there are probably right, and their approach deserves to be widely studied an evaluated by policy makers in the advanced and developing countries.<br /><br />The dominant school of thought is probably the supply-side theory, most visibly represented by Jeffrey Sachs (the authors call him a \\"supply wallah\\"). According to this theory, the poor are poor because they lack money and resources, and there is a \\"poverty trap\\" such that investment in productive technologies must be very large in order to have a positive and sustainable effect. Because poor individuals, and even poor countries, lack the capacity to finance such investments, they are trapped in a low-level economic equilibrium. For this reason, Sachs and the supply theorists advise that the rich countries transfer a large lump-sum amount of money to a poor country, so it can get over the poverty-trap hump.<br /><br />A second salient school of thought is the demand-side theory, represented by William Easterly and many others. Demand-siders (the authors call them \\"demand wallahs\\") believes that the poor are poor because they do not want to undertake what would be necessary to move out of poverty and there is no poverty trap. Thus, if you throw money and resources to the poor, they consume it immediately rather than using it for long-term betterment.<br /><br />The third school of thought is the corruption school, represented by Acemoglu and Robinson, as expounded in the book Why Nations Fail. According to this theory, countries remain poor because their governments are predatory, exploiting the citizenry by refusing to make investments in productive infrastructure, by direction all profits to cronies, and by permitting rampant corruption that renders creative entrepreneurship unprofitable. According to this school, to which I admit to being very favorable, the supply wallahs are wrong because the resources throw into the system will be appropriate by the rich and powerful, and the demand wallahs are wrong because the poor are actively maintained by the oligarchy in their position of servitude.<br /><br />The authors are very insightful and balanced in presenting the views of these three schools and the evidence that supports these various positions. They also clearly explain their mutual critiques. For instance, the supply wallahs claim that states are predatory and corruption is rampant only because the country is so poor, and the demand wallahs claim that when the people want to move out of poverty, they will reform their governments. I find these defenses of supply and demand wallahs rather tendentious, leaving the corruptions school as the overall most plausible school.<br /><br />I think it is fair to say that Banerjee and Duflo have little sympathy for demand and supply wallahs, but considerable respect for the corruption theory. Their own position is that there are virtually always ways to productively intervene to pull a significant fraction of people out of poverty. The authors, who have collected huge amounts of data and interviewed many poor people from around the world, make the following argument.<br /><br />Most important, the poor in a poor country have about the same array of preferences and capacities as that of the human population as a whole, and humans are substantively rational in making decisions that affect their lives. However, the poor have a lot fewer resources than the well-off, they lack information and skills provided to the well-off, and lack access to such public goods as clean water and consumables subject to food and drugregulations.<br /><br />The poor are therefore extremely heterogeneous. Microfinance organizations like the Grameen Bank therefore provide a general path to affluences, simply because only a fraction of the population has the will and ability to be successful entrepreneurs. On the other hand, entrepreneurs often fail several times before finally becoming successful, so the authors advise an expanded microfinance industry that is more tolerant of the sorts of behaviors that may involve short-term losses, but lead to long-run successes. The authors conclude that we must consider microfinance policies as extremely successful and worthy of following, even though it is not panacea for the abolition of poverty.<br /><br />Because the poor lack access to social services freely available to the non-poor, the authors advocate such measures as providing clean water to poor villages and adding nutrients, such as iron, to staple foods. This, they argue, is not charity but simply the extension to poor of services already supplied to the rest of society.<br /><br />Concerning education, the authors believe that poor parents are usually very eager to have their children educated, although they may lack the means of enrolling their children in schools or providing for their transportation to and from school. However, too often the content of schooling is determined by what is good for the more affluent classes, so poor children are led voluntarily to quit school. The authors advise that the content of education take into account the preferences and culture of the target population.<br /><br />I cannot do justice to the beauty and intricacy of the argument developed in this book. The authors' main point is that we must look closely at the details of the lives of the poor in order to develop policies to help people to pull themselves out of poverty. This is neither demand or supply wallah-ism, and as they repeatedly stress, real progress can be made even in a society whose government provides a poor environment for economic development.regulations.<br /><br />The poor are therefore extremely heterogeneous. Microfinance organizations like the Grameen Bank therefore provide a general path to affluences, simply because only a fraction of the population has the will and ability to be successful entrepreneurs. On the other hand, entrepreneurs often fail several times before finally becoming successful, so the authors advise an expanded microfinance industry that is more tolerant of the sorts of behaviors that may involve short-term losses, but lead to long-run successes. The authors conclude that we must consider microfinance policies as extremely successful and worthy of following, even though it is not panacea for the abolition of poverty.<br /><br />Because the poor lack access to social services freely available to the non-poor, the authors advocate such measures as providing clean water to poor villages and adding nutrients, such as iron, to staple foods. This, they argue, is not charity but simply the extension to poor of services already supplied to the rest of society.<br /><br />Concerning education, the authors believe that poor parents are usually very eager to have their children educated, although they may lack the means of enrolling their children in schools or providing for their transportation to and from school. However, too often the content of schooling is determined by what is good for the more affluent classes, so poor children are led voluntarily to quit school. The authors advise that the content of education take into account the preferences and culture of the target population.<br /><br />I cannot do justice to the beauty and intricacy of the argument developed in this book. The authors' main point is that we must look closely at the details of the lives of the poor in order to develop policies to help people to pull themselves out of poverty. This is neither demand or supply wallah-ism, and as they repeatedly stress, real progress can be made even in a society whose governmentprovides a poor environment for economic development.

B00127RAJY|4.0|In the 30 Day Shred, Jillian Michaels presents a strenuous workout that promises big results.  For those of you who are unfamiliar with Jillian, she is a hardcore trainer with a mouth to match.  She yells things like \\"I want you to feel like you're going to die\\" and generally has no sympathy for you. She proclaims to be \\"the toughest trainer on Earth\\", and the 30 Day Shred definitely lives up to that statement.    The 30 Day Shred works on Jillian's \\"3-2-1 System\\", which is 3 minutes of strength training, 2 minutes of cardio, and 1 minute of ab work repeated in three rounds of varying exercises.  The workout includes a short warm-up and an even shorter cool down for a total of about 25 minutes of exercise.  It also offers three workouts that increase in intensity.  Jillian makes the sound recommendation that you start with Level 1 and work to the next levels as you become more fit.    The workouts are difficult and not exactly for beginners.  Some moves, especially in Levels 2 and 3, require jumping or plyometrics.  Aside from the usual \\"talk to your doctor before starting a fitness program\\", Jillian doesn't exactly warn you of this before you start the video.  However, she does offer some \\"modified\\" moves for those who can't do plyometrics.    Jillian is a tough trainer, but she doesn't exercise as much as she talks about exercise.  Her \\"girls\\", Natalie and Anita, are the epitome of athletic and perform the workouts with huge smiles.  Jillian usually stops mid-move to go over to one of them and explain what is going on.  Her explanations are helpful for the most part, but the camera just ends up following her around instead of focusing on the exercise itself. Thankfully, the moves are repetitive enough that you can learn them after just a few sessions. However, when you are hopping around your living room like a crazy person, the combination of Jillian's voice and the cheesy techno music can get pretty annoying.  Even still, for the motivated and dedicated exercisers who follow the 30 Day Shred, Jillian does exactly what she sets out to do: She gets results.    I lost almost 30 pounds using this workout and a healthy diet.  I had done little to no exercise before I picked up this video, and I started seeing results almost immediately.  After 30 days, I was able to run a 5k.  I don't consider myself \\"totally shredded\\", but I have muscles and am no longer winded when I work out.  Overall, it is a good workout system for those daring people committed to the challenge and willing to deal with quirks of Jillian Michaels.

If compared to him, Mac, who is the narrator, who should share her emotions with the reader, seemed colder, more shallow, she's always overcompensating. I think that if the author had explored her feelings instead of her speculations the book would have been better.

0375831002|5.0|To preface, I have always been drawn to stories of the Holocaust ever since my first read of \\"Number the Stars\\" in elementary school.  In middle school and high school I read every fiction and non-fiction book regarding WWII that the school libraries had.  Over the years my taste in genres have broadened- but last week I decided to dip into my old past-time and simply searched online \\"great stories/books of the Holocaust\\"- and \\"The book thief\\" came up- I had never heard of it before.  I bought it on my kindle and in the first few pages, I quickly realized that this was not my taste in writing at all.  It was overly creative and the story line felt so ungrounded.  I immediately wished I had ordered the free sample version.  But, not one to abandon an unfinished book, I kept going.  I never ever expected to have been so moved by this unfolding story.  Never before have I encountered writing where I could literally feel the words on my skin.  I am usually a fast reader but it took me more than a week to get through this book simply because there were times where I read a sentence and then needed to go back just to savor its quality.  I know it is listed as young adult, and I am not sure if the rest of Zusak's books actually qualify under that category, but I assure you that no 13 year old could appreciate the quality of writing that you will find in some sections of this novel.  By the end of the book I longed to hold each character in my arms, I was that attached.  If you love to read, hate book \\"fluff,\\" and admire eloquent writing, then this is a book you owe yourself to read. In a way, the creative quality of \\"The Book Thief\\" and the absolute power of the story reminds me of \\"The Life of Pi\\" but with just a bit more soul.
B003UESJEM|4.0|While the media pumps out apocalyptic science-fiction fantasies centering around the world ending in 2012, the story we don't hear about centers on the slow, continuous destruction of people and families in America other than irrelevant en masse news briefs on the state of the global hivemind.  While the movie spends a lot of time with Bobby Walker (Ben Affleck) and how his sudden loss of income affects him and his family, director John Wells made sure he didn't let the talents of the rest of the star-studded cast go to waste.  Most notable is Tommy Lee Jones who is brilliant as a top-level executive struggling against the \\"business-friendly\\" policies of his company and what they do to the lives of those around him.  It ends the way I expected, unfortunately.

We didn't have that D minor with Emma exclaiming from the bottom of her hearth \\"I always loved you so much, Dex\\", as the happiest woman in the world. It was not like that. They both said \\"I love you\\" to each other on irrelevant moments (letters, voice mails and so on). But at that moment, in Paris, there was not the cosmical and epic \\"I love you\\".    Should I recommend this book? How many stars does it deserve? A book that felt me miserable but taught me a great lesson about life is a good or bad book? That's how life is. We learn more on our saddest moments.  Let's see how I fell tomorrow. For now, I will give it three stars. Maybe some days in my life, this book will be 10 stars and some other days it will be zero stars. This thing of stars for this book is totally inappropriate... I just need to get over it and get some fresh air...    My wife was surprised by my reaction. After all, I like opera and depressing European movies. I confess that I was surprised too.
B00008QSA5|4.0|I will diverge from popular opinion and state that this is not the Rock Summit/jam session that it was marketed as (especially in the liner notes, which start: \\"Always, the best things happen after hours, when the cat's away...\\"). What it really is, is an Al Kooper album - his choices define it - and if seen in that light, it's a very good one indeed, unless you don't like Al and his rheumy singing. I happen to like Al a lot, and appreciate him now more than I did back when this came out.     Oh, there are the loose blues numbers like \\"Albert's Shuffle\\", in which Mike Bloomfield participates, but I prefer the tightly arranged tracks like \\"It Takes a Lot To Laugh\\", whose hard-rock transformation sounds nothing like Dylan's original - Al might as well have called it something else and kept the royalties. Maybe it was recorded in a hurry, but it's clear Kooper had it well planned out, and just told Steve Stills \\"do a lick here\\". With Al's double-tracked harmony vocals, it could be a Byrds 45.    My point is, if you don't like the druggy phasing on \\"You Don't Love Me\\" or the horns on \\"Season of the Witch\\", or the ondoline (aka Kooperphone) on \\"Holy Modal Majesty\\", it's because you were expecting a different album, and given the title of this package, who can blame you? Super Session my ass! A crackerjack arrangement like that heard on \\"Man's Temptation\\" could have come right off \\"Child Is Father to the Man\\". The heck with \\"always, the best things happen after hours\\". In this case, the best things happen on studio time, with a producer who has a strong vision.    I deduct one star from the rating for including the horn-less reiterations of \\"Albert\\" and \\"Season\\". Al wanted the horns.
B00005RHGL|4.0|Opening on Christmas Day in 1993, Kurt Russell and Val Kilmer's \\"Tombstone\\" film enjoyed more than a half-year's head start on rival Kevin Costner's similar (and far more expensive) pet project, \\"Wyatt Earp.\\"  Largely through word of mouth, they easily won the battle of the box office.  In terms of pure entertainment, the romanticized \\"Tombstone\\" deserved to win, at least at that time because it carefully treaded the line between an adult Western melodrama (hence, the R rating) and often cartoony but vintage Hollywood clich&eacute;s, making it appealing to a very wide range of audiences.  Its ominous poster tagline, \\"Justice is Coming,\\" spells out perfectly the old-school Western that the movie is.<br /><br />In recent years, star Russell has purportedly admitted to secretly directing \\"Tombstone\\" using credited director George Cosmatos as an artistic front after original writer-director Kevin Jarre was dismissed.  Assuming that is a fact, it makes sense why \\"Tombstone\\" so often resembles a classic Western, since Russell is such an old pro dating back to his childhood working in this genre.  Using his expertise, there are several thematic choices that are simplistically brilliant here.  The four that most come to mind are: 1. asserting Wyatt Earp as a biblical-like Pale Horseman in which death, hell, and justice will follow in his wake; and 2. assigning trademark red sashes to the villainous Clanton-Curly Bill gang, so viewers can easily distinguish the good guys from the bad.  Obviously, no real Old West desperado would have sought that kind of unwanted legal attention, but it works really well for Hollywood's frontier mobsters in this movie who just don't care about anonymity.<br /><br />The third important choice is focusing the film equally on Wyatt and \\"Doc\\" Holliday.  Although Russell coolly has more screen time, Kilmer's flamboyant, rakish take on the tubercular Holliday steals the show.  Yet, by working together, the two actors effectively balance out each other's performances.  The relatively solid all-star ensemble cast, including old hand Sam Elliott, Bill Paxton, Dana Wheeler-Nicholson, Powers Boothe, Michael Biehn, Stephen Lang (a dead-on Ike Clanton),  and even a cameo from Charlton Heston conveys the ambiance of an old-school Western complete with mustache-twirling villains and reluctant ex-lawmen putting the silver badge on again.  The major casting problem lies with Morgan and Virgil's indistinctive blonde wives (who don't have any presence or dialogue) and more so with romantic co-lead Dana Delany.  While Delany enjoys some solid chemistry with Russell, she is miscast as a frisky, young Josephine Marcus, since the real Josie Marcus evidently wasn't anything like her.<br /><br />Lastly, the fourth factor is correctly presenting names and accepted historical events in the right order while heavily embellishing other \\"facts\\" about the great Earp & Holliday-Clanton feud that ignited the legendary Gunfight at the OK Corral and its bloody aftermath.  \\"Tombstone\\" also benefits from a majestic, well-balanced musical score from Bruce Broughton, and the fact that the filmmakers strove to make their Arizona location shooting (in Tucson) as colorful as possible, even with a close recreation of Tombstone itself.<br /><br />The film clearly stumbles when the various cliches (too many to mention) start piling up so close together that you don't need to know the historical back story to sense what is coming next.  Also, because of the huge ensemble cast, many characters (i.e. Jason Priestley's Deputy Sheriff Billy Breckenridge) are under-developed or so one-dimensional that the script treats them like mere after-thoughts.  You may also notice some occasional spots where the actors (including Billy Zane's efforts and Russell's wooden last line to Kilmer) sink into stilted melodrama, which erodes their overall performances.  As I stated in my review of \\"Wyatt Earp,\\" I honestly believe that, had these rival productions actuallyworked together by pooling all their mighty resources, a better and more profitable film would have resulted.<br /><br />Rating: 7.5/10 (In terms of sheer entertainment value, \\"Tombstone\\" trumps the plodding \\"Wyatt Earp,\\" despite its heavy reliance on traditional Western clich&eacute;s and some weak performances.  If they are compared side by side, I would consider the two films as roughly even with an edge to Costner's film for technical merits).<br /><br />P.S.  The impressive DVD special features are pretty solid entertainment and quite fun to watch.
1451629184|5.0|Jaycee tells her story, her horrible nightmare, with such honesty and strength. Some of the details she shares are hard to read- but not reading them doesn't erase that it happened.  Although a terrifying experience, she never lost hope and reflects quite articulately, what she did to make it through each day, week, month, and for several years.  She describes a very lonely life with such simple and heartfelt dreams. She has hope, but you can't imagine how. And when she speaks of the many times of having a dog, bird, cat, or even a spider, around her to care for, she is lifted and feels a purpose, only to have those things eventually gone too.  She re-invents the term survivor. Just a little girl who wants her mom and to wake up from this horrible dream.
B0001US8EO|4.0|In the summer of 1994, actor Kevin Costner's Western mega-epic \\"Wyatt Earp\\" crashed and burned at the cinema effectively halting his lengthy streak of critically-acclaimed hits dating back to \\"The Untouchables\\" in 1987.  At the time, the modestly-profitable rival \\"Tombstone\\" had effectively stolen Costner's thunder by beating him to the box office punch six months earlier and leaving his far more expensive saga as a tired retread.  Still, in its expanded version, \\"Wyatt Earp\\" deserves re-discovery for factors extending beyond Costner's presence alone.<br /><br />I will first address director Lawrence Kasdan and producer Costner's intentions since Costner basically is the movie.  This duo evidently wanted to capture a somber Louis L'Amour-esque look on-screen (the costuming is a dead giveaway), as their tragic interpretation of Earp's life story often resembles an Old West version of \\"The Godfather,\\" replacing mobsters with frontier cops.  Unfortunately, with so many individuals introduced or merely name-dropped in the span of three hours, similar characters (especially rustler Curly Bill and friends) blend together far too easily making it hard to tell them apart.  If you are not already familiar with whom all these historical figures are, then good luck to those who can't recognize who's who.  The same problem extends to the desert backdrop.  As the movie was filmed on location in New Mexico, this would explain why Wichita, Dodge City, and Tombstone largely all look like the same locale.  \\"Tombstone,\\" on the other hand, had the advantage of one primary location, which certainly simplifies the necessary story-telling.<br /><br />With a timeline spanning nearly forty years, \\"Wyatt Earp\\" should be commended for ambitiously giving viewers as much story as possible, but this inevitably causes obvious pacing issues.  Costner may have assumed that lightning would strike twice following the majestic 1990 \\"Dances With Wolves,\\" but this plodding film's ambiance (including James Newton Howard's melancholic score) is unable to successfully carry 180+ minutes without any comic relief or an exhilarating romance (although Costner and co-star Joanna Going are believable as Wyatt and the third Mrs. Earp).  The script's sometimes clunky dialogue also disguises speeches (i.e. Gene Hackman as Earp's father repeatedly spellling out the Earp family credo) and explanations of off-screen incidents as everyday dialogue, which only further muddles the slow narrative.<br /><br />The film's all-star ensemble (also including Dennis Quaid, Mark Harmon, Annabeth Gish, Michael Madsen, JoBeth Williams, Tom Sizemore, Bill Pullman, among many others) is top-notch, as it should be considering the production's estimated $75 million price tag.  Specifically, I give kudos to Dennis Quaid as the film's acting MVP.  Rather than copying Val Kilmer's high-profile, flamboyantly roguish take on John \\"Doc\\" Holliday, Quaid's coarsely authentic approach was certainly overlooked for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar nod (if not the trophy itself).  To Quaid's credit, he  not only looked the part, but he made the tubercular, decaying Holliday as unlikeable as most of his contemporaries thought he was.  Mare Winningham as Wyatt's second wife, Mattie, also merits acclaim.  Others, such as Hackman, Gish, James Gammon, and Joanna Going, in supporting roles, deserve some honorable mention as well.<br /><br />As for Costner's performance, with some reservations, it is generally a positive.  Based upon the various accounts of Wyatt Earp's life that I have read, his stone-faced portrayal of Earp is virtually dead-on.  Further, I would conclude that, although Kurt Russell physically resembled the real Wyatt Earp (and, yes, was more entertaining), Costner's depth drew closer to Wyatt's cold fish personality.  Make no mistake, though: Costner's ego tends to overplay his hand, including twice where he makes short announcements to the stunned saloon crowd upon prevailing in battle.  Somehow,I don't imagine that rowdy drunkards would have been awed into silent fear by Earp's mere presence.  Also, by having other characters tell Wyatt how much better a stage driver, buffalo hunter, shooter, etc. he is than they are, it doesn't really help build a myth; rather, it becomes a bore.<br /><br />The bleak, gritty realism of \\"Wyatt Earp\\" will appeal far more to movie-goers who enjoy historical documentaries as entertainment vs. those who prefer straight-up Hollywood historical fantasy (and, yes, \\"Tombstone\\" is largely a Western fantasy).  Speaking of which, it is known that Costner was originally linked to \\"Tombstone,\\" until he had a falling out with late writer-director Kevin Jarre over the proposed film's scope.  It helps explain the supposed bad blood between the rival productions, as Costner's ego dictated that he must pursue his own epic vision of Earp's life.  He was definitely right in providing the characters far more depth and creating a realistically somber balance.  Case in point: Costner and Kasdan accurately depict an aloof Wyatt as being despised by his sister-in-laws, as his brothers too often deferred to Wyatt's needs over their own wives.  Further, Mare Winningham's performance as Wyatt's neglected second wife, Mattie, is heartbreaking to watch as it removes even more luster from Earp's status as an Old West icon.  Except for conveniently ignoring the real Wyatt's alleged antics as a card shark and opportunistic con artist, Costner's film is and will likely remain the closest Hollywood will come to exploring Earp's legendary life story.  To its credit, the film's classy finale acknowledges that separating fact from fiction is often next to impossible, so Earp's life will always (to some degree) remain a mystery.  Still, real history alone doesn't sell movie tickets.  Despite offering a mostly outstanding Western epic for adult viewers, Costner and Kasdan underestimated the necessity of popcorn entertainment that \\"Tombstone\\" captured so well with mainstream audiences.<br /><br />As a random thought, this epic movie still has extraordinary potential if it were cleverly re-edited, i.e. trimming much of its first third into quick-snippet flashbacks, such as Urilla's (or Irilla's) death, for a more haunting effect on Wyatt's psyche during the Tombstone years.<br /><br />Rating: 8/10 (In most categories, it's a historically superior and better-acted film that ages better than \\"Tombstone,\\" but it sorely lacks the other film's charismatic flavor.  It really depends upon what you are looking for in a big-screen Western: gritty realism or Hollywood fantasy).<br /><br />P.S.  The DVD special features are not necessarily spectacular, but they are certainly some nice, well-produced additions to check out when you have the time.  Included in the special edition are some additional scenes that pad the film's running time past 190 minutes.
B0000A1HQP|5.0|I've found that this type of humor is not what most Americans find entertaining.  It's too slow and subtle which I think is the beauty of it.  French comedies are a genre of its own and this film is a perfect example of it.<br /><br />I grew up in Ukraine where French comedies were extremely popular instead of the usual American pie-in-the face, fart, toilet humor jokes so perhaps I have a different take on this.  This film is brilliant in the most typical French comedy way.  It's subtle and funny and quirky but at the end of the film I feel like all is right since these French comedies usually come full circle.  The Dinner Game is a personal favorite of mine because of all the twists and turns in it and the lessons to be taken from this script.  It's witty and quirky and everything that a French comedy should be.  5 stars all the way and I wish more Americans would appreciate this particular genre.

B004WKOCP8|5.0|I don't normally write reviews but I had to get on here if for nothing else then to raise this album's average from a measly 3 stars. Now Incubus is my favorite band, always has been and always will be. I even have a Chuck tattoo. So with that said you might take this review as biased but I will try my hardest to stay objective. Now usually when I first listen to a new Incubus album, the first time it grabs me in some way. My first listen through this album a couple of months ago I was scared. Nothing seemed to grab me or stand out. Everything blended together. I thought for the first time Incubus had disappointed me. So now I see all these negative reviews and can only hope that people stay with the album so it can become what it has to me. I now realize that this album was totally intentional. This is where they were going to end up if you think about it. Songs like \\"oil and water\\", \\"diamonds and coal\\" and even \\"here in my room\\" are proof of it. No two Incubus albums sound the same. The fact that all these people expect another S.C.I.E.N.C.E. or Make Yourself just shows how much they know about the band. Those albums are over a decade old and even those two records sound nothing alike. With Morning View started the alt-rock influence. The last two albums, CLOTM and Light Grenades sound the most alike, and I attribute that to Ben's funk/soul influence on the band. And now we have If Not Now, When? Just like always the band tweaked their sound for a new record, more drastically then ever before. This album is a slow burn. Keep listening to it and eventually you will just \\"get it.\\" It is very minimalistic and open spaced.  Mike isn't just a guitar player, he plays piano and composes every single song himself. Kilmore doesn't just scratch records, he provides sonic landscapes to add to the feel of the track. Jose's drumming is very calculated and quite often provides the backbone of the best songs. Even Brandon's lyrics which are a lot of the time meant to be indecipherable are much more straight forward and in tune with the album. It is a self-contained masterpiece. If you want a band to stay the same and true to a sound there are plenty of them out there but this band will never be one of them. Don't expect something that is never going to happen. In another 5 years we'll probably hear a new Incubus album that sounds nothing like this.

B004Y1USJE|3.0|'fly from here' is an album where if you singled out any particular song, you could argue it stands on its own merit. that said, together as a whole, it often moves at a lethargic pace. with the possible exception of the closing track (the terrific \\"into the storm\\"), yes rarely stomps on the gas pedal. the end result is reminiscent of the 'drama' album, however a much kinder, gentler version. what tips the scales into the \\"worth owning\\" category is guitarist steve howe's performance, delivering many tasty & memorable licks throughout. i do prefer 'fly from here' over the band's last few studio efforts, but admittedly the material lacks the attitude & ferocity of your typical yes album, lineups notwithstanding. if you're a diehard & have extra money to blow, you should probably get the japanese edition, since the track \\"hour of need\\" has an intro & outro tacked on (totaling an extra 3+ minutes) which is unavailable on other versions....
0545259088|5.0|For months, Tom Culpeper has had it out for the wolves. And now he is finally going to do something about them. Sam has finally been \\"cured\\", and now he stays human...but now it's Grace who is unstable, and this time she is the wolf in danger in the woods. When Sam and Cole get word of the hunt that Culpeper has orchestrated to finally kill the wolves, they know there's no way to stop him. And so they're forced, with Isabel's somewhat reluctant help, to somehow find a way to not only understand the virus that makes them turn into wolves, but save the entire pack.     Maggie Stiefvater is at her very best here. With equal parts action, romance, and moral contemplation, Forever is a lyrical and breathtaking conclusion. The excellent character development in Linger continues into this finale: Sam is forced to face the looming unknown of the future much quicker than he'd like, and become a leader, sometimes without the support of Grace. Grace has Sam, and has finally grasped onto the independence she's been fighting for--but at a large cost. Isabel, despite desperately not wanting to care about the wolves, and sometimes even her new friends, finds herself helping them in ways that could drive a wedge even further between her and her family. And Cole is forced to accept who he has become, for all his failures and successes, and work incredibly hard to create and preserve a new life for himself.     Along the way, both Cole and Sam are at odds with each other and how they view Beck and his actions, both good and bad, and are forced to live and work together to find a way to save the pack. Some unexpected characters step in, and other unseen forces work against the characters, culminating in an ending that is a suspenseful race against time, with some less than perfect consequences. Forever finishes out perfectly, with a note of finality but an open future for the characters of this intensely beautiful trilogy.
B004Y1USRG|4.0|I have been a Yes fan since I got my first copy of \\"Fragile\\".  Every Yes album seems to bring it's own feel. In my opinion, \\"Fly From Here\\" is not their best album of all time (Drama, Talk, Going For The One), but it delivers a very nice Yes experience. Benoit David sounds so much like Trevor Horn.  It lacks the muscle that \\"Drama\\" had, but the production is pristine, and the playing is top notch.  Also, the album packaging is incredible.  I bought it on vinyl (the only way to get a Yes album, in my opinion) and it sounds incredible.      I am on my second listen, and it is getting better the more I listen to it.  Yes not only deserves to be in the rock and roll hall of fame, but they sound great in 2011!

Did I hear some sort of a horn (no, not Trevor) near the end of the track? Hmm. It's a great finale<br /><br />This isn't an album that's very heavy on bass or keyboard solos, and Steve doesn't solo as much as he's done in the past, but it's not necessarily a bad thing. This album is representative as the band playing as a band, for the most part. It's something fresh from this new Yes. I really enjoy this new album and I hope the next one is not too far around the corner. Please work with Trevor again on the next one, guys!<br /><br />Yes is a band. It's not about one particular member, although all of them in one way or another contributed greatly to the history of one of the world's greatest and most dysfunctional rock bands. Yes, it's sad that Jon isn't in the band anymore, but even if he were back in the band, would we have a new album? I highly doubt that. I mean no disrespect to Jon by that comment. The band was put on hold long enough and with this album, they have delivered the goods. I recommend listening to it more than once to \\"get it.\\" Happy listening, everyone!vy on bass or keyboard solos, and Steve doesn't solo as much as he's done in the past, but it's not necessarily a bad thing. B004ZZS4CC|5.0|Like many other readers who have posted here, I read this book cover to cover without putting it down. I admire Jaycee Dugard's courage and incredible spirit. Her story is heart wrenching. Her journals written during captivity were the most compelling portion of the book for me. She presents the classic Stockholm Syndrome manipulated by her rapist/kidnapper. He deprives her of food & water breaking her down systematically over time. Intermittently he treats her with kindness and offers companionship. Eventually she begins to identify with the monster & his wife that snatched her off the street. Jaycee pines for love and acceptance. This story is both riveting and revealing. It evokes images of other kidnap victims like Patricia Hearst. Jaycee not only survives 18 years of abuse and privation, she triumphs over it. Jaycee emerges as heroic in her continuing ability to love and face life with joy. This is a remarkable book written by a remarkable young woman.

B00007KWI9|3.0|Obviously the reason I'm not rating the album higher is because I know extremely well just what Yes was capable of from 1970-1974.  Those were the best years of the bands career in my opinion (and hopefully the opinions of most!)    However, if we were to pretend those classic albums never occurred (WOW is *that* ever a hard thing to picture, haha- imagine if the classic years of Yes never even happened?  Talk about a tragic circumstance!) but uh.. where was I before I started rambling pointless, classic nonsense?  Oh yeah, if we pretend those classic albums never occurred (WOW is *that*... just kidding) it would be very easy for me to give in and allow this album to receive 4, if not 5 perfect stars.      The debut album by Yes has flaws *only* because I'm aware what the band went on to accomplish shortly after.  I think it's fair to base it on my experience with future Yes albums, and if it's not fair?  Well then, tough!  Life's not fair!  I never got what I wanted either!  That's not true, I was a pretty spoiled kid. :)    The best way to sum up the debut album by Yes is like this- do NOT expect tricky time signatures, numerous tempo changes, and the whole kitten kaboodle of everything we associate with the trademark style of Yes and progressive rock.  Throw it all out the window.  Be free!  Toss it out!  Feels good, doesn't it?  Alright, stop tossing.   STOP!  You destructive little monster!  You should be locked up for not knowing when to let up.  :)    The best song, without a doubt, is \\"Survival\\".  Why?  Why is it the best song?  The soulful vocal melody of Jon Anderson.  I'm not even a fan of his singing skills (or his bland vocal range) and he normally doesn't sing soul in my view, however none of that matters in the slightest because the vocal melody blows me away.  It makes me want to search for the heavenly silver star twinkle across the snowy fields and mountains.  It's extremely good, and let me tell you a personal secret- it's not often I say a Jon Anderson vocal melody is extremely good.  I don't like to.  I refuse, just like I used to close my mouth when my mom tried inserting broccoli in there!  I refused to accept stinky things then, and I refuse now.  :)    There's not a lot of sweetness is \\"Sweetness\\".  Unless it's supposed to be short and sweet with a simple vocal melody.  Well okay then- in that respect, it works.  Otherwise, burnt Christmas cookies are sweeter (and I've had my share of those over the years... ugh- why do cookies always burn on the bottom first?  Why don't cooks actually check the bottom of cookies to make sure they're done to prevent them from becoming burnt?  Don't just open the door and look at them- actually LIFT THEM UP!  Don't just assume they're done because the top is done!  It's too late then!!!)      I'm working backwards apparently because my next selection of discussion is going to be to describe \\"Every Little Thingy\\".  No, it can't stand in the same league as the Beatles version.  Then again, the psychedelic intro/guitar jam is quite the marvelous treat!  I bet the Beatles were thinking \\"Yo man, what's up with that?\\" but with a British accent obviously.    WOW, I love when the guitar solo comes in shortly after the 1-minute mark.  Perfecto!  This is definitely what dramatically separates it from the Beatles version, and perhaps even surpasses it.  Nah, the Beatles have better vocals.  Better and warmer.      Oh now, come on!  A song like \\"I See You\\" is a disruptive little stink hazard.  I don't like the fruity vocals at all.  I might like them if you handed me a butterfly net and guided me to a field of carefree insects and blooming dandelions, but not in the confines of my computer room!  \\"La la la la la\\" oh man, just stop it.  STOP IT!!  It's not even funny, haha.  I bet Greg Brady liked it.  Anyway it tries to be jazzy but trying and failing are two separate things.  The light guitar jam at the end saves it from total stinkiness, so let us show an abundance of thankfulness for that.  Otherwise, I can name a few cow fields that smell worse than this.    \\"Harold Land\\" reminds me of Kansas.  The band members of Kansas must have known about this song.  They simply must!  If not, well, get out of Kansas!  Don't be so secluded!  It's a big world out there, hehe.  I mention Kansas because the vocal melody sounds extremely similar to something they'd write such as on their Leftoverture album.   It's repetitive too, and that's not a good thing either.  Jon Anderson repeating the same vocal melody many times in a row?  Either something freaky is going on, or it's an unfocused debut album!      \\"Beyond and Before\\" (or \\"Before and Beyond\\" as my backwards brain insists on doing resulting in constantly changing it to the right way... and that's not true either!  I *really* want to call it \\"Bed & Breakfast!\\") has a vocal melody that takes me back to the late 60's.  I'm there man!   In a dingy smoke-filled room!  It's a really good vocal melody too.  I have nothing particularly comical to say about it.  \\"Say a few words to the wind?\\"  Okay that's funny.  I love it all the same, and I can definitely tell this is the same band that would write the melody to \\"Yours Is No Disgrace\\".   \\"Looking Around\\" has a standard vocal melody that's just... okay.  No great shakes or freedom flowers.   \\"Yesterday and Today\\" is so harmless it mine as well not be here.      Overall, pick up everything Yes did from Time and a Word to Relayer *first* and then march your buns back here pronto and hear their debut.

0553801473|5.0|Dance with Dragons is a worthy successor in Martin's series (though I must say that I liked AFFC better than most people.) There are some caveats, as always. My main quibble is the unfinished plot threads (the past books have tended not to end on cliffhangers. ADWD is akin to ending right after the... shocking moments in A Game of Thrones, and a Storm of Swords especially. But at a length of almost 1,000 pages, I can understand why Martin chose to end it there. There are other quibbles  as well - for instance, the bleak tone (for which I love Martin, but a bittersweet novel must have at least a *bit* of sweet, no?), the much-ballyhooed death that almost nobody actually believes is permanent by this point (why end on a cliffhanger that everyone knows isn't one? Though if I am wrong in this case, it would be an interesting twist), etc.<br /><br />But in the end, it's easier to list what I don't love over the novel than what I do. I would put it on the same caliber as A Storm with Swords if only the author had extended the novel so it wasn't so filled with cliffhangers. I give it a 5/5 because 4/5 is frankly far too low (my rating would be something like 19/20, if more distinction were available.) Not as good as Martin's best writing, but an 'almost perfect' work by Martin is far far far better than most other authors can achieve.

1451629184|5.0|I thought about my closeness to Ms. Dugard's own age throughout this book. I had frequently prided myself on being 'strong' when I was a pre-teen.<br /><br />But truthfully, I never imagined being captured/tortured by two psycopaths: My world then consisted of makeup and boy-bands. And I believed that the world was a relatively safe place.<br /><br />I only knew of one friend who had been abused by their parents. They were quickly whisked away to safety, so the system theoretically 'worked'. Oh, how sheltered and naive those ruminations were. Our generation was not at all safe.<br /><br />Writing this book is (understandably) very courageous of Dugard. It does not provide easy reading, and I actually skipped over entire sections.<br /><br />I was initially interested in seeing if she actually wrote about the State of California's missed prior opportunities to catch the Garrido's. I hope that the parole officers responsible for these serious errors are severely penalized. Focusing on her personal experiences, the book does not delve into this, instead using a 'first-person' approach to show people what living under such unsusual and cruel circumstances was actually like.<br /><br />However, the story is told so readers can actually skip sections and still successfully come away with the basic thrust of the author's survival. People would not be missing much of the plot. Against/under great personal adversity, human beings are resilent creatures. Jaycee bonded with pets as a 'coping' strategy while locked away in the maze of sheds and later worried about the fate of her daughters.<br /><br />The story itself will not make you feel 'good', and it is not actually supposed to. It is not really a book which people are supposed to come away enjoying.  But knowing that Jaycee and her offspring are now safe is trully the happy ending after all of the garbage and abuse which they endured.<br /><br />It would be a suitable personal purchase or maybe for a counselor collection who specialized in recovery from abuse.

0553386794|5.0|Starts with a bang and keeps going.<br />There is plenty of action and intrigue in this book but most of all it is intelligent. There are enough twists in this book to fill a normal fantasy trilogy and a lot of intimations of future changes that could make all the politics and intrigue irrelevant.<br /><br />The main characters are all likeable or hateable as intended, the children are not the sulky, annoying brats used in a lot of novels, they are intended to be children of their culture brought up on violence and war where life can often end early so marrying at 13 and going to war at 15 aren't considered strange and we are completely sucked into their viewpoint.<br /><br />There are plenty of changes in direction as the book goes and there are a variety of plot threads to keep track of as they impact upon each other and we can never be sure of who is lying to who and to what end.<br /><br />A great start to the series.

0553801473|4.0|It has been SIX LONG YEARS since George R.R. Martin last released a book in his Song Of Ice And Fire Sequence. That's a pretty long wait.<br /><br />So was \\"A Dance with Dragons: A Song of Ice and Fire: Book Five\\" worth the wait? Well... yes and no. It returns to much-beloved characters like Tyrion, Bran and Daenarys and slowly moves us toward the complex, treacherous endgame of Westeros' power struggles. But it's also very slow-moving, and sometimes it feels like events are happening too slowly.<br /><br />After killing his father, Tyrion flees his native land and ends up adrift in another, dependent on others for safety and shelter. So instead, he forges a new destiny for himself. Meanwhile, Bran is en route to the Wall, only to run into wargs and discover new facets of his mysterious skinchanging power.<br /><br />The new Night Watch commander Jon Snow finds himself facing an incoming horde of wildlings, as well as the presence of grouchy King Stannis and his bloodthirsty priestess Melisandre. Jon is determined to keep doing what he thinks is right, but his steadfastness may also be his undoing.<br /><br />Having conquered the city of Meereen, Daenarys starts learning the ropes of queenship there, as well as caring for her three rapidly-growing dragons. Of course, she soon discovers that it's a lot harder than it sounds, as she becomes enmeshed in a deadly tangle of love, treason, ambition and bloody murder.<br /><br />It's honestly hard to sum up a George R.R. Martin's books without giving away far too much, or going into countless detailed subplots. However, this book is very slow moving, and there isn't a lot of forward momentum until the last several chapters. It feels like Martin is arranging his vast chessboard for a the final clash, but it's going to be slow moving until he's done.<br /><br />However, for a Martin book, even moving forward slowly is a striking experience. He embroiders this bloodspattered tapestry with vivid poetic prose prose (\\"he fluttered like a burning leaf, a moth caught in a candle flame\\") mingled with sex, and quite a bit of gruesome violence handled very casually (when a man is beheaded, someone asks, \\"Can I have his boots?\\").<br /><br />The only very flawed scene that springs to mind is Daenarys' final scene, which is so melodramatic as to be almost silly. And yes, it ends on a multiple cliffhanger. Prepare to scream in frustration.<br /><br />As for the vast cast of flawed, intriguing characters, Martin only handles some of them -- we see more of Bran's burgeoning powers as he grows into a young man,  Jon's bleak, frustrating life as a commander, the ever-embittered Tyrion afloat without his family's influence, and Daenarys' quiet nature at war with her \\"dragon's blood.\\" Well, he touches on some of the other characters -- such as Cersei, who hits rock bottom -- but mostly focuses on those four. And without revealing too much, yet another much-loved character seems to have bitten the proverbial dust.<br /><br />\\"A Dance of Dragons\\" dances too slowly, but it's still a deeply absorbing read -- and it feels like George R.R. Martin is arranging the grand finale. Let's hope the next book doesn't take six years.ed like a burning leaf, a moth caught in a candle flame\\") mingled with sex, and quite a bit of gruesome violence handled very casually (when a man is beheaded, someone asks, \\"Can I have his boots?\\").<br /><br />The only very flawed scene that springs to mind is Daenarys' final scene, which is so melodramatic as to be almost silly. And yes, it ends on a multiple cliffhanger. Prepare to scream in frustration.<br /><br />As for the vast cast of flawed, intriguing characters, Martin only handles some of them -- we see more of Bran's burgeoning powers as he grows into a young man,  Jon's bleak, frustrating life as a commander, the ever-embittered Tyrion afloat without his family's influence, and Daenarys' quiet nature at war with her \\"dragon's blood.\\" Well, he touches on some of the other characters -- such as Cersei, who hits rock bottom -- but mostly focuses on those four. And without revealing too much, yet another much-loved character seems to have bitten the proverbial dust.<br /><br />\\"A Dance of Dragons\\" dances too slowly, but it's still a deeply absorbing read -- and it feels like George R.R. Martin is arranging the grand finale. Let's hope the next book doesn't take six years.
0307593495|5.0|Title: The Troubled Man  Author: Henning Mankell  Publisher: Alfred A. Knopf, 2010    The engrossing Wallender series by Henning Mankell comes to a satisfying end with this final book, the eleventh in the internationally bestselling series. With each novel Kurt Wallender, the brilliant, brooding and introspective Swedish detective seems to get moodier and increasingly inward looking. In The Troubled Man, he is faced with tracing what turns out to be naval espionage activities during the Cold War days and coaxing four-decades old memories from people who were there at the time. The reason Wallender becomes involved is that his daughter's future father-in-law vanishes while on a stroll in Stockholm. Before he retired, the man was a high ranking officer in the Swedish navy. Wallender feels vulnerable having just turned sixty and needs to prove to himself that he's not failing by finding out what happened and, particularly, why. He worries through today's Swedish society and his own self-doubts while, in typical fashion, neglecting his health, his friends and his associates in order to sort out how the confounding jumble of events from today interact with the distant past. A must-read and one that, for readers who are not familiar with Mankell, will have them coming back for more Wallender fixes.
0545259088|4.0|Maggie Stiefvater's tales of winter werewolves have always been far more striking and poetic than any other werewolf books I can think of. And she brings the story of Grace and Sam to a close in \\"Forever,\\" a hauntingly bittersweet, sumptuously-written coming-of-age tale with a somewhat flawed finale.<br /><br />Spring has returned Grace to her human form, but she's still unstable -- she keeps turning back into a wolf and running into the woods. Sam has spent the whole winter waiting for her, despite the people of Mercy Falls thinking he's a budding serial killer. And Cole is hotly pursuing a cure for lycanthropy, using himself as a guinea pig.<br /><br />However, Sam and Grace's idyllic reunion is ruined by another death -- another girl is found savaged by a wolf (pretty obviously Shelby). Isabel's father arranges for the wolves to be exterminated (with HELICOPTERS), leaving the teens only a few days to lead the wolves to safety. Otherwise, Grace may be among the dead.<br /><br />Maggie Stiefvater is one of the rare young-adult authors who has lyrical, hauntingly lovely writing. Fragmented thoughts arrange themselves into minimalist poems, and mundane situations take on the delicate crystalline quality of a romantic dream (\\"it was just me, broken into pieces, slivered like glass, made into something new\\").<br /><br />\\"Forever\\" centers on three important subplots -- the need to save the wolf pack from Isabel's revenge-obsessed father, the quest for a lycanthropy cure (especially for Cole), and the teenagers shedding their childhood problems as they prepare to set out into adulthood. The story drifts along between these three subplots, with some bloody, tightly-paced action scenes (like the grand finale) woven in.<br /><br />And her characters are just as brilliant as her writing -- four troubled teenagers, who are breaking away from their pasts and their weird parents. Grace and Sam settle into an idyllic little world of their own, but are haunted by the hostility towards Sam and Grace's feelings about her parents. And Stiefvater spends a lot of time focusing on Cole and Isabel's tumultuous relationship, as Cole goes all brilliant mad scientist.<br /><br />One problem: the ending is rushed. Isabel, Cole and Grace take dramatic actions that seem like they should have massive consequences... but they don't. At all. Shouldn't Isabel's dad be having a rage-induced stroke or something?<br /><br />The payoff feels rushed and a little incomplete, but otherwise \\"Forever\\" is a striking, romantic little finale for Stiefvater's brilliant trilogy. This is everything \\"Twilight\\" failed to be.t her parents. And Stiefvater spends a lot of time focusing on Cole and Isabel's tumultuous relationship, as Cole goes all brilliant mad scientist. The payoff feels rushed and a little incomplete, but otherwise \\"Forever\\" is a striking, romantic little finale for Stiefvater's brilliant trilogy. This is everything \\"Twilight\\" failed to be.

The book might be worth the price for the meatball sandwich recipe alone.    I'm so happy I bought this book--it took some practice, but it's a lot of fun and the bread and croissants are amazing.

B000UJ48VI|4.0|This movie has a loose interpretation to the novel Lolita in the sense that the time in history at which this film was produced was different than that of today's world. For instance, there is not as much sex in this film as is in the book Lolita. Stanley Kubrick begins the film with his signature ending-first directing style. For something that was made in the 1960's, Kubrick gets away with a lot that could be taken as borderline decency. One small piece of evidence to this is the name change of \\"Camp Q\\" to \\"Camp Climax\\". It is true that this setting of the novel was on Lake Climax, but in all seriousness, the change is a method of foreshadowing the symbolic lack of adolescent purity that the main character, Humbert, has a strong fetish for. There are some minor changes from the book in terms of its conclusion as well as its beginning. The film completely leaves out the psychosis factor of Humbert's own adolescent sexual experiences and how it causes him to develop his obsession for nymphets. It is definitely worth seeing, as this is one of Kubrick's earlier works, as well as a good interpretation of Nabokov's story.

0618918248|4.0|This book is aimed at what Dawkins sees as a growing population of closeted non-believers -- people who associate themselves with a religion or profess some vague spirituality, but don't, in their heart of hearts, really believe that there's a God. The God Delusion is his attempt to empower that population to take the small step to unapologetic, open atheism.  Dawkins begins by building a strong case that the traditional Judeo-Christian idea of God (as opposed to a more universal, philosophical concept of God, which he deals with less effectively) -- a supernatural being who created the forms of life on Earth, hears and responds to our prayers, brought about specific miracles and signs, directly communicated with scripture writers, wishes us to subscribe to specific beliefs and values, and preserves our personalities beyond the death of the brain that generates them for reward or punishment in some afterlife -- is unsupported by scientific evidence or logic. According to him, the main reason people DO believe has nothing to do with the rational validity of Christianity and Islam's claims, and everything to do with the huge social and political influence that the world's major religions continue to wield, the emotional power of their myths, and the simple fact that many of us never really examine why we believe what we believe.  Dawkins has been accused of being \\"scornful\\", but I felt that his manner was more probing and frank than mean-spirited -- the same way he would no doubt rebut a scientific hypothesis. As an agnostic with a Christian upbringing, I found that his eloquent criticisms of religion's more superstitious aspects expressed many of my own reasons for growing disillusioned with faith and dogma when I was in college. Outdated myths... check. Lack of evidence... check. The oppression and cruelty of fundamentalism... check. Its close-mindedness, the inconsistency of its morals, its many conflicts with science and a rational worldview, the endless human effort and blood wasted on pitting equally flawed belief systems against one another -- check, check, check, check. He makes a very good case, at the least, that society shouldn't shy away from honest discussion of religion's faults and flaws.  Without a doubt, Dawkins is a dyed-in-the-wool atheist, and he doesn't stop with religion itself, but lays assault to what he calls \\"belief in belief\\" -- the conviction among more wishy-washy non-believers (such as myself) that faith in a God has a benevolent side that's still worthy of respect. He systematically turns his guns on the arguments commonly used to justify religion: that it's necessary for morality, that it provides meaning and happiness, that it's compatible with science, that it's part of American government, that it deserves respect for the sake of cultural diversity (though he's careful to emphasize that he's in favor of teaching ABOUT various faith systems, since they're integral to understanding history and literature).  In general, I earlier parts of the book stimulating and well-argued, though I thought Dawkins went a little too far in later chapters on \\"culture war\\" issues, producing a self-righteous tirade against faith propelled more by smugness than data. Not the way to defeat the emotional needs that draw many people to churches, temples, and mosques. I also didn't appreciate his dismissive, \\"you've got enough data, pick one side or the other\\" challenge to agnostics and the \\"spiritual but not religious\\". And a commenter to my review indicated that he's a bit presumptuous in including certain famous thinkers, such as Carl Sagan, in his camp. Finally, I don't agree with his easy disposal of ultimate questions -- when considering an infinite, eternal chain of universes, there's simply no way for the human intellect to explain its origins, whether through top-down Creation or bottom-up Evolution. There's no reason to believe that this cosmic continuum doesn't contain god-like entities, that we aren't part of some larger universal consciousness, or that the laws of the greater multiverse, beyond our small, localized window of awareness, are remotely within our ability to understand. I still believe in transcendence and transcendent experience.  However, while Dawkins didn't cure me of my agnosticism, this book helped put it in clearer perspective. For other readers, if you're an atheist, an agnostic, a deist, a pantheist, or one of Dawkin's closeted skeptics, you'll probably get something out of The God Delusion, including more confidence to speak your mind. If you're an open-minded religious person, I think you will come away with a better understanding of the factors that draw thoughtful non-believers to atheism, which I hope you will contemplate with honesty. I think there remains plenty of room for debate about God as an abstract metaphysical concept, but this book offers an effective and, given the increasing politicization of religion, necessary challenge to superstition.

She truly did not understand what was happening to her.  I think people see this grown woman now and forget that she was only eleven when her life was thrown totally off course.  People forget what it was like to be eleven years old--how impressionable and malleable you are at that age.  Nothing in this world could prepare an eleven year old child for what these people did to her.  I read this memoir in one day.  Dugard's heart and spirit really come through in every page--her essence--and she is a remarkable and beautiful soul.  There is so much to learn from her story.  Her story is heartbreaking. Literally at times I felt nauseous and weepy and at other times enraged.  I wanted to gather that little girl in my arms and make everything okay.  I also wanted to do very not nice things to all the evil and uncaring people who hurt and failed her over the years. It's truly amazing to me that after all she's endured she ends this memoir on such a hopeful note. She is an example to all of us.  Read this and you'll be absolutely appalled at all the things you take for granted.  I wish her and her family so many wonderful things.

B004ZZS4CC|5.0|I started this book yesterday and couldn't put it down until it was finished.  I think most people know the story of what happened to Jaycee but this is her account... in her own words... as she recalls it.   So while I won't rehash the basis of the story, I will tell you what surprised me the most...  which were her personal reflections throughout the book.  This is where she would break from telling the past and reflect on how she feels about it now, in hindsight, what therapy has helped her realize, etc etc.  These are the parts that show her courage, her personal determination, her strength...  things you don't see in a short media frenzied news story.  So while parts of the book are hard to read, this is not someone just trying to recount the horrors of what happened to them in order to make a quick buck... no, this is a story to help other people see survival is possible... healthy survival from the the most horrible tragedies.   It also shows how therapy can be healing if you have a good therapist and a willing patient to help the healing process.  She could have allowed this tragedy to define her, to make her angry and bitter, to retreat into a life of expecting everyone to cater to her because she was \\"owed\\" something for what happened to her.... but she doesn't do that.... far from that... in fact, she is thankful for life, she decided not to allow the horrible couple who did this to her have one iota of control over her anymore, she is focused on helping her daughters make successful life choices... she's an inspiring woman.  Highly recommend this book!

0439023513|2.0|SOME SORT-OF SPOILERS IN HERE  This is a sadly bad and rushed-feeling ending to a page-turner; it left me angry for being let down. I don't mind an unhappy or ambiguous ending, but one that is simply weak is inexcusable. My main complaint is that although the main character is portrayed as a strong, proactive protagonist throughout the series, and although she is present as the final events go down, she has basically nothing to do with any of them and is in fact completely helpless through the last half or so of the book, if not the entire thing. The story remains exciting and full of action and violence, but what a let-down when you realize that Katniss's struggles through three books are all futile in very important ways; she may be (barely) alive, bad guys may be defeated, but the character traits of fortitude and control she supposedly fought for -- and that seem to be major developing themes in the novels -- seem to be an illusion (not unattainable -- just missing) and the reader feels misled. You are led to ask what the point was of all the excitement and, frankly, of reading the trilogy. Even those who applaud the Girl Power aspect of the book must feel really hollow inside, because the main character remains a helpless pawn.     I hope the author comes out with an alternate third book in which Katniss, who is portrayed throughout as an action-taker struggling to control her own life and future, actually takes action on any level and controls these -- and especially that the movie corrects this very weak and cynical ending. 0553801473|2.0|It's not that A Dance With Dragons is a bad book.  Its fine. The problem is that it suffers from the same problems as A Feast for Crows.  I had hoped that with the reintroduction of some of the most beloved characters in the series, and with the generally cooler reception of Feast, its flaws would be lacking. Sadly, that is not the case.<br /><br />Flaws include meandering, often repetitive, chapters, the introduction of characters I personally developed little care for (and seemed were introduced a little late in the game for me to take seriously and, more damning, appeared to accomplish nothing) and the general sense that Martin has lost control of his story.  Some motivations driving characters are revealed and they appear to not really conform to how those characters were last portrayed 11 years ago.  Where once Martin would use one chapter, well placed in the middle of a dramatic sequence, to set forth the developments of the story, now several chapters tell the same tale. There is no truly wonderful mental picture drawn in your head as there was in the first and third books especially. It also seems the editors were in such a rush to profit that they did not completely edit and were so desperate to put something out there that they did not call Martin on a story that has lost its focus.<br /><br />That being said, the book is not all bad. Martin's writing style is still largely intact.  Most particularly the end chapters had some of the flair of the first three books.  Still it is clear that Martin needs to work on tightening his chapters. He desperately needed an outline.<br /><br />The tale is still progressing but don't expect the wizardry of the first three books.

B001VZY4MS|4.0|I'd bet many people who consider themselves avid Neil Young fans don't know this album even exists.  They should.  Not only is it an important milestone in his career, but it's completely unique.  There's simply nothing else in his catalog that sounds remotely like it.  Leslie-ed guitars?  Growling B-3 organ?  Gospel choir?  Jazzy electric piano?  Bright, chiming guitars?  Instrumentals, and leading off both sides of the album at that?  This is Neil Young?  Well, yeah, it is, and mostly, it's pretty interesting.    The record isn't without familiar NY traits --- fuzzy guitars, and Neil's quirky voice and cryptic lyrics.  But it's the things mentioned above that get your attention.  Neil had a pretty nice backlog of songs built up for this record, which he started even before the last Buffalo Springfield album was released.  At times he seems unsure of just how to arrange some of these songs, and maybe that's what led to these arrangements being so uncharacteristic of his subsequent work.  But it pretty much all works.    \\"The Emperor of Wyoming\\" could be a movie theme (and wasn't it originally intended to be?).  \\"If I Could Have Her Tonight\\" is bright and Beatle-esque.  \\"The Old Laughing Lady\\" is notable for its jazz/gospel interlude.  And for me, \\"I've Been Waiting for You\\" is one of Neil's best rockers, remarkable given that it was recorded in several different studios in different cities.    The only real clunker here is the closer, \\"The Last Trip to Tulsa\\".  It's funny, because back in the day, this Neil-Does-Desolation-Row tome was considered the album's highlight.  But it hasn't aged well, and you might find yourself skipping it upon repeated listings of the album.  Everything before it is quite worthy, however.    After this album's release, Neil complained publicly that he didn't like the sound of it, and had it remixed and remastered.  I preferred one song from the original.  \\"Here We Are In the Years\\" had a more interesting (if muddy) mix, and more importantly, ran to its natural end, a glorious descent to a full stop rather than the wimpy early fadeout of the remaster.  The fadeout was a bad decision on Neil's part, robbing the song of its momentum at the end.    \\"Neil Young\\" is clearly transitional, but fascinating nonetheless.  NY fans who don't have it will find it a surprise, and a worthwhile investment.    A footnote: it was while recording this album that Neil acquired his \\"Old Black\\" 1953 Les Paul.  He swapped one of his Gretsches to Jim Messina for it.  Messina, who plays bass on this album, later labelled the trade a mistake on his part.
B000VSAEYI|5.0|This pool is amazing. Room to splash and really enjoy the water instead of just sitting in water like the little pools. The designs on the bottom entertain LO and he loves the slide!

0553801473|2.0|Yawn. Let me preface this by saying that I am a long-time Martin fan. I do not want my negative review to be discounted by those who will say I am a 'detractor.'<br /><br />[Background]<br /><br />I was first introduced to his work via Fevre Dream which I found in a used book store. That led me to search for more books of his and then I discovered A Song of Ice and Fire. I have waited a long time for this series to end, though perhaps not as long as many others. When I started reading, A Game of Thrones was in paperback and A Clash of Kings came out a few months later. I remember the days when GRRM used to chat with fans on AIM (something I appreciated greatly) and watched with despair as he succumbed to the pressures of his so-called 'detractors.' As a reader, I, too, was disappointed by the long wait. I agonized over it for a few months, but chose to read other fantasy novels instead of trolling him on the internet. I really, really wanted to like this book. I didn't expect much, but I felt that surely, after all this time, he had been able to get the series back on track. With the deaths of some major characters in Storm of Swords, and the criticisms of the slow pace of Feast for Crows, he had to have pared back and regained focus, right? Wrong.<br /><br />[Review]<br /><br />Pros:<br />(1) His prose is what it's always been: descriptive, lush, vivid and, at times, graphic. I don't want to spoil for anyone who hasn't read yet, but some of the chapters were so vile I felt uneasy for several hours after reading them. Though they were powerful, I'm still not convinced that the level of detail was necessary, and I still find myself wondering what exactly this added to the *overall* plot (i.e., not just the plot of ADWD, but of ASoIaF in general).<br /><br />(2) The characters who many longed for (myself included) in AFFC are featured in ADWD. This, for me, actually turned out to be a bit of a con (more on that later). Nevertheless, it cannot be said that GRRM doesn'tattempt to advance the plot and pick up where he left off in Book 3. His idea of plot advancement and mine must be two different things, however, as many of the characters take only one small step forward and several leaps back.<br /><br />(3) Bran. Those chapters are a pro in and of themselves. GRRM has said in the past that he had difficulty writing the younger kids, but I think he did a masterful job with Bran's chapters in Dance.<br /><br />(4) It's out. It's published. That's positive in and of itself, right?<br /><br />Cons:<br />(1) I don't want to rate Martin lowly for not doing what I want with his characters. Of course I'd love to see things play out differently, but then they would be my books and not his.<br /><br />On the other hand, I feel that in this chapter of the series, GRRM has given up on the novel and revolutionary plot twists for which he is lauded in exchange for shock value and contrived (and over-used) fantasy tropes. The introduction of a \\"new\\" character, one with little to no foreshadowing, albeit one who GRRM never fully admitted was deceased seemed like a desperate attempt to misdirect readers from the popular theory that Jon Snow is the progeny of Rhaegar and Lyanna as well as the hope that Dany will one day take back the Seven Kingdoms. In short, don't expect any game-changers of the Ned Stark or Red Wedding type in this book.<br /><br />(2) The introduction of new plot threads (again, don't want to spoil) that seem, at best, tangential to the arc begun in AGoT, or, at worst, the start of new plots upon ploys upon plots. I'm all for intrigue and suspense, but of all the novels, Feast included, this is the shortest and least satisfying on both accounts.<br /><br />(3) At the end of the book I'm left with many of the same questions I had at the end of Feast. And yes, I realize this book could (and should) be seen as the second volume of Feast. However, there is and was nothing in either SoS or AFFC that led me to believe that little tonothing would be resolved in ADWD for characters like Jon, Dany, and Tyrion. All the setup in ASoS about the glorious and troubled Targaryen past led to...not much. What happened to the immersive fantasy of the first three (and some of the fourth) books? It's lost between descriptions of food and animals and travelogues. The world, for even the high and mighty, is full of nothing but lowlifes and shallowness.<br /><br />(4) Dany. While GRRM hasn't gone the Cersei route with her quite yet, she is a far cry from the strong and certain khaleesi. Then again, for all his innovations, GRRM, like many (male?) authors of today seems to have a problem with strong female characters who aren't ugly or undead. A woman's who's all that and brains too doesn't seem to exist in high fantasy.<br /><br />tl;dr: I can't say I hated it, but I definitely didn't like it, and not for the standard \\"OMG he didn't do what I wanted him to do with my characters\\" reasons. Save your money and wait for the paperback or local library edition.
