0345528581|5.0|I was looking for a complete workout program based on bodyweight exercises, and came across this book. I was experimenting with the program while traveling around the world, when I did not have access to any modern exercise equipment.<br /><br />You Are Your Own Gym is a great read and particularly inspiring. It presents information you will not typically find in most fitness books.<br /><br />First comment:<br /><br />The workouts are absolutely challenging if you follow them exactly as laid out by the author! In 20 minutes you will get an impressive workout, and in fact will probably be sore for days after the first one.<br /><br />Note to beginners: If you don't have an established weight-training routine you would be well advised to seriously tone down the 10-week workout plans by creating your own routine based on the exercises and the concepts in this book. Even if you try to follow the most basic 10-week program you will be absolutely wiped out if you don't have enough serious built-up fitness.<br /><br />PROS:<br /><br />- The best thing about the book is it's laid out like a a recipe guide. First, you have the 100+ exercises covering every part of the body. Then, you have the various types of training, such as ladders, intervals, etc., with ideas that I've never heard before. For example, a ladder with pushups would be like this:<br /><br />* Do 1 pushup, rest for the same amount of time it took you to do the pushup. Do two pushups, rest again for the same period of time. Do three pushups, rest. Do four pushups, rest. Continue until you feel you've reached your \\"max\\" but can still come down all the way to zero. For example, if you reach 12 pushups, then after you do 11, then 10.<br /><br />This method of training will really workout your muscular endurance like nothing you've tried before. However, it's not the best to build sheer strength, so the author has other methods to build your strength. The trick is to alternate these training methods, and to cover different body parts every day.<br /><br />- You can pick and choose to create your own training programs<br /><br />- You can follow the training programs as laid out by the author, but they are challenging!<br /><br />- There's lots of exercise beyond the typical pushups, many of which you've never heard of.<br /><br />- You can do the exercises everywhere with almost all of the exercises. This is a great program if you like to workout outside in a part or while traveling.<br /><br />CONS<br /><br />Not many, but:<br /><br />- The book lacks a \\"super basic\\" workout program for people who are not in shape. Therefore, if one is just getting started, he or she cannot realistically complete the basic 10-week program.<br /><br />- Some exercises, like the \\"lift me up,\\" require equipment that is not always available. You can improvise with what you can find, but in some cases you can't find anything suitable. However, you can substitute an exercise for another easily.<br /><br />- The information about nutrition is pretty skim, and partly inaccurate (I study nutrition), but WAY better than the protein-overdose nutrition program presented in most other strength training manuals.<br /><br />The bottom line is that this is the best book on bodyweight training available. It's way more realistic than Pavel's absurd workout, yet challenging enough for anyone to get a complete workout, no matter what your background is.e to create your own training programs    - You can follow the training programs as laid out by the author, but they are challenging!     - There's lots of exercise beyond the typical pushups, many of which you've never heard of.     - You can do the exercises everywhere with almost all of the exercises. This is a great program if you like to workout outside in a part or while traveling.     CONS    Not many, but:    - The book lacks a \\"super basic\\" workout program for people who are not in shape. Therefore, if one is just getting started, he or she cannot realistically complete the basic 10-week program.     - Some exercises, like the \\"lift me up,\\" require equipment that is not always available. You can improvise with what you can find, but in some cases you can't find anything suitable. However, you can substitute an exercise for another easily.    - The information about nutrition is pretty skim, and partly inaccurate (I study nutrition), but WAY better than the protein-overdose nutrition program presented in most other strength training manuals.       The bottom line is that this is the best book on bodyweight training available. It's way more realistic than Pavel's absurd workout, yet challenging enough for anyone to get a complete workout, no matter what your background is.

0007119550|2.0|I have just finished this fourth book in the Song of Ice and Fire series, and will be reading no further. I am bored out of my skull, with what started out as a fabulously-engrossing story in Game of Thrones, but has now deteriorated into an endless series of 'cliffhanger' chapter endings and an endless parade of characters, created apparently only to be killed off or passed around, ad infinitum. I no longer give a rip who becomes 'king' or IF anybody ever becomes king, who survives, who doesn't, or who-marries-whom. This is going on too long.  Ho-bloody-hum.<br /><br />Is there any resolution to this saga in sight? Well, no, apparently not yet. I understand this author has written, what, 5 books, 6 books, and STILL his 'story' isn't anywhere near being finished? I do think Mr Martin is having us on here. As long as people keep buying these books, he'll keep on churning them out. Why kill the Golden Goose?<br /><br />What a waste of such a strong writing talent!<br /><br />A GOOD story -- any kind of story, short OR long, including fantasy sagas -- must have focus.  It needs a beginning, a middle, AND an end. The ending need not be happy, but all loose threads need to be tied together in some satisfactory and believable way at the conclusion. And there really DOES need to be a conclusion.<br /><br />Mr Martin should take a gander at Joe Abercrombie's First Law fantasy trilogy, to see how a multi-viewpoint, lengthy and complicated 'gritty' story SHOULD be constructed.  That story was one of the most original and engrossing tales I've ever read, with a very satisfactory conclusion indeed.  This one ...well, sadly, it's not.  Unfortunately, this 'saga' has turned into a soap opera.<br /><br />Soap operas are different from stories. No matter how original the setting (remember Dark Shadows?), soaps just diddle on and on and on from day to day, until somebody finally pulls the plug on them. Exciting events come and go, original characters have their moments of drama, leave the show, new characters appear, hang around, have THEIR dramas, then THEY leave, etc, etc. Characters continually swap partners till nobody can remember who started with whom, family members fall out with each other, make up, fall out again ...etc, etc... Sound familiar?<br /><br />There are obviously folks out there who enjoy this kind of never-ending saga, but I'm not one of them. If somebody comes to me and says 'Hey -- did you know George RR Martin actually FINISHED his Song of Ice and Fire saga?', I might pick it up again and read on. But until that day dawns, I'm through. Sorry.around, have THEIR dramas, then THEY leave, etc, etc. Characters continually swap partners till nobody can remember who started with whom, family members fall out with each other, make up, fall out again ...etc, etc... Sound familiar?    There are obviously folks out there who enjoy this kind of never-ending saga, but I'm not one of them. If somebody comes to me and says 'Hey -- did you know George RR Martin actually FINISHED his Song of Ice and Fire saga?', I might pick it up again and read on. But until that day dawns, I'm through. Sorry.

B004GUSG4M|4.0|I don't read much fiction but am glad I selected this one.  The story takes place over two weeks in the life of a woman who wakes up each day having little if any memory of who she is.  Each morning her husband gently tells her what happened - 20 years earlier(!) she was hit by a car; the accident resulted in an unusual form of amnesia in which her memory disappears when she goes to sleep.  Unbeknownst to him, she is seeing a doctor who gives her a journal to write in each day so she will have some concrete record of it the next day.  The hope is that this will help her regain her memory to some degree.  As the story progresses she begins to remember things - or at least she thinks she does; but she can never be quite sure if she is truly recalling something that happened, or if it's a false memory that came about because of something she read.  To top it all off, she finds inconsistencies between what her husband tells her and what her doctor tells her, leading to the question of who can she trust?  Ultimately and perhaps inevitably the novel leads to a surprise ending - actually two surprises - that I didn't completely see coming.  By about day 10 in the journal I admit I was ready to get to the climax of the story, and at that point hearing about her waking up each day with little or no memory of herself or her life was getting to be a little old (although no more so for me than for her!!)- but all in all an excellent read.  I'm looking forward to more from this author.

B001E1GXPA|5.0|Now roughly 3 years old, Trivium's Shogun has withstood the test of time, and still remains one of my favorite metal albums of the last 5 years.  I picked up this album about the same time that I purchased Kamelot's The Black Halo and Symphony X's Paradise Lost, and to me, these 3 albums are still my unholy trinity.  I usually cannot listen to one without listening to the others soon afterwards.  Though the styles are different, each is powerful in its own right.  My previous experience with Trivium was with the albums The Ascendancy and Crusade, and while technically proficient, they just didn't grab and violently shake me like I expected.  But it only took a few minutes of listening to \\"Kirisute Gomen\\" on Shogun to make me rethink my opinion of this amazing band.  Matt & Co. have truly created something genuine and breathtaking, and ultimately timeless.  And that is an amazing feat for any band.<br /><br />With the imminent release of the new album In Waves, I have been playing Shogun more and more often, and it seems to get better and better with each listen.  Why?  I honestly can't answer that question with words.  Suffice it to say that there's really not a weak track on the album.  Not a single one.  While not every song knocks it out of the park, there isn't a filler track or lackluster entry, and that is not something that happens too often on metal CD's.  But it's more than that.  Somehow, this album generates actual emotion, and ebbs and flows like a living thing.  When I first bought it, I tended to gravitate to my favorite songs, and ignore the others.  But recently, I have been playing it from start to finish, and because of that, it has evolved into an experience, not just a CD.  But I digress...<br /><br />So, for you few uninitiated, here are the tracks to pay attention to;  \\"Kirisute Gomen\\", the perfect choice as the intro track, teasing the ears with a slow & quiet start before the punishing drums kick in; \\"Down From the Sky\\", the single, released with an official video, and a pretty awesome metal song; \\"Throes of Perdition\\", my personal favorite from the album, with great lyrics, a sing-a-long chorus, and a brutal breakdown in the middle; \\"Insurrection\\", a blistering track with staccato drums and Slayer-esque soloing; \\"The Calamity\\", a more melodic track with a great solo; \\"Of Prometheus and the Crucifix\\", another song with a catchy chorus and great solo; \\"Like Callisto to a Star in Heaven\\", my other personal favorite, with driving guitars and drums and raspy vocals; and \\"Shogun\\" the 11+ minute title track, a slow burner for about 8 minutes before kicking into high gear for nearly the remainder of the song.<br /><br />I always recommend picking up the special edition of albums if they have bonus tracks, and Shogun is no different.  There are 3 bonus tracks to be had.  Of the 3, \\"Upon the Shores\\" and \\"Iron Maiden\\" are the standouts, and evoke a sense of Ride The Lightning and Kill `Em All era Metallica.  I know that's what Trivium is going for, and it works well.<br /><br />I am hoping that In Waves continues the strong trend that Shogun has established.  If not, I still have this great album that keeps getting better with every listen.  If you haven't heard it yet, take a listen to \\"Kirisute Gomen\\" and see if it doesn't blow you away.  If it does, then this album is for you!l video, and a pretty awesome metal song; \\"Throes of Perdition\\", my personal favorite from the album, with great lyrics, a sing-a-long chorus, and a brutal breakdown in the middle; \\"Insurrection\\", a blistering track with staccato drums and Slayer-esque soloing; \\"The Calamity\\", a more melodic track with a great solo; \\"Of Prometheus and the Crucifix\\", another song with a catchy chorus and great solo; \\"Like Callisto to a Star in Heaven\\", my other personal favorite, with driving guitars and drums and raspy vocals; and \\"Shogun\\" the 11+ minute title track, a slow burner for about 8 minutes before kicking into high gear for nearly the remainder of the song.    I always recommend picking up the special edition of albums if they have bonus tracks, and Shogun is no different.  There are 3 bonus tracks to be had.  Of the 3, \\"Upon the Shores\\" and \\"Iron Maiden\\" are the standouts, and evoke a sense of Ride The Lightning and Kill `Em All era Metallica.  I know that's what Trivium is going for, and it works well.    I am hoping that In Waves continues the strong trend that Shogun has established.  If not, I still have this great album that keeps getting better with every listen.  If you haven't heard it yet, take a listen to \\"Kirisute Gomen\\" and see if it doesn't blow you away.  If it does, then this album is for you!

B004EPZ084|3.0|My feeling after seeing this movie was that it is silly, adolescent, vulger & crude, but that it is pushed (just barely) up into the level of 3 stars by its all-star cast (Kevin Spacey, Jennifer Aniston, Colin Ferrell and Jason Bateman).   Of course, many people can relate to having bad bosses, and fleeting thoughts of knocking them off sometime.  So our modern three stooges (three 30-something middle-class guys) each have a bad boss: Spacey is the arrogant bastard boss, Ferrell is the selfish druggie boss, and Aniston is the overly sexual female boss.  Each is over-the-top unrealistic.  Actually the whole movie feels over-the-top (I guess that Hollywood thinks they have to do everything that way -- like hitting you in the face with a mallet.)  But Spacey does play a very effective flaming jerk, ultra-arrogant, rich guy, and Ferrell a flaming jerk, coke-head, and Aniston a flaming jerk nympho dentist.    The guys decide to knock off each other's boss and things get out of control.  Really, the plot is just a vehicle to run a number of gags & jokes.  Like breaking into the druggy's house & spilling his cocaine all over the place & sweeping it up with a dust-buster.  Like hiring a \\"hit man\\" from \\"men seeking men\\" in the local paper and learning that he's got other things on his mind.  Like going to a black bar in a seedy part of town and hiring a scary-looking ex-con named \\"M********r Jones\\", and our silly, wimpy stooges calling him by his name all the time.  Like getting an Indian guy on the GPS help line in the car, named \\"Gregory\\" because his real name is unpronounceable (Gregory plays a big role at the end though).    Everything is exceedingly stupid, but it hits the funnybone about half the time.  The three stooges have pretty good comedic chemistry.  Aniston does add a lot of stimulation by showing off her (pretty darn sexy)  body in different stages of undress in a psycho-nympho role .... that old adolescent Hollywood trick works all the time I guess.  Then there's the old \\"who would get raped worse in jail?\\" supposedly humorous discussion ... there's nothing better for yucking things up than prison rape jokes!  Then there's the old \\"we are three white goofy buffoons talking to a cool black guy who calls us morons and rips us off\\" situation.  i.e. self-abasement by the immature and non-streetwise white men is supposed to be hilarious (or maybe it's just a Hollywood requirement if there are blacks & whites together in a movie.)  But the abasement goes both ways, due to the first name of the black ex-con, which has to be the most despicable word in the English language.      So there's a lot of low-class humor in this movie.  Actually, I get pretty tired of the F-word interjected into half of the lines in the movie by its end.  Don't the writers, who are supposedly the best in the country and very well paid, have any more literary talent than to say \\"F-this, F-that, F-ing F\\" all the time in order to get laughs?   Well, OK, that's what to expect from a modern R-rated comedy.
B004WPT3ZM|2.0|This is a phenominal package for Megadeth fans and newcommers alike. Excellent liner notes and the amount of material you get for the price is great. But in terms of the remastering quality, it isn't worth it in my opinion. The fact that it is the original mix is great because now you can hear the way the album was intended to be, but if you have the original CD pressing from 1986, stick with that copy. It seems these days record labels are only interested in making remasters and releases louder, instead of putting care and quality into them. Like I always say, heavy metal is great when played loud, but that's why we have volume knobs. If the CD is already too loud, then it clips and distorts in places where it shouldn't be and just sounds compressed and wimpy. Whereas the original sounds great at any volume, especially if you crank it up.
B004Q84Z0S|5.0|Ariodante is the one of Handel's \\"great\\" operas I've always had the most trouble with. I found both Minkowski's and McGegan's recordings curiously unsatisfying, even with such great singers as Anne-Sofie von Otter and Lorraine Hunt in the title role. This recording is different. Alan Curtis apparently decided \\"no more mr. Nice Guy\\", and went for broke in this recording. It's an exceedingly dramatic and forceful performance, aided and abetted by his star, Joyce DiDonato. Even the recitatives sparkle with drama. There are still problems, but they are mostly of Handel's making, not mr. Curtis. The first act has always seemed disappointing to me, with a lot of downright awkward music. There's the great aria \\"Con L'ali Di Constanza\\" of course, but it's always struck me that Ariodante follows closer to the pattern of many second-tier Handel operas, where the first act is not quite on the level of the second and third acts, than the other great masterpieces such as Guilio Cesare, Rinaldo or Orlando which are on a uniformly high level of inspiration.<br /><br />No matter, Curtis leads a wonderful performance, and when Handel's greatest operatic aria, \\"Scherza Infida\\" rolls around, Joyce DiDonato gives an absolutely electrifying rendition of this masterpiece. Better even than her recent CD of Handel arias, and better than the live performance I saw her give at Zankel Hall a couple of years ago. Everyone else is excellent, the orchestral playing is top-notch. Very satisfying, at last.
0783225725|5.0|The first time I saw High Plains Drifter was probably in the late 1970s. Clint Eastwood stars in and directs the film. I that speak in righteousness, mighty to save. Wherefore art thou red in thine apparel, and thy garments like him that treadeth in the winefat? B001I0T92Q|4.0|I bought this product because not only was it cheap, but it seemed like the perfect solution for my PSP.    This review is how this product performs in a PSP-1000 system (generation 1, original motherboard). I've been stuck with a 4gb card since I bought this PSP at launch. I love it. 4gb served my purpose well. But recently there have been some titles and games that I've wanted and I don't regularly change what games and songs and movies I have on my PSP. In fact I hate syncing so I try to avoid it at all costs.    Anyways, that's where I found this beauty. This thing is fantastic. I have a 4gb class 6 microSD card, and an 8gb class 2 card. Those are my 2 highest MicroSD cards I own. Therefore I was interested in trying to couple their capacities. And this adapter did not disappoint.    I only gave it 4 stars however due to a small but diminishing con. That is; if your PSP is hacked for a custom firmware, you MUST use this card as a MMS (users will know what this means and I won't go into great detail about it). The other facet is; you MUST use this card inside the PSP from the start, meaning formatting and everything. When you open the package and put in your MicroSD cards into the adapter, you must first and foremost format your memory card as the PSP can't read it. Standard with any raidcard if you have experience with that.    But this adapter is so much greater than a raidcard. Yes it functions in the same method, meaning if you remove a card or swap the slots, it becomes inert and requires a reformat. Essentially making it a raid 0. But here's the kicker. YOU GET TO USE ALL YOUR STORAGE. That's right. My 4gb and 8gb sticks combined for a total of 12gb and 11gb usage space due to overhead. This was better than I expected as a standard raid operates by taking the lowest single drive of space and only uses that much per drive. So if you had a 2tb drive in a raid with a 1tb drive, you could only use 1tb of the 2tb drive in the raid. Making it 2tb raid instead ofthe presumed 3tb. But not with this card, it simply adds. And that is what I had hoped for.    I will be getting 2 16gb cards in the next couple months but for now this will suffice.    As for speed, it's pretty standard. upwards of 6mb/s real world transfer speed of 8gb of data at once from computer through USB to the PSP.    All in all, it's a damn good product, but like anything it could be better.    tl;dr    Pro  +Adds storage for very cheap  +Adds storage devices together instead of lowest common denominator  +Not particularly fragile as others mentioned  +No noticeable difference when up and running how you want it  +CHEAP! (the good kind)    Con  -Must be a MMS for homebrew PSP's  -MUST be formatted and used inside the PSP/other devices    Other thoughts  =Not a pro or con, the documentation is a little lacking but it's a freaking adapter card so what can you expect.

I didn't hate nor favor their music, but it wasn't until 2008 that I really started liking the band.  I found myself liking every song of theirs immediately.  S.C.I.E.N.C.E. was a bit bizarre to me initially since I wasn't used to the style (I was used to Morning View and Make Yourself), but with one listen I was hooked.  I don't mind whatsoever if Incubus changes, that's good.  Never in a million years will I expect a \\"S.C.I.E.N.C.E.\\" album from them, I loved all their styles from Fungus to Light Grenades and appreciated all of them.       With \\"If Not Now, When?\\", when I try to get into the songs of this album, it feels forced.  I know the album is a lot softer and I expected that ever since I heard Mike Einziger's insight on the album, but the songs just sound so mediocre.  Incubus can create music far more brilliant than on this album.  The soft sound is not the problem, they've been making soft music for 12 or so years and that hasn't been an issue to me.  Some of their best music has been the softer tracks (Drive, I Miss You, Mexico, Southern Girl, 11 AM, Just A Phase, Dig, Love Hurts, Are You In?, Talk Shows on Mute, the list continues), but they just had so much emotion, so much passion into them.  On here, most of them feel haphazard and seem to just move out into nowhere.        This band has so much potential, talent, and skill, but this album shows otherwise and demonstrates that they're not living up to it.  It's like watching your child work at McDonald's when he/she has the credentials and intelligence to go to medical school.  Brandon's vocals as always are spot on, very beautiful and heavenly.  As for the others of the band, it's very lacking and neglected.  Einziger's guitar playing isabsent in many parts of the songs and doesn't contribute as much as before on previous albums, Pasillas' drumming is too laidback and rather a bore on the majority of tracks, playing really slow and forgettable drum beats.  There's little to no contributions from Kilmore with his samplings/mixings and weird but tasteful sounds that really added flavor to songs in the past.  I know the turntable days are long gone with the band, it's a pity because as I said earlier, it truly added spice to their music.  As for Kenney's bass playing, like Einziger, I can hardly ever hear any bass in the songs.  The instruments seem too neglected on this album and are focused merely on Brandon's vocals complimented by some slow and stale drum beat by Pasillas.  The only songs that didn't really feel forced to get into were \\"Thieves\\", the first two singles, and \\"The Original\\".  Here's a breakdown of all the songs:  1.  If Not Now, When? 5/10.  Probably the worst track on the album and a horrible way to start it off.  Feels extremely tedious and found myself waiting for this track to be over just to get to the next one.  2.  Promises, Promises 8/10.  In spite of the backlash this single has received, I rather like it.  Brandon's lyrics and storytelling are done very well.  3.  Friends And Lovers 6/10.  A mediocre track.  I try getting interested in it but catch myself skipping this one.  4.  Thieves. 10/10  By far the best track (in my opinion) on the album.  The figurative language is outstanding and the chorus is extremely catchy, It's always in my head and I'll be singing it in my head periodically throughout the day.  5.  Isadore.  9/10.  One of the better tracks.  Good acoustic song.  Not really that much else to say about it.  6.  The Original.  10/10.  Another top song of the album.  The beginning has this odd, yet intriguing part and while a slow song, it's nevertheless a proficient one.  7.  Defiance.  8/10.  An acoustic track that resembles the sound of older Incubus songs.It has a \\"Incubusy\\" feel to it.  Too short of a song however.  8.  In The Company of Wolves 7/10.  The longest song on the album.  The songs changes as it goes on.  It's not a bad song, but it feels dragged out, empty and contains filler.  As with the first track, you just want the song to be over and move on to the next.  9.  Switchblade.  8/10.  One of the more energetic songs on the album, the vocals don't seems as concentrated upon as the others.  An adequate track.  10.  Adolescents.  10/10  The most reminiscent of all previous Incubus sounds.  Though the lyrics are sort of repetitive, and the oriental part is tedious, the solo is nice and the song in general is up there with the top tracks.  11.  Tomorrow's Food.  9/10.  Another one of my favorite songs and good way to end the album.  I loved it the first time I heard it when it made it's premiere at Oxford when it was just Mike and Brandon playing the track.  It would have received a perfect score had it not been for the end.  The last 2 minutes or so are empty of singing and the instruments add a modicum to maintain your interest, it feels blank towards the end.         Overall, I give the album a 3.5.  I know I'm being biased as Incubus is absolutely my favorite band and I listen to their music all the time, but when you bear in mind the 5 year break, Incubus has a lot more to bring to the table than this.  You have to eliminate from your mind that this is the same band that brought you \\"Morning View\\" and \\"A Crow Left of the Murder\\".  This effort is something that they can and should transcend in their next effort.  Hopefully the criticisms of this album gives the band something to reconsider and reevaluate once the next album rolls around.

B004GUSG4M|3.0|I don't know  - was it part of the author's clever plan to have the reader feel the same frustrations as Chrissie, by repeatedly recovering the same ground over and over and over again? I really wanted to skip ahead because the story itself was so repetitive. Honestly, you could explain the plot pretty thoroughly in about 30 words or less.     It felt like the author started with a good idea (albeit one which borrowed heavily from the movie \\"Memento\\" ), planted the mystery in our minds and then was committed to fill a certain number of pages (reiterating the premise at regular intervals), until  she had reached a predetermined word count.  Finally, in the last few pages there was a mad rush of story,  with key characters suddenly spilling revelations to neatly tie up all the loose ends.    The premise was a good one, but I felt like this was really a short story, contrived to be a novel. Lots of tension, but not much plot..  When I learned that the book was the end result of a novel writing course the author attended, it kind of made sense.    An okay first book, but the reviewer hype sets expectations too high, I thought.

I was thrilled to see the high rating, but disappointed to see the price; $40.00 more than the thing costs at B/N since its release last month.  Amazon, you need to do better here!    Now to the product - This is my first e-reader and I am certain that I went with the best product for me.  As someone who buys a lot of books from Amazon, I would have preferred to have bought the Kindle,especially since Amazon has more of the types of books I read and for much cheaper than B/N, but I just do not appreciate those tiny buttons on the device.  I absolutely LOVE my Nook Simple Touch, and I use it for several hours every day.  B/N has Free Fridays - when you can download a featured book for free -, book share -with contacts on your device and social networks, and free reading of selected books when you are in B/N.  My understanding is that I can go to local libraries and even borrow my books using my Nook; This may or may not be any special news.    The touch screen is a bit sensitive on the device, so if you prefer not to use it, they are also tactile \\"buttons\\" that will allow you to change pages.  The home screen shows the book you are currently reading and the page number you are on - a few other books in your library, and some suggested readings.  You can create shelves that you name on which to house your books by categories. They do not look like physical shelves, rather they are just a grouping of books.     Without going into more technical stuff that you can read online, I will say that if you are new to e-reading and you enjoy touch screens -  AND YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A PRODUCT THAT SIMPLY ALLOWS YOU TO READ - Do not hesitate to go into a B/N and try this out.  Some people buy this expecting it to browse the web (although it does have a hidden browser that the techies are working to hack) - Play their audio files, when there is not headphone jack (Techies have discovered that it DOES have built-in bluetooth, however), and folks buy this and complain that they do not like how it does not display their magazines in color.  It is not meant to do that - it is meant to be solely an enjoyable easy-to-use reading device that does not give you a whole lot of options to be distracted from the task at hand, READING!    This is why I bought it - Eventually, I will get a nook color - or a Kindle *color* if they come out with one, but for now, I thoroughly  enjoy my Nook, which has encouraged me to slow down and spend so much more time in the peaceful, leisurely act of reading. In my excitement, I am reading like 8 different books at once.  That is the great joy of having an e-reader - speaking to those who are, just as I used to be, resistant to the e-reading craze - there is no more lugging around a bag filled with books, and when I get tired of reading one, another book is just a couple of swipes away. I am learning about how to get all sorts of books for free or low cost, as well as learning how to take advantage of conversion and e-book management tools such as Calibre.  I am having a blast with this thing!    Yesterday, I received a nice leather case for it that I purchased off Ebay for a great price.  Once again, I looked to Amazon.com first, but there simply were not good options.  I got a black leather Caseen case that also came with a screen protector for twenty bucks.

I ended up reading it in less than 1 day. I often felt like I was reading the actual thoughts of an 11 year old because there are many short sentences and simple writing, but I think that's what makes you relate to it even more, you feel so strongly for this stolen child. This was a child who was never allowed to grow up the way a child should. Jaycee is an amazing person and a survivor, you feel for her, her daughters, and I cried for most parts dealing with her mother. Though frustrating, she does make you understand why she stayed for so long. She was broken down for so long, she didn't know how to make decisions of her own.    I do feel this should be used as a tool for children today. Perhaps they shouldn't read the whole thing, it would be very traumatizing, but I think parents, teachers, etc should not only teach about \\"stranger danger\\" but they should teach what happens if you are successfully abducted and the mind control that will be used and that your mother will always want you back and look for you no matter what. And though they may feel no one wants them anymore, this couldn't be further from the truth, a mother (or father) will never forget you and if you can escape if not for yourself, do it for all the people who love you. 0060558121|4.0|Was set to write a five star review for American Gods, but took a few minutes beforehand, and read some of the other reviews here.<br /><br />And... they swayed me.<br /><br />And I had to knock a star off....<br /><br />Here's why....<br /><br />Loved the idea of this book.<br /><br />America has been a melting pot for centuries.<br /><br />The idea that everyone who came to our shores brought their own beliefs with them, and either left again, or gradually altered their beliefs, leaving their old gods stranded and then weakened... That's brilliant!<br /><br />And Gaimen's  portrayal of them as past their prime,  working day jobs and cons to get by because they have no other options...  Again - brilliant!<br /><br />The idea of the existence of places of power, and what we as a people have created to mark them.... Having grown up taking long car trips with the family back and forth across the country.... Loved the idea and execution of this idea.<br /><br />Hell, I actually went to House on The Rock, in WI because of this book.<br />Helps that it's only 3.5 hours away...<br />(It's worth a stop, if you're in the neighborhood.)<br /><br />This book has given me much pleasure and satisfaction in the 6 or so years that I've owned it.  My copy is dog eared, to say the least.<br /><br />But in reading the negative reviews, I realized - I've only read it cover to cover, once.<br /><br />All subsequent readings have involved massive skimming, or just plain skipping pieces of the book, because I found them to be tedious, and unnecessary to the storyline.<br /><br />Other reviews suggesting need for greater editing, are dead-on.<br />The \\"histories\\" that seem to drop into the novel at random, are just that to me.<br />Random.<br />Unnecessary, and overlong.<br /><br />I didn't care why or exactly how one of the gods ended up here.  I accepted the premise at the start of the book, and didn't need it reiterated and supported over and over.<br /><br />***As a heads up, there are spoilers, sort of, below ***<br /><br />Didn't really care for how Shadow's dead ex-wife was used, though I AM a sucker for redemption at end of stories.<br /><br />When sticking to the actual plot / storyline, I was enrapt.<br /><br />It was well paced, while regularly reminding the reader of the idea that old gods walk among us all the time.  Be they meat processors, car rental agents, hookers... you get the idea.<br /><br />Shadow's lack of ... a lot made sense, given how he came to be out of prison early. The one happy thought, if you will, that he clung to while doing time, was squashed, as was everything he had planned for a life upon release.<br />He was a good straight man for all the godly oddballs.  Near the climax, when he finally got to choose his fate, the one he chose also made sense to me.<br /><br />The foreshadowing of a two man con was well done.<br /><br />These are the reasons I keep picking the book up, and (mostly) re-reading it.  But the idea that it's a better story if you skip...entire chapters speaks negatively of the book as a whole.When sticking to the actual plot / storyline, I was enrapt.    It was well paced, while regularly reminding the reader of the idea that old gods walk among us all the time.  Be they meat processors, car rental agents, hookers... you get the idea.   Shadow's lack of ... a lot made sense, given how he came to be out of prison early. The one happy thought, if you will, that he clung to while doing time, was squashed, as was everything he had planned for a life upon release.  He was a good straight man for all the godly oddballs.  Near the climax, when he finally got to choose his fate, the one he chose also made sense to me.  The foreshadowing of a two man con was well done.  These are the reasons I keep picking the book up, and (mostly) re-reading it.  But the idea that it's a better story if you skip...entire chapters speaks negatively of the book as a whole.
B00425S1H8|5.0|This product even worked with my piece of junk motion stage in my lab.  My motion stage is about 15 years old and very flaky and to my surprise this converter worked just fine with it.  One issue I had was that the program to control the stage wasn't recognizing that the stage was plugged into the computer.  Turns out that the converter was attaching the stage to COM port 3 and not COM port 1.  So if you are having connectivity issues, try going into the hardware folder on your computer and looking up which port the converter is using.

0962477060|1.0|I first got this a few years ago when I started playing guitar. Looking back, I can't recommend this book.<br /><br />The one good thing about it is it introduced me to the CAGED system. The idea is: if you play these chord shapes at different positions on the neck: C at the open position, A at the 3rd, G at the 5th, E at the 8th, and D at the 10th position with appropriate barreing - they will all sound like the C chord, but use the shapes of C, A, G, E, and D chords.<br /><br />What's more, you can permute this. If you start with A in the open position, you can play the AGEDC shapes up the neck (with appropriate spacings) and they will sound like the A chord. Similarly, the scale patterns repeat in a predictable way on the neck.<br /><br />As a beginner, this was cool. But then the rest of the book was really confusing. After a few days I put this book away and haven't really looked at until I wrote this review.<br /><br />The book is really wordy - the CAGED overview lasts ~20 pages. Even now that I have a better grasp of theory, I still can't get through his description of how to find lead patterns, triads, arpeggios, modes, and chords. Instead of getting this book, I suggest reading up on the CAGED method on the internet and then try one of the following books:<br /><br />If you actually want to really learn the fretboard, I think the best book out there is the [[ASIN:0634049011 Guitar Fretboard Workbook]] by Barrett Tagliarino which will ask you to figure out the patterns yourself (after teaching you some basic theory).<br /><br />I personally like Bruce Emery's Music Principles for the The Skeptical Guitarist series: [[ASIN:0966502906 Music Principles for the Skeptical Guitarist Vol. 1 : The Big Picture]] and [[ASIN:0966502914 Music Principles for the Skeptical Guitarist, Volume 2 'The Fretboard']] which goes over theory (in Vol. 1) and the CAGED system in Vol. 2.

B000E1ZBGS|5.0|The 2005 version of Pride & Prejudice is a great movie, to be sure, to help connect modern audiences with this masterpiece. Indeed, I hated Jane Austen for 23 years, the time between high school British Lit class and that when I first saw this film in 2006.<br /><br />A couple of notes on the version. Macfadyen is not quite the actor that Olivier was, but he seems very real as Mr. Darcy. In fact, when he appeared in Frost/Nixon, I silently exclaimed, \\"it's bleach-blond Mr. Darcy!\\" The role sticks to him as if he were superglued to it.<br /><br />Mr. Collins is rather serious, almost to the point of mean spirited, whereas Jane Austen's version (and 1940 and 1995 screen versions) paint him as comic relief, a buffoon.<br /><br />Keira Knightly is perhaps the most adorable Lizzie of all, certainly one whom viewers can easily relate to and even befriend. Donald Sutherland is in the middle of the pack as Mr. Bennett overall, but his father/daughter relationship with Lizzie is rather warm indeed!<br /><br />Cinematographically, a bit too modern... two camera elements should be used more judiciously: Zoom/Perspective, and camera angle. In the former, there's no aesthetic benefit to seeing such frequent close-ups of characters when they speak. The two zoom close ups of Mr. Darcy's hand after it had touched Elizabeth's were obvious, nearly to the point of offensive to this viewer.<br /><br />As for the latter, perhaps a bit too much camera acrobatics... in a few scenes, I thought the camera was a supporting actor jealous of the attention given the star, trying to seize the spotlight where it could. The camera was a bit too dramatic at times in angle and movement.<br /><br />The classic (1940) employs both of these techniques, but they are so subtle as to be moving and effective, without distracting the viewer by causing their stomach to jolt with constant gritty emotion. Pride and Prejudice is a fine experience, not a visceral one.<br /><br />I'm compelled to point out one instance where zoom was properly used. At the end of the film, where Darcy and Elizabeth finally declare their love for each other, the use of restrained zoom on the couple was a rather moving as it created a romantic portrait. I felt sparks fly all over my body (as opposed to jolts in my entrails).<br /><br />Despite what I consider cinematographic shortcomings, I love the 2005 version of Pride and Prejudice. It opened the door to Jane Austen for me. Nevertheless, it took a first viewing of the Olivier (1940) version five years later to finally pull me in entirely, to hook me on Jane Austen, deeply and permanently.film, where Darcy and Elizabeth finally declare their love for each other, the use of restrained zoom on the couple was a rather moving as it created a romantic portrait. How you livin'?'\\". B004TTOOQO|4.0|Films about British colonialism were popular in the 30s, if for no other reason than the impending World War was sufficient rationale to show Britain's might. Hence we have such classics as \\"Charge of the Light Brigade\\" (1936) with Errol Flynn and \\"Gunga Gin\\" (1939) with Victor McLaglen, Cary Grant, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. Of lesser note are the so-called \\"Empire trilogy\\" from famed producer Alexander Korda - \\"Sanders of the River\\" (1936) with Leslie Banks and Paul Robeson, \\"The Drum\\" (1938) with Raymond Massey and Valerie Hobson, and this film, \\"Four Feathers\\".<br /><br />Alexander Korda (1893-1956) produced nearly 60 films in his career that started in 1923 in Hungary. His break through film was \\"The Private Life of Henry VIII\\" (1933) and there followed a series of historical dramas including \\"Rise of Catherine the Great\\" (1934), \\"The Scarlet Pimpernel\\" (1934) and \\"Rembrandt\\" (1936). He was extremely pro-England and made films like \\"Clouds Over Europe\\" (1939), \\"The Lion Has Wings\\" (1939), and \\"That Hamilton Woman\\" (1941).<br /><br />His younger brother, Zoltan (1895-1961) directed 20 films and was twice nominated for an award at Cannes (\\"Cry the Beloved Country\\", \\"The Four Feathers\\"). Shortly after making this film he moved to the US where he made \\"Dark Journey\\" (1941), \\"The Thief of Bagdad\\" (1940) and \\"Jungle Book\\" (1942).<br /><br />\\"The Four Feathers\\" is based on a 1902 novel by British writer A. Mason (who also wrote \\"Fire Over England\\"). It was filmed in 1915, 1921 and again in 1929. - the 1929 version directed by Merian Cooper and starring Fay Wray (they worked together again in 1933 on \\"King Kong\\") was the last major Hollywood silent film.<br /><br />FWIW - Producer and RKO head Merian Cooper had been a POW in Russia in 1920 and one of his sources of sustenance was reading a copy of \\"Four Feathers\\". When he made the film in 1929 he incorporate some episodes from his own life, including his imprisonment and escape, into the movie.<br /><br />This version stars John Clements, Ralph Richardson, C. Aubrey Smith, and June Duprez. The story takes place in 1895 when an expedition is being prepared to avenge the death of General Gordon in Khartoum, Sudan, 10 years earlier. Just prior to leaving, a British officer (Clements) resigns his commission and his 3 friends and fianc&eacute;e each send him a white feather - signaling they consider him a coward. Clements faces his fears, ships off to the Sudan, and attempts to redeem himself by rescuing his friends who have been captured by the natives.<br /><br />The film's star John Clements (1910-88) is virtually forgotten today. He was popular in the late 30s and 40s and made nearly 30 films between 1935 and 1982. His role in \\"Four Feathers\\" was the high point in his career.<br /><br />June Duprez (1918-84) is also not a household name. She made fewer than 20 films between 1936 and 1961 and this was her most prominent role to date. She followed this film with a starring role as the Princess in \\"The Thief of Bagdad\\" (1940). She was a favorite of Zorda who used her in many of his films.<br /><br />Ralph Richardson (1902-83) plays a Captain and one of Clements' friends. He was nominated for  an Oscar for \\"The Heiress\\" (1949) and \\"Greystoke\\" (1984), won the Best Supporting Actor from the NY Film critics for \\"Greystoke\\" (1984) and \\"Breaking The Sound Barrier\\" (1952), and won Best Actor at Cannes for \\"Long Day's Journey Into Night\\" (1962). Richardson made more than 50 films between 1933 and 1985. I remember him best in \\"Time Bandits\\" (1981) as the Supreme Being and as the befuddled Inspector Hammond from \\"Clouds Over Europe\\" (1939).<br /><br />C. Aubrey Smith (1863-1948) plays a retired General and father of Duprez. Smith was a great actor known for his roles as an aristocrat. He appeared in more than 100 films from 1915 to 1949. He gave us memorable roles in a host of films, including Major Hamilton in \\"The Lives of a Bengal Lancer\\" (1935) and Lord Capulet in \\"Romeo and Juliet\\" (1936).I remember him best as Col. Williams in \\"Wee Willie Winkie\\" (1937) with Shirley Temple.<br /><br />FWIW - Korda, Clements, Richardson, and Smith were all knighted.<br /><br />Miklos Rozsa (1907-95) was a fellow Hungarian and often worked with Zorda. He scored more than 100 films and earned 16 Oscar nominations and 3 wins (\\"A Double Life\\", \\"Spellbound\\", \\"Ben Hur\\").<br /><br />Cinematographer Georges Perinal (1897-1965) was nominated for an Oscar for this film and \\"The Thief of Bagdad\\" (1940). He filmed 70 movies between 1926 and 1960. Much of the filming was done on location in the Sudan.<br /><br />The film was nominated for an Oscar for Color Cinematography and for Best Picture at Cannes and at the Venice Film festival.<br /><br />Nowadays the notions of honor and country are different than they were in the 30s, so a proper viewing of this film must take the changing ethos into consideration. As well, the British Empire and indeed the notion of being British is far different from what it was, so adjustments are required to appreciate this film, as they are with many of the 30s films.<br /><br />That being said, my favorite British colonial films are \\"Gunga Din\\" (1939) and \\"Charge of the Light Brigade\\" (1936). Add to this \\"Lawrence of Arabia\\" (1962), \\"Zulu\\" (1964), \\"Shaka Zulu\\" (1986), \\"Ghandi\\" (1982), \\"Gallipoli\\" (1981), and \\"The Man who Would be King\\" (1975).irley Temple.     FWIW - Korda, Clements, Richardson, and Smith were all knighted.     Miklos Rozsa (1907-95) was a fellow Hungarian and often worked with Zorda. He scored more than 100 films and earned 16 Oscar nominations and 3 wins (\\"A Double Life\\", \\"Spellbound\\", \\"Ben Hur\\").     Cinematographer Georges Perinal (1897-1965) was nominated for an Oscar for this film and \\"The Thief of Bagdad\\" (1940). He filmed 70 movies between 1926 and 1960. Much of the filming was done on location in the Sudan.    The film was nominated for an Oscar for Color Cinematography and for Best Picture at Cannes and at the Venice Film festival.     Nowadays the notions of honor and country are different than they were in the 30s, so a proper viewing of this film must take the changing ethos into consideration. As well, the British Empire and indeed the notion of being British is far different from what it was, so adjustments are required to appreciate this film, as they are with many of the 30s films.    That being said, my favorite British colonial films are \\"Gunga Din\\" (1939) and \\"Charge of the Light Brigade\\" (1936). Add to this \\"Lawrence of Arabia\\" (1962), \\"Zulu\\" (1964), \\"Shaka Zulu\\" (1986), \\"Ghandi\\" (1982), \\"Gallipoli\\" (1981), and \\"The Man who Would be King\\" (1975).
B004ZQBOXC|3.0|Can LMFAO really be serious? Probably not, but the group's sophomore effort [[ASIN:B004ZQBOXC Sorry for Party Rocking]] surprisingly works, despite its ludicrous conception.  Sure, it won't be recounted as as the classic album of 2011, but in a market that is so fixed on the `latest trend,' Sorry for Party Rocking's infectious, stupid, club-savvy nature works in its favor.  After all, if the Black Eyed Peas and 3OH!3 can thrive off of the `stupid,' why can't LMFAO.  Honestly, Sorry for Party Rocking trumps the latest efforts by both groups.  And face it, with \\"Mr. Corny\\" himself will.i.am at the helm as executive producer, wouldn't one expect one of the `stupidest' efforts ever?  While some may splurge for the deluxe edition, Sorry for Party Rocking's standard edition is enough for the casual listener, despite it's brief 37 minute duration.<br /><br />\\"Rock The Beat II\\" opens the effort, `intro' style, with captivating production work that comprises of a dizzying array of synths and electronics.  The group raps a bit, setting the tone of the album.  The title track follows (\\"Sorry for Party Rocking\\") with great success.  The production is solid and the `party vibe' of the album is overtly conveyed.  The chorus is great - well catchy and silly which makes it viable for this effort: \\"People always say my music's loud/sorry for party rocking...\\" The #1 Billboard Hot 100 hit \\"Party Rock Anthem\\" proceeds, featuring performances by Lauren Bennett and Goonrock.  The production is solid, the hook is catchy (despite immaturity), and the cut itself ends up being a `guilty pleasure.' The best line? \\"Everyday I'm shuffling.\\"<br /><br />\\"Sexy And I Know It\\" is a silly as anything else, but that's the point.  The hook is stupid, but addictive: \\"When I walk in the spot, this is what I see/everybody stops and they staring at me...I'm sexy and I know it.\\" Other notable lines: \\"We hit it to the bar, baby don't be nervous/now shows, no shirt, and I still get serviced...\\" \\"Champagne Showers\\" is better, featuring Natalia Kills on vocals.  The driving dance groove continues once more truly epitomizing the classic line \\"the beat goes on.\\"  Kills's vocals are laden with processing, but then what else do you expect on a dance record? The production is stand-out, the hook as stupid as anything else, and you find yourself singing the cut to yourself despite the fact `you should know better.'  \\"One Day\\" is a bit less enthralling from the onset, but settles into another enjoyable cut led by it's easily dismissible hook: \\"Money in the bank, my car brand new/I got everything I want, but you...\\" Geez, these boys are corny!<br /><br />\\"Take It To The Hole\\" is ridiculous, but brilliant.  The production is handled by Rami Afuni (most of the other cuts are handled by LFMAO) which smartly differentiates the sound a bit. The hook is as stupid as all others - possibly even more so: \\"Take it to the hole, take, take it to the hole...I beat it up...\\" Redfoo is good for some one-liners: \\"I take it to the hole, its Redfoo I'm aggressive/Four moves ahead, wrong dude to play chess with/I roll with the best click flow so impressive...\\" Busta Rhymes `puts a cap on it' with a superb guest rap here.  \\"Best Night\\" works, but at five minutes in duration, makes the listener a bit weary, will.i.am feature or not.  \\"All Night Long\\" reinstates any lost energy with sound production and yet another addictive hook.  Closing cut \\"With You\\" is not the best of the album, but ends the album solidly enough with captivating production being a highlight.<br /><br />Overall, [[ASIN:B004ZQBOXC Sorry for Party Rocking]] is one of those efforts that you take for what it is - an utterly ridiculous pop album that is meant to be a `guilty pleasure.'  This is not an album that will win or even hope to be nominated for `Album of the Year,' but for `what it is,' it works.  After all, after you listen to it, you can say you're \\"sorry for party rocking.\\"er, featuring Natalia Kills on vocals. Overall, [[ASIN:B004ZQBOXC Sorry for Party Rocking]] is one of those efforts that you take for what it is - an utterly ridiculous pop album that is meant to be a `guilty pleasure.'  This is not an album that will win or even hope to be nominated for `Album of the Year,' but for `what it is,' it works.  After all, after you listen to it, you can say you're \\"sorry for party rocking.\\"
B004L79VUI|2.0|I wanted to like this collection of songs from the great Robbie  Robertson.  And all the details surrounding it sure sounded great - including Clapton's presence and contribution.  But I was seriously let down by it.  His vocals don't do well over the course of an entire album.  He lacks the pipes and the expressiveness needed to anchor these songs.  That breathy, talky-style stuff only goes so far before it becomes monotone, expressionless and boring.  The songs, themselves, are lyrically sub-par.  It's hard to believe this is the guy who wrote all of that classic material before. This stuff seems obvious, awkward even - with no real inspiration or revelation.  Considering the personal issues he dealing with - he does so in the most generic fashion.  There's very little insight to be found here.  And musically, well, it's just a yawn.  Middle of the road, mid-tempo - nothing burns or sizzles.  Neil was right - it's better to burn out than fade away.   A little honest-to-goodness passion would go a long way here  - instead it feels like an attempt at ultra-cool posturing.  I know a lot of people have posted highly positive reviews - but I wonder how many times they'll actually be turning the thing on and listening to it all the way through.
B0045JEPXU|4.0|Pitbull's sixth effort [[ASIN:B0045JEPXU Planet Pit]] is chocked full of hits `gift-wrapped' for the clubs.  While Planet Pit should only be a `guilty pleasure,' it turns out that Planet Pit is a sound release that stands on its own aside from just being a club album.  Pit's rhymes are sound throughout, but the attention may be most drawn from the exceptional production work that graces the album as well as a smart choice of collaborators that further accentuate the LP.  There are shockingly no overt misses making Planet Pit a bright spot in the 2011 rap market.<br /><br />\\"Mr. Worldwide (intro)\\" opens the album featuring and produced by Vein.  The intro opens with typical, Latin rap driven-pop production work, which foreshadows the content of Planet Pit. The effort explodes with first single, the exceptional \\"Give Me Everything,\\" which features sound contributions from Ne-Yo, Afrojack (who also produces), and Nayer.  The intro sets up the track strongly finding Pitbull quasi-rapping: \\"Me not working hard?/Yeah Right! Picture that with a Kodak...\\"  Ne-Yo `holds down' the effort with a sound vocal performance on this #1 Billboard Hot 100 hit: \\"Grab somebody sexy, tell `em hey/give me everything tonight...\\" Overall, everything works perfectly with \\"Give Me Everything.\\" The Marc Anthony featured standout \\"Rain Over Me\\" picks up where \\"Give Me Everything\\" left off, providing yet another solid cut.  RedOne & Jimmy Joker handle the boards here on this Euro-pop/Latin production to superb success. Aside from Anthony's catchy hook, the best moment might be the bridge section where the cut changes pace: \\"...I was playing with here, she was playing with me/next thing you know, were were playing with three...\\"<br /><br />\\"Hey Baby (Drop It To The Floor)\\" features T-Pain `doing his thing' as usual.  Sandy Vee's production is great and keeps up the `driving, club vibe' of this effort, getting Planet Pit off to a rollicking start.  \\"Pause\\" doesn't disappoint in the slightest, changing the production scope ever so slightly (Affect, DJ Buddha & Apster produce here) with an exceptional percussive groove that is amongst the best of the effort.  Brevity works in the favor of \\"Pause\\" as an over saturation of infectious, dance-grooves may have threatened to derail Planet Pit ever so slightly.  The Enrique Iglesias featured \\"Come N Go\\" is solid too, finding Dr. Luke & Benny Blanco (Ke$ha, Britney Spears, Katy Perry, etc.) handling production duties.  \\"Shake Se&ntilde;ora\\" is easily one of the album's strongest outings, finding a sound collaborative effort between Pitbull, T-Pain & Sean Paul.  Clinton Sparks & DJ Snake change he pace of the production, which breaks up any weariness of the constant groove that characterizes the effort.  Sean Paul's guest spot is exceptional while T-Pain's hook receives an `A+': \\"...shawty what's happening/girl let's get this thing rocking/you just bend it on over/I'll get behind you and bring it...\\" Definitely a hit.<br /><br />\\"International Love\\" features a superb sounding Chris Brown, with his best showing being the R&B bridge section.  \\"Castle Made of Sand\\" smartly contrasts the driving Latin-dance production for a slightly more conventional, mainstream rap sound.  Kelly Rowland `kills' the refrain while Jamie Drastik provides a solid rap verse.  \\"Too My Love\\" features none other than Red Foo (LMFAO), Vein & David Rush.  \\"Took My Love\\" sounds very much like a LMFAO song given the fact that Red Foo is behind the boards.  It is by no means a miss, but it is a bit weaker than the very best cuts.  \\"Where Do We Go,\\" the penultimate cut, serves as atonement featuring an unlikely Jamie Foxx as Pit's collaborator.  Foxx holds it down as always while producer Jim Jonsin `stitches up' one of the best and tightest productions of the entire album.  Closing number \\"Something for the DJs\\" finds David Guetta and Afrojack collaborating on the production and ends the album solidly.  The best line: \\"If you're sexy and you know it,clap your hands.\\"<br /><br />Overall, [[ASIN:B0045JEPXU Planet Pit]] turns out to be a pleasant surprise. It is very much a dance/club album, but it is very enjoyable across the board.  Pitbull contributes only his best on this album and may draw a new legion of fans because of this album.  Rock solid.rall, [[ASIN:B0045JEPXU Planet Pit]] turns out to be a pleasant surprise. It is very much a dance/club album, but it is very enjoyable across the board.  Pitbull contributes only his best on this album and may draw a new legion of fans because of this album.  Rock solid.

B004K7HMJ6|3.0|Unfortunately for the artist, many times both critics and music fans/enthusiasts often `sleep' on albums, even if they purchased them when they first materialized.  That is the case with Jessie J's [[ASIN:B004K7HMJ6 Who You Are]], the debut effort from the British starlet who has come to be known for her moderate hit \\"Price Tag,\\" featuring American rap standout B.o.B.  The album is an alluring pop album by all means, showcasing Jessica Cornish's (Jessie J) Christina Aguilera-rivaling pipes.  The album debut just outside of the top ten in the U.S. which is a shame considering it is a solid affair for the most part.<br /><br />Dr. Luke produces the enthusiastic first single, \\"Price Tag,\\" which features a guest spot from the ubiquitous B.o.B.  The production work still channels Dr. Luke, but has a slightly more soulful-pop edge than normal for the producer.  The chorus is the selling point: \\"It's not about they money money money, we don't need your money money money, we just wanna make the world dance, forget about the price tag...\\" \\"Nobody's Perfect\\" follows up the excellent cut with another solid cut, also notable for its refrain.  Jessie J sounds great, though she may over-sing the slightest bit.  \\"Abracadabra\\" is enjoyable as well, finding Dr. Luke behind the boards once more.  Aided by songwriting by Dr. Luke & Claude Kelly, Jessie J pulls off another enjoyable cut that showcases her prodigious vocal abilities.<br /><br />\\"Big White Room,\\" a live, acoustic cut, proves to be among the `cream of the crop,' but is somewhat hampered due to it's odd placement.  The cut appears fourth on this effort where it probably would have been best served at or towards the end.  Regardless, Jessie's own personal composition is killer, showcasing her in a `singer/songwriter' vein and differentiating from both previous and later cuts.  \\"Casualty of Love\\" possesses and exceptional soulful-urban vibe about it, contrasting the singer/songwriter edge of \\"Big White Room.\\" \\"Rainbow,\\" another solid cut (though not revolutionary), once again contrasts the track preceding it, and showcases Jessie J's gift o'er and o'er again.  \\"Whose Laughing Now\\" is enjoyable, finding the chanteuse singing/pop-rapping.<br /><br />\\"Do It Like A Dude\\" is an instant standout, produced by The Invisible Men with Parker & James in a \\"Tricky\\" Stewart/The-Dream-style production.  While the cut is a bit overt - OK very overt - it is one of the best of the effort.  \\"Mama Knows Best\\" tames the beast of Jessie down, well as far as the profanity and overt sexual references, placing her against a production palette that recalls big-band meets funk-soul.  \\"L.O.V.E.\\" contrasts once more, in favor of a reggae-tinged pop love song that finds its muse singing: \\"you're my key, you unlock me/keep me close, keep me safe, keep me happy/So sweet, oh love/it's destiny, so nothing stops me/I'll tell the world that you're mine and you got me so...\\"  \\"L.O.V.E\\" definitely exhibits solid songwriting (Jessie J & Toby Gad).<br /><br />\\"Stand Up\\" is a `B+' cut at best, but it works.  \\"I Need This,\\" the penultimate cut is a `B,' beginning to mark the `falloff' of the effort at the end.  \\"Who You Are\\" showcases the great nuances of Jessie's voice, cracks intact.  Unfortunately, like so many title tracks, it doesn't live up to the hype.<br /><br />Overall, [[ASIN:B004K7HMJ6 Who You Are]] is a solid pop album.  If you like pop at its best, I recommend this British starlet's LP by all means.  Vocally, she is a `gem.' Creatively, she has a lot to offer the pop market.t (though not revolutionary), once again contrasts the track preceding it, and showcases Jessie J's gift o'er and o'er again.  \\"Whose Laughing Now\\" is enjoyable, finding the chanteuse singing/pop-rapping.     \\"Do It Like A Dude\\" is an instant standout, produced by The Invisible Men with Parker & James in a \\"Tricky\\" Stewart/The-Dream-style production.  While the cut is a bit overt - OK very overt - it is one of the best of the effort.  \\"Mama Knows Best\\" tames the beast of Jessie down, well as far as the profanity and overt sexual references, placing her against a production palette that recalls big-band meets funk-soul.  \\"L.O.V.E.\\" contrasts once more, in favor of a reggae-tinged pop love song that finds its muse singing: \\"you're my key, you unlock me/keep me close, keep me safe, keep me happy/So sweet, oh love/it's destiny, so nothing stops me/I'll tell the world that you're mine and you got me so...\\"  \\"L.O.V.E\\" definitely exhibits solid songwriting (Jessie J & Toby Gad).      \\"Stand Up\\" is a `B+' cut at best, but it works.  \\"I Need This,\\" the penultimate cut is a `B,' beginning to mark the `falloff' of the effort at the end.  \\"Who You Are\\" showcases the great nuances of Jessie's voice, cracks intact. 1594744769|4.0|The creepy cover made me curious about this book when I first saw it but when I watched the trailer and it actually gave me chills I was convinced that I wanted to read it, I was definitely curious to find out more about these peculiar children and see all the photos inside this book. I was surprised to find out that it wasn't as creepy as I initially thought it would be but it had much more to it and the story just kept surprising me with twists along the way.<br /><br />After Jacob's grandfather dies his last words to Jacob send him off on a hunt to find out the truth about the school where his grandfather spent part of his childhood and about the children that he talked about often with Jacob. From then on the story takes off and becomes much more than just a creepy tale that gives you chills. The story turns into a bit of a mystery with a fascinating plot, we get to see Jacob find out more about his grandfather and his life in the house, and also find that the children were real, that they do have those supernatural abilities (some that were extremely creepy) and that they are still very much alive and unchanged but also hiding from something that is hunting them. The story behind that is a bit of a spoiler so I won't say how it was possible for them to still be there, you would have to read it to find out but I thought it was pretty unique twist to the story which made it a lot more interesting.<br /><br />Jacob was such a great character, his voice was very realistic for a teenage boy, he starts off being a bit of a brat with lots of attitude but begins to develop and change as the story goes along, he becomes someone braver and responsible.  I loved the addition of the pictures in the story, as it goes along the pictures represent a lot of what's going on and also some of the characters in the book and made the story feel much more real, which made me picture everything so much easier in my mind. There's also a bit of historical facts from World War II in the story intertwined with the fiction and made it a lot more chilling. The ending definitely left me curious to see where the story will go next, it gives you an idea of where it's heading but still leaves you wondering and definitely yearning to find out more. Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children was engrossing from the start, everything was described with rich details and it had a pretty original concept with a great setting and lots of twists that will keep you thinking about it long after you finish it.ined with the fiction and made it a lot more chilling. B0050CQY1W|3.0|OK, so here it is...Beyonce's fourth studio album since going solo and if you thought the blas&eacute; title was indicative of her creativity eroding over time, judging by this CD, you'd be right. But first, lets get something straight: Beyonce does not write/compose her own songs. You know it. I know it. There's no point in pretending to judge the merits of an artistic endeavor (this album) when the 'artist' in question is just a glorified performer (Mrs. B). Michael Jackson she ain't. In light of this, I won't be reviewing Beyonce's work, all of us on Amazon (and elsewhere) are really reviewing her 'creative team' made up of writers, producers, etc. To be fair, the vast majority of mainstream artists today have become cash cows devoid of any creative/artistic input: the Jonas Brothers, Britney Spears, Fall Out Boy, Miley Cyrus, etc. The word 'writer' doesn't mean what it used to and today references copyright ownership as opposed to the individual who allegedly puts pen to paper.<br /><br />That said, just because Beyonce is a studio performer doesn't mean I can't take her for what she is, sit back, and enjoy the show. I own all of her previous solo releases as well. Some great and some not so great. 'I Am...Sasha Fierce', '4's predecessor, was (for me) a tremendous let down; a boring, monotonous bloat-fest featuring 18 tracks unnecessarily spread over two CD's. What was she thinking? That we would just snap up anything offered because a gimmicky alter ego (Chris Gaines anyone?) was being showcased? It certainly seemed that way.<br /><br />Which brings us to '4' a great chance to redeem herself and prove there's more to this performer than meets the eye. Yes, Bey has a great voice. Yes, 'I Am...Yours' proved she is an entertaining performer with charisma and stage presence (albeit ego). So what can Beyonce and her team forge, possibly rectifying that previous injustice of an album? In my opinion, not much. I gave three stars for what appears to be an average album; nothing more, nothing less. '4' is undoubtedly better than 'I Am...', but that's not saying much. I expected much better considering the far-reaching claim that Beyonce is creating her own genre of music, a claim heavily attached to this album in particular. Well, it's not hip hop that's for sure, nor is it  an exercise in experimentation (a similar claim). If anyone listens to '4' and hears something radically different that would warrant a claim of 'experimental', then that person has led a very cloistered life. It's an average album, neither helping nor harming her career/discography. Is it possible Beyonce has been left floundering in the wake of her own hype-machine?<br /><br />Overall, I've given '4' a good listen and the stand out tracks on this album all come from the second half. 'Love On Top' is a fun bouncy number reminiscent of a track from the early Michael Jackson era akin to 'Rock With You' including the semi-lifted lyric: \\"dance [rock] the night away\\". 'Countdown' is typical of her usual fare, but with a nice brass section chiming in occasionally; just good fun. The first 45 seconds of 'End of Time' is great, but as soon as the vocals kick in the track just becomes OK. Beyonce had me fooled with that one, I actually thought I was going to hear something innovative or, at the very least, outside of her comfort zone. For some reason 'Run the World (Girls)' ends up being the final track on the album which I feel belies the whole atmosphere the album seemed to build: somber, soulful ballads shifting precariously into euphoric celebration of true love only to be suddenly interrupted by a disjointed power anthem; otherwise, that track has really grown on me due in large part to the sampled Major Lazer drum rhythm. The video, however, has sunk my opinion of the song since it appears Beyonce resorts to the same-old/same-old 'sex sells' gimmick masquerading as feminism. Women run the world and yet we still dress like Bellagio cocktail waitresses? Huh? And don't get me started on the warped weirdness war she seems to have entered with Lady Gaga...lions and hyenas and riot police, oh my! Anyway, I absolutely hate '1+1', the sickly sweet ballad I'm convinced Beyonce is contractually obligated to add to every album since becoming a solo artist. I really could have done without it. All of the songs on this album feature dull lyrics lacking intellectual or emotional depth. An example: 'Best Thing I Never Had' croons \\"I bet it sucks to be you right now...\\" and \\"You showed your ass and I saw the real you\\", ugh. 'Party' featuring Andre 3000 should have been a lot better, but I was sorely disappointed by that track and this is coming from an Outkast fan. The rest of the tracks are just plain forgettable, but don't take my word for it (it's a short listen at 45 minutes) you'll blow right through it and come to your own conclusions.<br /><br />Ultimately, I don't believe there was a way for Bey to prevent her next album from being completely enveloped by the dreaded 'hype'. Beyonce's publicist and other PR people in her camp need to give it a rest. According to '4', Bey's not as great as she, you, or I think she is: she's no Diana Ross, she's no Michael Jackson, and no amount of televised montages touting her 'contributions' to the music industry will change that.arped weirdness war she seems to have entered with Lady Gaga...lions and hyenas and riot police, oh my! Anyway, I absolutely hate '1+1', the sickly sweet ballad I'm convinced Beyonce is contractually obligated to add to every album since becoming a solo artist. I really could have done without it. All of the songs on this album feature dull lyrics lacking intellectual or emotional depth. An example: 'Best Thing I Never Had' croons \\"I bet it sucks to be you right now...\\" and \\"You showed your ass and I saw the real you\\", ugh. 'Party' featuring Andre 3000 should have been a lot better, but I was sorely disappointed by that track and this is coming from an Outkast fan. The rest of the tracks are just plain forgettable, but don't take my word for it (it's a short listen at 45 minutes) you'll blow right through it and come to your own conclusions.     Ultimately, I don't believe there was a way for Bey to prevent her next album from being completely enveloped by the dreaded 'hype'. Beyonce's publicist and other PR people in her camp need to give it a rest. According to '4', Bey's not as great as she, you, or I think she is: she's no Diana Ross, she's no Michael Jackson, and no amount of televised montages touting her 'contributions' to the music industry will change that.
B003GEDLW6|5.0|I'll admit I was a bit apprehensive about getting into these guys from the get go. I am not an electronica person at all, and I had only heard one DnB band, which is Canada's Indie/DnB act U.S.S. What drew me into U. S. S.' sound was the catchy two step beat, in fact that may be what made their music so damn catchy and listenable in the first place. I had mentioned it in a conversation with a buddy of mine, and this is where he mentioned that the two step rythym is very typical DnB stuff, similar to Pendulum. Now I thought the name was interesting but I had my doubts, but I consider myself to be an open minded person. So I searched up a song of theirs on YouTube, and came across a catchy tune called \\"Propane Nightmares\\". I was hooked. After a bit of further research I found out they opened for my favorite band, Iron Maiden. That just left me with no choice but to buy a CD of theirs.<br /><br />So the week after I went to HMV while waiting for my girlfriend to go see Hangover II, and I was searching for Pendulum in the store, specifically In Silico, which has the above mentioned Popane Nightmares. There weren't any copies, but there were just 2 copies of Immersion sitting there, the one in front hypothetically desperately on it's knees begging for me to buy it. Needless to say, I obeyed it's begs.<br /><br />Honestly, I haven't been this surprised by an album purchase in a long time. The moment it began, I was hooked. Not a single song on this album can be labeled \\"weak\\" or \\"filler\\".<br /><br />Genesis is a short instrumental that gets us offmto a grand start. It has a bit of a Star Wars epic march feel to it, and it sets the tone perfectly: 2000mph DnB delivered to your ears in the most pleasant way.<br /><br />Then Salt in the Wounds came, and I will admit. Was a bit taken aback. Two instrumentals to start a CD. odd. I was gob smacked when I first heard the song. I hadn't heard ANYTHING like that before. Honestly, who is creative enough to come up with such a sick beat, such killer and heavy synth riffs, so many twists and turns I can't see coming? For six minutes I just sat there in wonder, amazed at what I was hearing. Guys, this is INTENSE music. This is the second song I listen to every morning. It gets me all energized.<br /><br />Rob Swire has a chilling voice. It is so crisp, pure and strong. When Watercolour came, I was so surprised at how eerie and beautiful his voice sounded. Watercolour is a touching and energetic number with great lyrics and amazing music. One of the best tracks in years.<br /><br />There is something for everybody in this album, no matter what their tastes may be defined as. Crush is a catchy Muse-esque number that is consistently fun to listen to, I can imagine it being a great singalong tune at a concert. Under the Waves can only be described as \\"Iron Maiden doing electro rock\\" with the twin synths and what not. The two parter The Island makes for a truly different experience. I love the second part especially, with all the sick scratches and synth effects... That was AWESOME! Immunize is fun for a catchy dance tune.<br /><br />Ben Mount, popular English rapper and The bands concert MC, makes an appearance on The Vulture, and it RULES! His appearance alone makes it the best track on the album for me. I can imagine myself at a Pendulum concert losing my voice shouting the words of the song. It also doesn't surprise me that he has a hell of a lot of energy on stage. I consider him to be the rap equivalent of Bruce Dickinson... he even looks like Bruce Dickinson too!<br /><br />And how awesome is a consistent final four tracks. The edgy electro rocker Witchcraft sends shivers down my Spine every time I hear it. Honestly it's just powerful. I especially love the heavy reprise of the chorus near the end. Self Vs Self is a great duet with In Flames and it just fits so well! Anders and Rob have such perfect chemistry. Steve Wilson of Porcupine Tree appears on The Fountain, an interesting little dittythat reminds you a lot of latter day Rush. The final track Encoder is a very cool tribal track in the first half, then becomes a U2-esque tune to finish the album.... It's a total ear worm. I won't lie it was in my head dreams he first night I heard it. I was also gob smacked by the rather creepy ending to the tune with the water sounds and breathing then the wham noise.<br /><br />In short, while not quite The Final Frontier, this is one of the best albums I've ever heard! I guarantee you it is so addicting. Even if you're like me and dislike electronica, this album is one hot package. Buy it now!!!!!! Essential listening, people!!!!!!!der is a very cool tribal track in the first half, then becomes a U2-esque tune to finish the album.... It's a total ear worm. I won't lie it was in my head dreams he first night I heard it. I was also gob smacked by the rather creepy ending to the tune with the water sounds and breathing then the wham noise.
