B004Y1USV2|3.0|After the highly successful 35th Anniversary tour petered out in the summer of 2004, Yes went on the longest hiatus in their history.  Mostly this was due to several physical ailments that Jon Anderson endured as well as his resistance to continue with the traditional recording/touring process that Yes had done consistently from 1997 forwards.  In 2008 a summer tour was set to take place with Anderson, White, Squire, Howe and Rick Wakeman's son Oliver on keys, but was cancelled due to another bout of serious health problems for Jon Anderson.  However, this time, Squire, Howe, and White were not keen on waiting any longer to get out there and tour Yes songs, so they hired Benoit David from a Yes tribute band after being impressed with his performance on a YouTube clip.  They toured initially as \\"Howe, Squire, and White of Yes,\\" before then touring as Yes and referring to Benoit David as an \\"understudy,\\" and then eventually stating \\"This is now Yes\\" with David replacing Anderson outright.  After a couple of years of touring together, they decided to make an album.  Trevor Horn then came into the picture, along eventually with Geoff Downes replacing Oliver Wakeman, and we are now back to essentially the 1980 line-up of Yes with Benoit David on vocals instead of Horn.    The first 15 or so minutes of [[ASIN:B004Y1USV2 Fly From Here]] (Overture, Fly From Here, Sad Night At The Airfield) are just as strong a beginning to a Yes album as you can hope for in 2011.  It's not [[ASIN:B00007LTI9 Close to the Edge]] or [[ASIN:B00007LTIB Relayer]], but it is very melodic and well performed music, satisfying and interesting in nearly way.  The production and sound quality is also excellent.  \\"Madman at the Screens\\" is also good, with the \\"Sailor...Sailor beware\\" part echoing \\"Machine...Machine Messiah\\" from [[ASIN:B000002J23 Drama]].  As you will tell quickly from the writing credits, the bulk of the material on the album was written by Trevor Horn & Geoff Downes years ago when they were in The Buggles and in the midst of joining Yes for [[ASIN:B000002J23 Drama]].  The \\"suite\\" works pretty well...I think the transitions between the different parts could've been handled a little more creatively, but each part has its strengths and taken as a whole - it's a very good start to the album, with \\"Fly From Here\\" (Part One) being the stand-out and one of the stronger tracks from Yes in the last 20 years.    From there, things get a little bit spotty.  \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a Chris Squire tune that he was working on for a solo album; he sings lead on it and it's very reminiscent of Conspiracy's first album [[ASIN:B00004RI7V Conspiracy]]-- so much so, that I kept anticipating Billy Sherwood coming in with some lush, swamped in reverb backing vocals!  This is a frustrating song in that the first three and a half minutes are pretty basic in composition and unmemorable in melody, but the last minute and a half is very, very good - they should've started the song out with this part as it contains a very tasty bass line and catchy hook (\\"eh yeah, eh yeah, eh yeah, eh yeah\\"), and then segued into the `song,' eventually coming back to this part.  Would've made it a little bit more interesting.  The potential in this song was not reached.  But, at least it's solid.  The same cannot be said of \\"Life on a Film Set\\" which actually had me really excited as the first couple of minutes are excellent - setting up a really cool vibe and mood.  It sounds a lot more like Asia or The Buggles than Yes (it's a Horn/Downes composition from the early 80s), but regardless, it's pretty engaging.  However, for reasons I don't think I will ever understand, the song totally changes into a herky jerky, silly song that sounds like a [[ASIN:B00009Z574 Tormato]] or Drama outtake that would've never made it on to those albums.  Why they didn't just stick with the mood and vibe of the first two minutes is beyond me.  I do realize this song is based on the Buggles outtake \\"Riding a Tide\\" which has more or less the same arrangement, but when re-doing it for this album, they should've tossed out the second half.  Seems to me this is another example of Yes not being committed to just sticking with a solid idea because they feel they need to \\"shake things up\\" in an effort to come across as \\"proggy.\\"  Shake things up if you have strong material and it makes sense in the context of the rest of the song, but the abrupt switch in tone and music during this song is extremely frustrating considering how silly it sounds.  These few minutes are among the most annoying in Yes' entire catalog.  \\"Hour of Need\\" and \\"Solitaire\\" are nice Steve Howe showcases, with him singing co-lead on the former and knocking out another solid acoustic guitar showcase in the latter.  Props to Oliver Wakeman as well for his keyboard solo on \\"Hour of Need\\" which maybe more than anything else on the album harkens back to Yes' glory days in feel.  \\"Into the Storm\\" is a nice closer, with a heavy Tormato vibe going on.      Fly From Here is better than it has any right to be.  Having seen this line-up of Yes live in 2008 and from numerous accounts from fans and videos on YouTube, Benoit David is not a strong singer.  He sounds very good on this album - but in all fairness, in the year 2011 and working with one of the most well-renowned producers in the world, it's faint praise.  Even an excellent singer would have a hard time filling the shoes of Jon Anderson, and Benoit David's performance clearly does not contain the emotional depth that Jon Anderson brings to his vocals.  But, take that as you will - there are Yes fans that criticized Jon's direction of the band on [[ASIN:B00069FKC8 Ladder]] and [[ASIN:B00005NWMK Magnification]]; Fly From Here presents Yes in much the same light that the other non-Jon Anderson album Drama did.  And while it's hard not to be cynical with much of the material on this album coming from Horn & Downes' songwriting partnership 30 years ago ([[ASIN:B0033QEUGI Adventures in Modern Recording]]), I can't deny that there is a lot to like on this album.  The question now is...where exactly does Yes fly from here?

Kurt Russell does an excellent job acting as a disciplined, regimented soldier, and the soldier is selected from birth.  Later in the movie he starts showing some emotional ties to his fellow captives.  Then Kurt must save this group of people, from invading soldiers that have replaced him and almost single handedly (kill them all).

193413712X|2.0|Okay. Okay. I'm duly intimidated. Pulitzer Prize. Iowa Writers Workshop. Harvard Teaching gig. Literati praise up the wazoo. So what do I know? I read Tinker in my book group. I put it down after the first sixty-seven pages. Then I picked it up again.  Gave it a second chance. Was I missing something? Behind my love of reading did a Philistine lurk?      I got to the book club meeting and discovered that everybody had problems with Tinkers. And, lest you doubt our credentials, there are librarians, academics and some other pretty damn educated folks among us.     To begin with, let me say that I don't give a damn about clocks. I understand the metaphors that go with living, dying and clocks. My mother used to sing a lullaby about a grandfathers clock that stopped working \\"when the old man died.\\"  It's been done so much the steak has burned to charcoal. And I also don't get a whole lot out of the Borealis stuff. Yes, I understand that there is a relationship between these little vignettes and the family that Harding is telling us about. I know the literary establishment can ponder and brood and wax intellectual about the profundity of it, but it doesn't work for me. So what does this prove? Only that you have to pass yourself off as better that the common reader to enjoy this book. Those who count yourself among Harding's admirers can wallow in their superiority, but to me the book was BORING.     Take out the clock and the Borealis and you've got about a hundred and twenty pages of slip-sliding between past and present tense, even within paragraphs, and ever changing points of view with first person and omniscient narration. I tried to find a pattern to this chameleon but the changing colors didn't make much sense to me. Oh yes, life's got its subjective side, alright. And we do tend to wander through it in ways that sometimes can be replicated by slipping through time and point of view. But to call that Pulitzer worthy is a stretch. Nothing new here. Nothing to see. Just move along, I say.     On top of that, and most frustrating for me, we've got ourselves some inherently unreliable narrators. George is on his deathbed, and I for one, having managed to slip out of Death's close grasp myself three times over the last five years, understand perfectly well that in those moments when life and death hang in the balance, the narrator experiencing this transformation is unreliable. I wouldn't believe my account of anything that happened to me if I delivered it in that condition. And because this is true, I don't believe Mr. Omniscient either. Harding gives me no reason to trust this narrator's account. He (And it is likely a \\"he\\" because this is a very male book. We don't even learn George's wife's name until fewer than twenty pages before the end.) gives us no reason to believe a word he says and can't hold the floor against the authors whims. That means I vote \\"not guilty\\" based upon reasonable doubt, whenever Harding tries to make a point or render a judgment.     I don't fare any better with George's father, Howard the Tinker. I'm not holding his epilepsy against him. Epileptics can be credible, but Howard is not cut from that cloth. For example, Howard apparently believes that his wife, Kathleen, is a two-faced schemer, and Mr. Omniscient doesn't dispel us of his conclusion, or delusion. But wait just a minute here. They live in a hovel, not some mansion. Howard the Tinker, can't even afford a decent horse to pull his sad inventory through the muck of rural Maine. He makes bupkis. What's Kathleen going to get out of committing him to a mental institution in secret? Is there a Mr. Right lurking who will do a Cinderella number on her? Not in this book? If she commits Howard, she gets no income, no inheritance, no palace. What's the purpose of all her scheming Howard? Can it be that a mental institution is really the right place for you after all? I dare say, your sanity is not exactly beyond question when you spend years brooding about the kids you left behind, then travel hours or days to spend five-minutes with George. Howard's not giving me strong sanity vibes.    So Tinker, for me, boils down to a bloated novella that ambitiously attempts to make statements about life and death, about family and hard-times, but never actually says anything very profound. There's no payoff and the pace is a slow Iowan death. It seems to me that whenever the author approaches anything that peaks the interest, he slams on the brakes, balls it up with a gambit of magician-like flourishes of time and point-of-view changes.  Presto, you get bored. You want to turn pages all right, but just to get through it, not because you're anxious to find out what's going to happen next.    No doubt, Harding, the teacher, knows how to use all the golf clubs in the bag, but using them when he doesn't have to makes it seem like he's just showing off for his students and the literary intelligentsia who are wont to crow over style to the sacrifice of substance. This book is not for me and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who actually likes to read for the story.     Barry S. Willdorf author of The Flight of the Sorceress

B005529EI2|5.0|When the first film in the epic &#34;Lord of the Rings&#34; trilogy thrilled fans and topped the box office for weeks, expectations rose even higher for the sequel, &#34;The Two Towers.&#34; Would the follow-up be as beautifully crafted as the first?<br /><br />The answer is yes -- and much more. &#34;The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers&#34; is not quite as beautiful and strange as the first movie, but it makes up for this by the even more epic, spellbindingly complex story. Jackson follows different groups as they make their way through Middle-Earth, encountering Anglo-Saxon-style kingdoms, talking trees and the most horrifying of nightmares.<br /><br />The fellowship has been split, and two members are dead. Now Aragorn (Viggo Mortensen), Legolas (Orlando Bloom) and Gimli (John Rhys-Davies) are pursuing a band of orcs who kidnapped Merry and Pippin (Dominic Monaghan and Billy Boyd). But soon Merry and Pippin are rescued by an ancient treelike creature, and the others encounter an old friend -- Gandalf (Ian McKellen), reborn as the White Wizard.<br /><br />Meanwhile, Frodo (Elijah Wood) and Sam (Sean Astin) are making their way towards Mordor, and soon Frodo realizes that they are being followed by Gollum (Andy Serkis), who once possessed the One Ring and still lusts after it. But Frodo begins to pity the degenerate creature, and agrees to let Gollum lead them to Mount Doom -- but Sam suspects that Gollum cannot be trusted. And<br /><br />Though billed as such, &#34;The Two Towers&#34; is not really a sequel. Instead, it's just a continuation of the story that left off at the end of &#34;Fellowship of the Ring,&#34; when Frodo and Sam went off on a journey by themselves. So now, the focus spreads past our little band of heroes to include all of Middle-Earth -- it's not all about Frodo and the hobbits anymore, but about whole kingdoms being crushed by the bad guys.<br /><br />While there are some humorous moments still (&#34;Don't talk to it! Don't encourage it!&#34; Pippin wails when a &#34;tree&#34; speaks to them), there is a darker tone to the overall story. Aragorn's quest along with his friends involves a seemingly hopeless battle against the evil wizard Saruman, which may involve the deaths of many  innocent, ill-equipped not-soldiers. To top his previous work, Jackson creates three simultaneous climaxes, including the grimy, rain-soaked battle of Helm's Deep.<br /><br />But as he tells the epic stories, Jackson doesn't neglect the smaller, more intimate stories, like Gollum's sometimes-chilling struggle between good and evil... which manifests as multiple personalities. And the final battle is capped by a magnificent, tear-jerking speech by Sam about what they are doing (&#34;Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back only they didnâ€™t. Because they were holding on to something&#34;).<br /><br />And WETA Workshop's CGI effects don't disappoint. Not only do they manage whole armies and battles, but they brought the gruesome Gollum to life. He's probably the first convincing CGI character, to the point where you can actually forget that this Ring junkie is just a bunch of pixels.<br /><br />Elijah Wood continues his magnificent performance as Frodo Baggins, with the deep friendship, compassion and weariness that he started to show before. But his performance deepens to include some serious Ring-lust, as Frodo increasingly is worn away by the Ring's evil. And Sean Astin's Sam becomes even more determined to protect Frodo -- from soldiers, Gollum, ringwraiths -- even as Frodo slips away from him.<br /><br />But the supporting cast gets plenty of attention too. Mortensen shows Aragorn growing into a natural leader who passionately wants to save the people depending on him, and becomes enmeshed in a love triangle with Miranda Otto's strong-willed warrior-maid Eowyn. Bloom and Rhys-Davies also get to change their characters with time, becoming best buddies and competing to see who kills more orcs. And whileMcKellen isn't quite as much fun as Gandalf 2.0, he still has the wisdom and fire of his previous self -- and as his opposite, Christopher Lee gets to be disdainful and vicious.<br /><br />&#34;The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers&#34; is an epic done right -- it's crammed crammed with so much action, beauty and pathos that it never has time to suffer from &#34;middle chapter syndrome.&#34; An amazing continuation.revious self -- and as his opposite, Christopher Lee gets to be disdainful and vicious.  &#34;The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers&#34; is an epic done right -- it's crammed crammed with so much action, beauty and pathos that it never has time to suffer from &#34;middle chapter syndrome.&#34; An amazing continuation.

So then I did some research and the ATEN 221A appeared well reviewed, was 1/2 the price of Staples' peripheral switch (!), and also comes with a USB / device cable, e.g. no need for that additional expense as you'll need at least one extra cable when you add this small switch to your peripheral device. With the Staples switch, it was $40 plus the cable and of course as noted, it didn't work as advertised.    I couldn't believe it - loaded up the Aten 221A and it immediately worked manually, e.g. back and forth between the PC and MAC, as long as we pushed the little button on top of the switch. The next morning I phoned into ATEN's tech support line and somebody immediately picked up. It turns out there was one simple software command to \\"check\\" on both computers, and VOILA!, now automatically, we can print from either printer, just by hitting \\"print\\" on either computer. The software / switch is reading what's coming in and prints in sequence, perfectly.    I am thrilled with this small purchase, which will help us out so much, along with its ease of installation, tech support, and that what it promises - it delivers!
0670022411|1.0|I finished this book weeks ago and am still angry enough that I was compelled to write my first ever Amazon book review.    I admit my expectations were probably too high.  The description was promising, the reviews favorable.  Brainy supernatural historical thriller sounded right up my alley.  I slogged through it, hopeful till the end that it would redeem itself.  And then it didn't.    Other reviewers have already captured the lack of action, the endless descriptions of tea drinking or toast eating or rowing or napping or putting on leggings or planning vampire dinners or doing supernatural yoga.  I could have made it through all of that with only mild irritation.  I think I could have even come to terms with the fact that the marketing campaign was a complete dupe and this book is really a sappy supernatural romance.    I think what put me over the edge was that it wasn't just a sappy supernatural romance, it was a terrible sappy supernatural romance.  We start out with intriguing characters like Diana, a strong, intelligent, accomplished alchemy expert who happens to be a witch.  We also get Matthew, a brooding, extraordinarily handsome, slightly threatening and mysterious vampire.  Then, for no apparent reason and in the space of a few days, they fall hopelessly, madly in love.  Not just soul mate love, but the kind of love where Diana completely reverses every aspect of her previously strong personality and becomes a simpering, mindless pile of goo that spends her time napping and being frightened by things and wishing that Matthew would come to her.  And Matthew goes from being a somewhat menacing super powerful vampire to being a puppy eyed mope who murmurs hacky terms of endearment like \\"ma lionesse\\" and other gag worthy bits of love froth to Diana.  Eventually Matthew lays claim to Diana and marks her as his possession and she's just fine with that, since they're in supernatural love and all.       For anyone interested in the book I recommend one of twocourses: a) read the first few chapters and let yourself get excited about the potential and then, while Diana is still wary of Matthew, put the book away and just imagine the rest of the story until you reach a thrilling and satisfying conclusion; or b) skip the first few chapters and dive in just as Diana and Matthew start mooning over each other and revel in a maudlin tale of supernatural love so overwhelming that even a complete lack of personality or backbone can't keep these two apart.

B000EHQTZO|5.0|King Kong, a classic of its genre, didn't become famous due to emotional power, an interesting story, or compelling characters. Rather, at the time, its special effects drew in the crowds. This kind of film shows that innovation in the film industry is met with critical acclaim.     Of course, compared to today's films, the special effects of the archaic King Kong seem like a joke. However, even though the monsters are obviously fake, the movie is still a gripping action film, which is pretty amazing considering it's about 80 years old. A comparison of this film to something such as, oh, I dunno, [[ASIN:B0014Z4OQG Cloverfield]], shows how far special effects in filmmaking has come. What's more, this film paved the way for the special effects industry by creating a creature on screen (King Kong) that would be impossible to replicate in real life, and doing reasonably well at convincing the audience that the beast was real. During this time, the monster thriller type of film was a new concept.     While plot is not this film's forte, it does have some allusions and foreshadowing, making it several notches above your everyday action film. (See the Comments section below for more clarification).     Overall, I'd say that, even though its characters (excluding King Kong) are mediocre and the special effects are dated, this one classic film that rocked the film industry, and still continues to thrill audiences to this day.

B003UESJIS|3.0|FILM RATING:  2.5 stars<br /><br />Let me start by saying that Another Year (2010) is not a bad movie, as you might assume from my rating. Even though I didn't connect with it, it's a well made film that will connect with certain audiences who appreciate the subtle nuances of the story. Many film critics seem to love the movie, but I'm not one of them. It was just average for me...hence the 2.5 star rating.  I just couldn't get into the story and characters emotionally as much as I wanted to. The plot felt dragged out and a bit too boring.<br /><br />Writer/Director Mike Leigh, whose probably best known for Secrets & Lies (1996), continues his small character-driven indie films with Another Year. I haven't seen Secrets & Lies yet, but I'm definitely interested to see if its better than Another Year since I've heard such good things about it. Another Year was my first Mike Leigh film, and while I wasn't impressed with it, I could appreciate the artistic and technical craft that went into producing it. The production design and cinematography supported the story perfectly. The photography didn't stand out for me, but it wasn't bad either. I tend to favor more stylistic photography in my movies, but Director of Photography Dick Pope gave the film a realistic look and feel with lots of natural lighting that made it feel like the 4 different seasons in the UK.<br /><br />The lead actors all gave good solid performances within the story and writing they had to work with. Leslie Manville is probably the best performance, but her character also began to annoy me and get on my nerves by the end. She was just so clingy and immature. So kudos to Manville if that is what she and director Mike Leigh wanted to accomplish. But it didn't make for a character I could ultimately root for and want to watch again. Jim Broadbent and Ruth Sheen were definitely believable as an older couple in the twilight years of their marriage.<br /><br />I watched Another Year on DVD, where it looked ok. I'm sure there is a color and picture quality difference that you see on blu-ray. So if you're going to check this film out, I would watch it in the high definition format and see if that helps you appreciate the film more. B004Y1USV2|3.0|This release is really not worthy of Yes, but not for the reasons that some others have suggested.  Personally I am not all that troubled that Jon Anderson was not a part of this effort and has not been touring with Yes for the past few years.  Certainly he deserves much of the credit for Yes' creativity over the decades, but I have always favored the work of Steve Howe and Chris Squire anyway.  I know many Yes fans decried this album as a return to the Drama days.  If only that were so.  Drama was the first new Yes album I bought in the summer of 1980.  I was really into it then and it is still among my favorite Yes albums.  In my estimation \\"Machine Messiah\\" and \\"Tempus Fugit\\" stand alongside any other classic Yes material and the songs on Drama were more even and consistent than its predecessor, Tormato in which Jon Anderson was very much a creative force.  \\"Fly From Here\\" sounds very little like Drama despite Geoff Downes returning to play keyboards and Trevor Horn producing the record.  It is a collection of mostly mid tempo, generic sounding songs.  You can tell it is Yes but it sounds like a collection of castoffs, like the extra tracks you find on the Rhino reissues of Yes' classic albums.  \\"We Can Fly From Here\\" is certainly one of the stronger tracks on this recording.  It is a holdover from the Drama sessions in 1979.  Regrettably it is not as good as most of the music that was recorded during those sessions.  Five additional tracks were written around this piece to create a 20 minute multi-part suite like the ones that used to consume an entire album side back in the 1970s, but this one is not nearly as compelling as \\"Close to the Edge,\\" or Tales From Topographic Oceans, or even the three part \\"Starship Trooper.\\"  Once you get past the \\"Fly From Here\\" mini epic, there are several decent tracks.  \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is the best in my opinion.  Co-written by Chris Squire, it features him on lead vocal for much of the song.  The lyrics though are a bit cheesy and the song lacks the twists and turns of a great Yes tune that takes you on a journey and offers you something new with multiple listens.  \\"Hour of Need\\" and \\"Into the Storm\\" are two of the better tracks on the album, they just don't measure up to what Yes is capable of with or without Jon Anderson.  Finally, some remarks about the vocalist Benoit David.  Many have dismissed him as a Jon Anderson wannabe; a bad joke because he sprang from a Yes tribute band.  The man has proved his gifts singing live with the band the last few years, hitting all of Anderson's trademark high notes.  Obviously his natural voice is in a lower register, but unfortunately it seems to me that his abilities have been masked by the production and the mixing of this album.  He is not really allowed to front the band.  Many of the songs feature the harmony of Benoit and Chris Squire mostly, and even when Benoit's voice does stand alone on the album it is drowned out by the instrumentation around him.  I think Trevor Horn really missed the boat here.  Let the man sing and allow him to stand or fall on his own merits but don't muffle or disguise him through harmony or a wall of instruments.  This is a collection of largely forgettable songs, none of them really bad, just nothing special.  After several listens the CD will go on the shelf where it will be mostly forgotten.

The chorus will undoubtedly be sung by millions of young girls experiencing their first strong feelings of affection. A joyous tune was inserted toward the end of the album with \\"End of Time\\" produced by The Dream. In signature BeyoncÃ© style, the track boasts a catchy chant proclaiming never-ending devotion. The listener is made to feel like he or she has attended a celebration for lovers as the highly infectious beat keeps a fast, but exciting beat. The final song on the album was the first released \\"Run the World (Girls).\\" While some may be quick to dismiss it as another feminist proclamation of power, others will dig deeper into the cluster of sounds and tribal overtone and find a well-orchestrated performance. The tune samples Major Lazer's \\"Pon de Floor\\" and reintroduces fans to a virtually untapped Caribbean flavor reclaiming her influence in pop history.       All in all, many fans will be pleased that BeyoncÃ© took risks most artist would not, resulting in an enjoyable collection of captivating rhythm with international appeal.

It was a nice idea to have an older Spock end up in the thick of things in order to get the Kirk-Spock relationship back on track, but wouldn't it have been even more interesting had they got Shatner to do the same thing for the 'old' Kirk relative to the 'young' Spock?    The biggest weakness in this film, as the start of this review says, is the plot. It makes little sense that rogue Romulans would seek to act out revenge on Spock. Otherwise the video quality is pretty awesome.     Audio Quality   This is not going to be your big budget action movie with explosions, but the DTS-HD MA track got the job done. The book is well-written, moves along quickly, includes photos, and is very readable if you don't mind some difficult sexual scenes. I highly recommend it.
B004WKOCP8|4.0|Ok, so everyone's established this is by far Incubus's softest and slowest album to date.    Seems to me they're just playing to their strengths, which, as good as all the guys are at their individual instruments and roles within the band, is undoubtedly Brandon's vocals.  Whilst most vocalists' voices get gravelier and lower as they get older, Brandon's seems to have done the opposite.  Listen to him sing something live from one of the older albums now, as compared to how he sang the same song, say ten years ago, and his voice is far higher pitched and whinier when really pushing it.  The logical step for the band was always to move in this direction as they have always written the music around Brandon's lyrics and melodies, whereas most bands go the opposite way, writing the instrumental side of the song before later putting the vocals over the top.    Personally i've noticed when listening to Incubus over the last few years that i've tended to listen more to they're slower stuff anyway when picking out songs. ie Agoraphobia and Talk Shows on Mute from A Crow Left of... and 11am, Just a Phase from Morning View etc, so when I read that this one was going to be a \\"Slow burn\\" as it was put, it seemed to make total sense to me.  Incubus are probably the only band I can think of that I would be happy to embrace an entire album of softer material from, because they just do it better than pretty much anyone else.    When Adolescents and Promises Promises were first released I'll admit it took a couple listens for them to grow on me, but once they did, I fell in love with them and couldn't stop listening.  Given time, the rest of the album is much the same way.  Although it seems much more simplistic and beige at first compared to a lot of they're previous material, the songs reveal more and more upon repeated listens.    One thing that did surprise me about this album, from a band that has produced so much completely original music, were the blatant influences from otherartists.  I mean, In The Company of Wolves - Pink Floyd much?  Jeez! The first two and a half minutes of that track would have given Pink Floyd's lawyers a massive boner! And throughout the album there are quite a few little hooks that i'd heard before.    Nevertheless If Not Now, When? is an album i think Incubus were always due to make, and if given enough time and listens, stacks up against they're previous material.  It's not their best album, but it's worthy of its place amongst a back catalog  from a band that has been at a higher level than 99% of other bands over the last 15 years.

I'm not a huge guy, but my ears are a little larger than average for my size.  All previous headsets I've owned have started some soreness in the cartilage when I wear them too long, but this headset fits around my ears and doesn't put any pressure on them. B0043URV8M|5.0|I'll try to keep this short.  I don't normally write reviews on Amazon, but I need to sing the praises of this soundtrack.    Yes, John Williams' score to the original Harry Potter was amazing, and set the bar very high (I mean, he's John friggin Williams.)  Since Williams left the franchise, Harry Potter films have gone through quite a few composers (and directors, and actors, and set designs...)  None of Williams' successors were terrible, but they never quite reached the level of quality that Williams set.  Alexandre Desplat has reached that level, and without trying to emulate John Williams.    The score to Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is magical, frightening, funny, beautiful, and original; Desplat is a masterful orchestrator.  Williams original Potter theme is sprinkled into the score, but it is not at all intrusive (as it sometimes was in movies 4 through 6) and is intricately woven into Desplat's own orchestration style.  If I didn't know any better, I'd assume Desplat himself had created the theme.  Desplat has also created a beautiful 'secondary' theme, which truly rivals Williams' own.  Where Williams' main theme is magical and mysterious, Desplat's theme is contemplative and somewhat melancholy.    Now, to top it off, the audio quality is amazing.  I've never experienced audio so clean, warm, bright, dynamic, and full.  My CD came with a code to download high quality waveform audio files.  These files are HUGE (the mp3 album is 134.4 MB, and the waveform album is a whopping 782.6 MB) but the quality is like nothing I've ever dreamed.  When combined with my Bose headset, I feel like I'm sitting in front of a live orchestra.  I have now been spoiled by this quality, and I demand that all soundtracks include a redemption code for high-quality downloads!    Whether or not you are a Harry Potter fan, you will love this soundtrack.

B0053YEM7U|2.0|I've held off on adding my \\"Fly From Here\\" review until I was able to say that I fully knew and understood every drop of this new Yes album. So I've given it 7 solid, serious, objective listens and the word that resonates the most is \\"disappointing\\".    Things definitely begin and end on high notes. I love the Overture. It's exciting and reveals themes that are used later on but never as well as during these first few minutes. Fly From Here Part 1 - We Can Fly has a lush melody and great momentum to it. And my favorite song on the album is probably the closing number Into The Storm, an upbeat, rhythmic number with a gorgeous and absolutely haunting middle section.     The rest of Fly From Here is either predictable, boring or just plain not very good. The song-structure and melodies are so basic and unimaginable. Steve Howe's solo pice Solitaire is decent enough but it feels out of place among this collection of songs. Same goes for Chris Squire's The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be which I might be able to justify on a solo project but certainly not in the middle of a Yes album. Life On A Film Set is ridiculously cheesy...if they sing the phrase \\"riding a tiger\\" one more time, I may be tempted to break something.  And Hour Of Need is harmless but more worthy of someone like Asia than Yes.     The centerpiece of the album is the 20+ minute Fly From Here suite which is once again, disappointing. As I said earlier, it starts off with lots of promise...I have no problem with it's first 8 minutes but it quickly turns lame and silly. While I wasn't expecting The Gates Of Delirium or The Revealing Sciences of God, something a little more challenging and intricate would have been welcomed.      I know that so many of the comments about this new chapter of Yes are centered around Jon Anderson no longer being in the band and sure, I'd rather Jon was here and am not at all happy about the way his legendary time with Yes came to an end. But I actually like Benoit David's vocalwork on Fly From Here --- he somehow makes it his own and most of what he's doing works nicely. I just don't think that Geoff Downes' keyboard style is suited for Yes music. He brings a Mannheim Steamroller kind of quality to the sound which might work in limited doses but over the course of a whole album I don't think he comes anywhere close to the many keyboard-players who passed through Yes over the years.    I was definitely expecting a lot more from this effort and am surprised at just how mediocre it is. I've heard some refer to Fly From Here as Drama, Part 2 but I loved Drama which was dynamic and original and this one doesn't come anywhere within miles of approaching that level. Two stars out of 5.

B000KJTOMQ|5.0|What is the machinery of divine grace?  For the characters of Brideshead Revisited, it is a fishing line:<br /><br />\\"I caught him with an unseen hook and an invisible line which is long enough to let him wander to the ends of the world and still to bring him back with a twitch upon the line.\\"<br /><br />Beginning with a summertime outing in the English countryside, and ending in the darkness of World War II, BR attempts to trace the thread of grace as it leads Charles and the Brideshead family back to the heart of God.  What exactly that means the reader will have to discern himself, but the result is a mixture of both the organic and the contrived.  But what else would one expect from a divine plan?<br /><br />Evelyn Waugh writes dialogue effortlessly; the characters of Sebastian, Brideshead, Edward Ryder, Julia, Lord Marchmain, Anthony Blanche--all of them speak with an ease that in part is due to their upperclass status but moreso to the skill of Waugh.  His ear for voices is remarkable--I never read a line of dialogue that I didn't hear in my head with a distinct, vital voice.<br /><br />If I chose to complain (which I have not), my only issue would be with the topic of divine grace.  The few moments that struck me as false were a certain character's guilt-speech concerning the death of Christ, a later moment from the same character on the possibility of living outside of God's grace, and a specific scene of witnessing someone crossing himself which I will not further elaborate on, for the sake of spoilers.  At these moments the machinery of grace showed itself, and by this I mean the machinery of the plot.  It's the only time the characters seem to do unexpected and unaccountable things, and I felt the story suffered for it.  Some will call it grace, and attribute these changes of character to divine power.  I will call it Waugh.<br /><br />Finally, Waugh's prose is at times ornamental, but in my estimation, always appropriate to the task and quite beautiful to boot.  My favorite bit was Marchmain's monologue near the end, which is a gorgeous blend of prose and poetry.  The potentially challenging aspects of this novel are its religious themes and its vocabulary.  If one is familiar with British slang and idioms, this will likely pose no problem, but if you're a stranger to phrases like \\"come a cropper\\" and the like, you have been warned.  What I found difficult was the usage of architectural terminology I was unfamiliar with.  However, I am guessing Waugh uses a rather stock vocabulary of architectural terms, and I simply need to memorize them for future endeavors.  Quibbles aside, I really can't recommend this one enough.  Five stars.monologue near the end, which is a gorgeous blend of prose and poetry.  The potentially challenging aspects of this novel are its religious themes and its vocabulary.  If one is familiar with British slang and idioms, this will likely pose no problem, but if you're a stranger to phrases like \\"come a cropper\\" and the like, you have been warned.  What I found difficult was the usage of architectural terminology I was unfamiliar with.  However, I am guessing Waugh uses a rather stock vocabulary of architectural terms, and I simply need to memorize them for future endeavors.  Quibbles aside, I really can't recommend this one enough.  Five stars.

B002ZG980U|5.0|I see that this film has about as many 1 star ratings as it does four star ratings.  Obviously, a lot of people didn't enjoy the film.  I'm not sure why that is.  I found it very entertaining and enjoyable.<br /><br />The film does start out in a confusing way, but the opening scenes where Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) awakes on a beach, near a Japanese castle is explained later in the film.  The subsequent scenes show a small group of people who are experts at 'extraction', stealing industrial secrets from the sleeping mind, when the brain's defenses are down.  Cobb offers his services to Saito, (Ken Watanabe), but in a different vein, to train him to protect his mind from others like Cobb who are bent on stealing his secrets.<br /><br />Now, they are asked to do something that is much more difficult, perhaps even impossible; not to take an idea, but to plant one into another's mind.  This time, it's rich industrialist Maurice Fischer's son, Robert, whom is sought to take his father's company into a different direction than the one his father chose.<br /><br />It's elaborate and complex.  In order to plant an idea, the small team led by Cobb must go not just one level down, into a dream, but beyond that, perhaps even three levels down, in other words, a dream within a dream within a dream.  In order to accomplish this, a new and perhaps dangerous sedative will be tried.  The danger, of course, is that the dreamer may die from the sedative, or more ominous, he or she may continue into the deepest level of the dream state, where hours in this world translate into years in this deepest level.  Cobb has been there before, and knows the danger.<br /><br />Inception is a fun romp!  There is a ton of action, as things are happening on all three levels of the dream.  There are bad guys everywhere who are manifestations of those who are trying to prevent the supposed theft of Robert's thoughts and ideas.  And then there is the wild card no one, except Cobb, expects; his dead wife, who is still very much 'alive' in his, and everyone else's, dreams.<br /><br />A strong recommendation for Inception.  The amount of planning that must have gone on just to write the script is fantastic.  To have it all make sense is impressive.  And, of course, the special effects are outstanding; really unbelievable.  The best effects are when Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) have to defeat the bad guys in the dreams second level.  The hotel they are in is rotating, and somehow everyone appears to float around, climb walls, and walk on the ceiling. B00006JYMW|5.0|What is the sound of one hand clapping? Don't just read that and nod - try to visualize, or audibly imagine, the sound. Koans are instructions to be practiced, not puzzles to be intellectualized, and they're meant to lead to insights about the nature of life that one could never reach by reasoned philosophy or rational thought.<br /><br />To my mind, Sigur Ros' aptly un-titled album serves something of a similar role. It is not meant to be appreciated in the same way that much of our music presents itself. All of its scarce and repeated lyrics are unintelligible, just familiar enough to make you try to draw meaning from them. But the human noises mixing with the often surreal instrumental ones evoked something in me that feels deeper than a \\"mood\\". The songs on this album proceed slowly, deliberately, but are punctuated occasionally by sudden shifts in intensity. The auditory tour evokes imagery and visceral sensations which are usually inspiring, sometimes uncomfortable, and generally very weird. Accordingly, it feels like this music pushes me, challenges me in odd and foreign ways that defy verbal explanation, ways which I have found at times disconcerting but always appreciated.<br /><br />If you have never heard Sigur Ros before, take care in how you first listen to it. Create a setting that is surreal enough and imaginative enough to give the album room to unfold its otherworldly splendor - for me, my first hearing was in an almost-dark log cabin with incense burning at three in the morning. Maybe being outside in the woods would work better for some people. My experience is that if you form strong associations with music like this the first time heard, the music will have more meaning and value to you when you hear it in other (more normal) contexts later on.<br /><br />Sigur Ros' [] album is for those who think music can draw them a little out of their comfort zone and help them learn more about themselves, or perhaps give them emotional strength they will need in daily life. I experience the music as cleansing and supportive, and I listen to it when I need to decompress from a particularly stressful week. You may use it in drastically different ways. However you use it, I think you'll admire Sigur Ros for their subtle and trippy auditory artwork.ed in daily life. I experience the music as cleansing and supportive, and I listen to it when I need to decompress from a particularly stressful week. You may use it in drastically different ways. However you use it, I think you'll admire Sigur Ros for their subtle and trippy auditory artwork.

When bands are real and put their personal experiences and resulting emotions and feelings into their music and their albums, their \\"fans\\" are SURE to be disappointed when the artists change as individuals and a corresponding new musical sound emerges on their albums.    They are artists. They are people. They change. If they are to stay honest artists, their sound will change as well. 0553801473|3.0|I started reading ASOIAF novels when I first heard about the HBO series. It seemed intriguing and I thought there were only 4 novels with Feast being the last. I didn't realize how wrong I was and should have done my research. I am not a fantasy reader. I do not peruse the fantasy section of my local bookstore or even care to know the newest series. My mother tried to buy me Wheel of Time and I refused after picking up the book at my local library and putting it down after 50 pages of nothing; however, A Game of Thrones is a very different fantasy novel and I found after the 2nd Bran chapter how triumph George was at bending and breaking typical fantasy rules.<br /><br /> I read a lot of fiction both good and bad and very quickly noticed in Clash of Kings, a slowdown, of the story arc. A slowdown occurs when the author purposely hold the character back to make room for another novel or if the characters story advances too much it will give away a mystery.<br /><br />This is what has happened with Feast and Dance. I would rather call Feast a companion novel than anything else and it is probably one of the most dim novels I've ever read in my life. The only story arcs that matter Samwell, Alayne (sansa) and Arya. Everything else is cannon fodder.<br /><br />Yet, George learned. He couldn't have another Feast. Dance does move at first but then get's mired down in muck. There are points where I jumped up while reading and was like yes. This is awesome. Dance is by far a better book but it suffers the same fate of not moving enough. Also, do not give me characters in the middle that I don't care about nor really contribute to the story. I am not stupid and that is one of the reasons, Snow cannot be there. B0034G4P8A|5.0|This movie was very, very good from start to finish. If you love comic book adventures, then Thor has a good but different look into the life of a superhero movie. It is more of an introductory story rather than an origin since our main protaganist was born to be a super hero, not some accident-gone-wrong mutation like a lot of the others, which works for them, but not for Thor. Thor (played by Chris Hemsworth) is an Asgardian, who are beings from another dimension who are far superior in strength and power compared to people living on Earth.  The family drama between Odin (Anthony Hopkins) and his two sons, Thor and Loki(Tom Hiddleston), plays out wonderfully and is essentially the main driving plot in this movie. Thor is a proud and arrogant warrior prince who is destined to be the King of Asgard whenever his father, Odin, thinks he is worthy of that title. Soon into the movie Thor disobeys an important request from his father that ultimately jeapordizes the peaceful times on Asgard by assaulting the Asgardians ancient enemies, the Frost Giants of Jotenheim. Odin is outraged at his eldest son and quickly strips him of his \\"godly\\" powers and banishes him to Earth until a time that he learns the error of his actions. Upon Earth, Thor quickly meets a group of scientists led by Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) who, through some mis-adventures, end up helping Thor to find his purpose behind his banishment. Meanwhile, back on Asgard, King Odin is falling into a coma, a rest he needs to replensh his awesome powers from time to time called the \\"Odinsleep\\" and cannot continue commanding Asgard, so Thors brother Loki assumes command in his place. But is all good with Loki? He seems to have a mysterious past, and now his motives are a little unclear as to why he wants to rule Asgard.  Back on Earth, Thor must quickly learn his lesson in humility and get back to Asgard and set the things he messed up straight.    Overall, this movie was very well acted. Director Kenneth Branaghdeserves many kudos for getting good performances from his lead actors. Many have said that Tom Hiddleston steals the show with his portrayal of the jealous brother, Loki. And he readily does! The set designs in this movie were top notch- the interiors of Odins Throne room, Heimdalls observatory and parts of the frost giants homeworld were all stage built and they looked wonderful. The small town in New Mexico for the Earth scenes was built as well, but maybe this you can tell as it kind of looks simplistic, but it was still more than serviceable for the movies sake.  And I'm kind of tired of people saying Thor and Janes \\"Romance\\" was to short to be believable. First of all, who ever said it was a full-blown romance gone full circle? I never once heard either character proclaim their love for one another. This was just Thor and Janes introduction to each other. They developed a crush for each other, and the filmmakers are waiting for the sequels to flesh it out even more. Have some patience people, this will pay off down the road.  Buy or rent this movie and enjoy a great adventure with good action, you won't be disappointed! 4.5/5  (rounded up to 5/5)

0452287022|4.0|I somehow never got around to Girl with a Pearl Earring back when it became popular, and then again when the film came out. I kept having friends whose opinions I respect speak highly of it, even after years had gone by, and I figured that it must be better than the normal best-selling fair, that is forgotten weeks after its appearance and left by the dozens to yellow on used-bookstore shelves. As it happens, it was quite a good, striking and certainly memorable.    Plot-wise, I guess not much happens. Griet, the well-grounded daughter of a tile-maker who has recently been blinded in an accident, must take work as a maid in the home of a local artist. Griet's life is consumed by the tensions and dramas of her tiny world--jealousy between staff, the clueless mistress of the house, power-struggles with the spoiled children, romance with a local boy, fear and sadness caused by poverty and the plague, etc. But, sort of like Vermeer's paintings, there are details in the midst of her life that just shine, that are simply sublime. Griet, an artist's daughter, possesses an aesthetic sense that the master of the house recognizes, and so she begins to help Vermeer to produce his masterpieces, an enviable possession that is threatened when the artist's wealthy patron begins to take interest in the girl.     The key strength of the book is in the writing itself. The novel is told in Griet's voice which reflects her keen and artistic observations. The novel is also subtle, and psychologically astute. A lot happens between the lines, as Griet begins to grow up and to learn how to look at and appreciate herself and the world around her. Certainly, it is a quiet novel, and brief. But again, the analogy of Vermeer's paintings comes to mind; even if one offers just a glimpse of a simple scene at a brief moment in time, there are many small beauties to enjoy and levels to discover. Girl with a Pearl Earring the novel is like that, a finely drawn and artistic tale.

B003UESJIS|5.0|Mike Leigh's slice of life movies such as High Hopes, All or Nothing, Secrets & Lies, Career Girls and his previous movie Happy-Go-Lucky, (with astonishing performances by Sally Hawkins and Alexis Zegerman), are at the opposite end of the spectrum from Hollywood Blockbusters. They are understated and believable. Within this realm of slowly moving observation events become magnified leaving one invested in developments. After somewhat of a detour with the well-crafted Topsy-Turvy and Vera Drake, Leigh has returned to contemporary setting with his last two movies. Perhaps Another Year doesn't pack the punch of Happy-Go-Lucky, but it doesn't have to, that's not the point. Somewhat reminiscent of his 1980 Grown Ups, also featuring Lesley Manville, Another Year has more space to explore the inner workings of the characters.  Like Fassbinder, Leigh has an entourage of versatile actors to work with. Lesley Manville and Ruth Sheen are mainstays in his films and, particularly Manville; expectedly turn out first-rate performances. If you are looking for explosions or mystery don't look to Mike Leigh, but if you want to watch an atmospheric, beautifully realized drama with real dialog that will resonate long after the end credits roll, he's your man. After decades of making these compelling movies Leigh's special talents have not tarnished.

0307341550|3.0|I read Dark Places recently and while it had a few flaws, I thought it was a great novel and I declared myself a fan of the author.  What I especially liked about the novel was how flawed the protagonist was and how dark and nasty the story was.  Reading the author's debut novel, Sharp Objects, I found the same elements (a flawed central character and a dark and nasty story) but I didn't care for this novel as much.<br /><br />I have often said that I appreciate flawed, even unlikeable characters in novels. I guess I have come to realize that this is true - to a point.  I liked flawed characters unless one of their flaws is that they are pathetically self destructive.  I thought the author's choice in making her a `cutter' was an interesting one.  It created an opportunity for Flynn to use a clever literary device by playing with the words the character carves into her skin but as the novel wore on, I just grew weary of watching the passive downward spiral of the main character.  I appreciate the author's brave, unconventional choices, but even so, while I found the character compelling to start with, as the novel wore on, she tested my patience and I just didn't want to read about her anymore.<br /><br />My lack of enthusiasm for the central character obviously affected my enjoyment of the novel, but it didn't help that there were other flaws as well.  I found much of the novel improbable.  I wasn't convinced that the methodology of the killer was consistent and made sense when all was revealed.  And the inevitable twists at the end were obvious and predictable.<br /><br />I'm still in Flynn's court, but I'm not sure I'm a full fledged fan yet.  I look forward to reading more from this author.  She shows tremendous promise and I remain optimistic that everything will come together in her next novel.  I have to applaud any author who has the courage to create such flawed characters.

Nothing truely terrible on it. Yet nothing that really stands out in a huge way. One thing that's important to not,especially after seeing documentaries and reading about them that the core members of Yes but a lot of genuine musical knowledge and labor into what they do. Miles Davis once said that too many rock musicians \\"didn't know anything about music,but were popular\\". Yes manage to be one of those bands who have the advantage of being both. The pages are also arranged in such a way that no matter what location you jump to, \\"flipping\\" the page will align the play so lines don't get separated between pages, if at all possible. This makes for much easier reading.<br /><br />I would have rated this 4.5 stars if I could. I guess I don't like it for the same reasons other do:<br />While I don't like formulaic fantasy either, sometimes a \\"formula' exists for a reason. I don't need black & white good and evil, but I would like to LIKE certain characters. I want to root for SOMEONE. I get it- make the characters flawed, human (or not) etc., but the author will present the character in a certain way, and then have them do something completely outside the character. Cat Tully for instance- strong, supportive, brave....impetuous and stupid. I couldn't help but think- go ahead and behead the woman- when she kidnapped Tyrion. Are we to believe she'd really be that stupid because she got spotted in a inn? Ned is courageous, honor-ific and so loyal to his king- that he alters Robert's will. Huh?<br />Also George is afflicted with the Stephen King disease: toomanyuscharacterus. How many main characters can you fit in a novel? I need a chart or a Dummy Guide. I lose track of who I should be keepng track of.<br />And last but not least: enough with devoting 4 pages to a freakin' banquet/feast and every stinkin' banner and standard. After ten feasts I don't CARE if its roasted duck, quail, pig or Lannister. I don't CARE if Sir Stabs-A-lot has a bluebird on his chestplate or a ball of flaming crap. Enough already! Action, sex, carnage, whatever- all better. I appreciate the intricate details but after awhile they obscure the story.<br />Oh, and one more: I think when George thought it was getting boring he threw in a little....fantasy. Seriously- 3/4 of the first book is all medieval, lords and ladies, war and games and politicking. And then suddenly...toss in a dragon! Bring on the witch lady! There wasn't really any fantasy until the very end. Make up your mind George.<br />I am trying desperately to finish book Two, but after that I am done. The only plus is that I am using it as a sleeping tool. I'll go back and read Lord of the Rings.am using it as a sleeping tool. I'll go back and read Lord of the Rings.

0345444051|4.0|To fully appreciate 'Childhood's End,' one has to consider it in two contexts.<br /><br />The first: the era in which it was written and the audiences who first read it ... In several respects, 'Childhood's End' is a work of fiction that transcends the five-star rating system. I can only imagine how groundbreaking the concepts, images and ideas presented in this book must have been to 1950's readers. While it's usually erroneous to assume that previous generations were less sophisticated,  this is truly one of the pioneering works of science fiction, something that, by its very nature, was novel to readers of its day. That writers and filmmakers have been shamelessly borrowing its concepts and images for 60 years is testament to the appeal and longevity of this pioneering work. The fact that many of these images and concepts are now cliche and prosaic cannot be held against the innovator Clarke himself.<br /><br />The second: the plot and themes as an enduring  literary work, regardless of era....because unless someone somehow manages to do what to this day has only been imagined--find a way to move backwards in time rather than forward--it must be judged based purely on the merits of its entertainment value and ideas.  Here, it's nearly impossible to remove the cynicism and high expectations that a 21st century reader will bring.<br /><br />There is very little hard science beyond relativity and time dilation, and much like 'Foundation,' we are never given a relate-able character with whom we can experience the entire journey . Some elements of the plot receive many, many pages, while the seminal events, those with the most profound and philosophical implications, receive far fewer pages. Much more time is spent setting up the idea of the mystery than is actually spent delving into and exploring that mystery, which is a little disappointing. It all fails somehow to come together as an organic story, and feels like the setup is so generic that nearly any twist or ending could have been attached to it. The overall premise and final reveal of 'Childhood's End' are very intriguing, and the two together are enough to overcome Clarke's shortcoming as a story-teller and weaver of mystery.  What tips the scales into the favorable and memorable categories are the deep philosophical questions that Clarke asks about humanity, religion, intent, and desire. Even if you do not agree with Clarke's views, whether stated or implied, the topics remain as pertinent today, and vital to the future of society, as they were in 1953, making this a must-read for fans of sci-fi and deep thinkers alike.ttached to it. The overall premise and final reveal of 'Childhood's End' are very intriguing, and the two together are enough to overcome Clarke's shortcoming as a story-teller and weaver of mystery.   What tips the scales into the favorable and memorable categories are the deep philosophical questions that Clarke asks about humanity, religion, intent, and desire. Even if you do not agree with Clarke's views, whether stated or implied, the topics remain as pertinent today, and vital to the future of society, as they were in 1953, making this a must-read for fans of sci-fi and deep thinkers alike.
B0052UZIFA|5.0|This is a near exact copy of the pc version!  There are only minor differences,  and i was very surprised by that.  It runs amazingly on my droid incredible.  I have had zero issues.
0812550706|5.0|I've seen this book listed at or near the top of many list of the all-time great sci-fi novels ... Whether it's deserving of #1, 10, or 50 I don't know ... what I do know is that it belongs in the conversation.<br /><br />While the story focuses around children, this is not a children's tale, nor is the target audience children. Let's be clear ... this is a very damning book about adults and the way, after a certain age, almost any behavior, with near any consequence, can be rationalized to comply with one's sense of morality. Card tackles many topics in this book--war, propaganda, bureaucracy, violence, sacrifice, and even touches on some existential elements--while keeping things moving very quickly.  While character development may be thin, there are enough ethical considerations layered into nearly every chapter that any more context setting may have been distracting, if not exhausting.<br /><br />Card asks some tough questions about the nature of human relations ... to whom does one owe more: himself or his race?  To what extent does intent play a role in guilt or innocence? Is there anything that can justify a pursuit by any means necessary?<br /><br />Where this book loses a few points are the hastiness with which the plot lines involving Ender's siblings materialize and end....and the unexplained origin of their seeming superiority.<br /><br />I am not sure that simply integrating space and aliens qualifies something as a work of science-fiction, especially when there is very little hard science or anything particularly forward-looking to mention....but it doesn't really matter, as there is enough sub-text here to make this a gem of any genre. Particularly moving to me was the final chapter. I can't quite explain why the last few pages were so powerful, but they were quite unexpected and welcome. Here, Card forgets about genre altogether, and speaks to tolerance and communion without preaching, ending on a note that undoubtedly affirms the maturity and wisdom with which this \\"children's tale\\" was written.

0553801473|4.0|A lot of the reviews that have been negative so far for Dance talk about how \\"the wait wasn't worth it\\".  But the thing is, for the most part these reviews only harp on the fact that \\"oh, I've waited six years for Martin to finally finish it, but there's no epic battles/resolution/revelations\\" etcetera and \\"I waited so long for THIS?  Oh man I'm done with the series\\" blah blah blah.  They don't actually talk about the story itself.  And while I'm as critical of Martin for how absurdly long he makes his loyal readers wait between installments--especially since the argument could be made that a part of that wait is spent by him not spending as much time on writing as fans think he should--this isn't the place for those arguments.  A book should be judged by its contents, not how long a reader waited for it.<br /><br />These people, while not completely unjustified in a lot of the criticisms they're raising--especially in the abundance of cliff hangers and open-ended storylines-- are missing the point of what, in my mind, makes A Song of Ice and Fire great--the characters, the unpredictable nature of where the plot's going to go, the wonderful world of Westeros and its environs, but again, most of all, the characters!  Dance is much more about character development than other books in Martin's series, especially compared to Storm of Swords, in which almost every chapter involved some great action scene, or development, or advancement of the plot in some way.<br /><br />The pace here is more like that of Clash of Kings--and much better, not just barely better than Feast, which I think most will agree is the most slow-paced novel in the series.  While it lacked epic scenes equivalent to the Battle of Blackwater, the wildlings' attack on the wall, or the Red Wedding, there's still plenty of solid content that should satiate most fans of the series, particularly the introduction of a storyline/group of characters that pretty much changes everything, and one cliffhanger fora certain character that I had to reread again, it was so exciting and unexpected.<br /><br />Again, its the characterization and not the war or overarching storyline that's the star of the show here.  The POVs are essentially divided into three groups: those in the North and around the Wall reacting to the events of Mance Rayder's failed attack on the wall and Roose Bolton's rise to Warden of the North; Dany as she attempts to establish her role as Meereen's monarch and the various suitors and others attempting to reach her and her dragons; and a smattering of returning POVs from Feast for Crows which, while not completely resolving loose ends from the previous novel, do just enough to tie up those loose ends but leave the reader intrigued as to what happens next.<br /><br />The three main POVs are easily the most slowly paced, but they also have, in my mind, some of the best character development in the series.  Jon is struggling to remain neutral in Stannis' efforts to win the north, while at the same time asserting himself as a strong commander.  Tyrion has decided to embrace the image of the evil imp everyone else had wrongly made him out to be while trying to decide what to do with his life.  And Dany makes decisions in her ruling of Meereen that may or not go against the destiny meant for her.<br /><br />I enjoyed the other POVs more than I did the main ones, but really, all of them, set the stage for what will hopefully be a brilliant next installment...whenever that may be.  The new POVs (there are four--two are brand new characters and two are former periphery characters)are more or less welcome additions to the story, especially one of the new ones. Finally, Dance easily has the best one-shot POV (meaning prologue or epilogue) of the series so far.<br /><br /> And the book isn't just nothing happening until the end as some are making it out to be--there is a HUGE revelation early on(not to mention another towards the end careless readers will miss), andone of the main POVs comes out of the gate really strong in a moment that had me cheering when I read it.<br /><br />No, it isn't perfect.  But Martin can't make every installment of the series Storm of Swords or of its same exact caliber.<br /><br /> Complaints for me include, that while cliffhangers aren't necessarily a bad thing, and some of them are excellent in this, others just left me going \\"really?  That's all we get?\\"  Martin definitely overuses his techniques of repeating phrases and describing food and fauna in a ton of detail. And while I enjoyed most of the POVs, I had a problem with two of the new ones--one only got one chapter, and the other, who was foreshadowed in the previous novel, just never became fully realized for me.<br /><br />But hey, at the end of the day, I got to be reunited with Jon, Dany, Tyrion, Bran, Davos, and other characters we haven't seen in years.  And while there may not be a slambang, epic beheading, battle, or wedding people may have wanted as a reward for their long wait, there is still plenty of developments, and plenty of foreshadowing at things to come, that should leave most fans at least somewhat happy, or at the very least talking about and debating the events of Dance.

After Star Wars(1977) made a ton of money in box office tickets, Paramount Pictures turned the pilot for Star Trek Phase II into Star Trek The Motion Picture. They spent $35 million and hired seasoned director Robert Wise to direct the film. A malevolent entity known as \\"V'Ger\\" is destroying everything in its path on its way to Earth. The USS Enterprise has to save Earth from V'Ger. Star Trek The Motion Picture(1979) is very slow paced at times; some people call it \\"Star Trek The Motion Sickness\\" or \\"The Slow Motion Picture\\"! One movie critic claimed the film put too much of an emphasis on glossy visual effects and not enough development into the characterization. The ugly, drab Starfleet uniforms were considered a joke! Director Robert Wise claims he wanted people to stare at the sets(designed by Harold Michelson) and pay less attention to the uniforms. At a stand up show, Kevin Smith poked fun of Superman Returns(2006) and Star Trek The Motion Picture(1979) for having too many VFX shots and not enough \\"spirit\\"! People have criticized the scene where Admiral Kirk(William Shatner) spends 10 minutes staring at the new Starship Enterprise in drydock. This film should not be confused with J.J. Abrams' reboot of Star Trek(2009). As a gag, he wore a Star Trek The Motion Picture jacket on the set! It's nice to see the original cast of Star Trek reunited in a movie and the music score by Jerry Goldsmith is a classic! The main title music was recycled for Star Trek The Next Generation(1987-1994). In the 2000 \\"director's edition\\" of Star Trek The Motion Picture, Robert Wise and a team of visual effects artists fixed some pacing problems and they fixed some of the cheesy and incomplete visual effects shots. V'Ger's ship is now visible as it hovers over the Earth. The opening credits in the 1979 version appeared overa black screen. Now, they appear over a starfield. Star Trek The Motion Picture was released on the same month as Disney's The Black Hole(1979). Everyone from the actors to the crew to the visual effects artists worked night and day to get Star Trek The Motion Picture completed and it's a miracle it turned out as well as it did. December 1979 was the deadline for the movie's release. In a rare \\"Making Of\\" featurette, you can see Spock(Leonard Nimoy) in a spacesuit and the Memory Wall in V' Ger's ship. This incomplete scene was deleted from the movie and replaced with a scene where Spock mind-melds with an orb. The Special Longer VHS version and the ABC TV version from 1983 have an additional scene where Kirk gets into a spacesuit. You can tell the scene wasn't finished; there's a giant soundstage behind Kirk. Special camera tricks and lighting were used to make the cast look younger. This is the only time we get to see Uhura(Nichelle Nichols) in an afro! In the sequels, they admit they're middle aged. Star Trek The Motion Picture(1979) is a decent movie.

B004EPYZP8|4.0|I'm not a huge Matthew McConaughey fan, but I did like him in \\"A Time to Kill.\\" While I haven't read the original novel, my wife and I figured \\"The Lincoln Lawyer\\" might be a good midweek flick, and we were right.<br /><br />McConaughey is Mickey Haller, a defense attorney who seems to do most of his business from the back of an old Lincoln. He's shrewd, wily, and fits right in with those he represents from the shadier side of the streets. As far as he's concerned, he doesn't ever have to feel bad if he loses a case because he knows all his clients are essentially guilty. It seems, though, that his father once warned him about the day he would represent an innocent client. Sure enough, his father's warning proves prescient when Haller ends up being retained by an ultra-wealthy L.A. client, a young man played by Ryan Philippe. This man has been accused of assaulting a hooker in the midst of a transaction, and indeed he was discovered with her blood on his hands, but he swears his innocence.<br /><br />Haller takes the case. He makes a lot of money from it. But he also uncovers some small lies by his client. What is his client trying to protect? Does it have something to do with a rich mother who suffered abuse of her own? Soon Haller is getting pulled back into an old case and is questioning his own judgment, even while trying to make amends with his ex-wife and his young daughter.<br /><br />It's pretty obvious early on that something is not right, but the manner in which this unfolds, both in the courtroom and on the streets, makes this a fast-paced and entertaining story. It has some lessons hidden in there about justice and the flaws in the legal system, particularly apropos after the Casey Anthony trial, but it never rises to greatness. There are some sloppy moments that may have worked better in book form. For example, I kept wondering how a Maserati managed to go unnoticed in slum areas, especially when the driver was supposed to be oh, so intelligent.<br /><br />In the long run, Haller lives up to his own tarnished and questionable character by meting out justice on his own terms. He doesn't prove himself above the law, but he does show that he has a penchant for wanting the truth and wanting justice at all costs, if it means protecting the truly innocent. It leads to some interesting ethical discussions without ever taking itself too seriously in the process.s up to his own tarnished and questionable character by meting out justice on his own terms. He doesn't prove himself above the law, but he does show that he has a penchant for wanting the truth and wanting justice at all costs, if it means protecting the truly innocent. It leads to some interesting ethical discussions without ever taking itself too seriously in the process.

1442419814|5.0|I'd been eagerly waiting to read this book and when I finally found a copy, I couldn't wait to get into it.  I love dystopian novels and this one fit the bill perfectly.  It had all the great components; characters, premise, plotline.  Definitely a good book to read.<br /><br />Tally is an Ugly eagerly looking forward to her 16th birthday when she will be able to have the surgery that makes her a pretty.  You see, new pretties get to have all the fun, and well, they aren't ugly.  There's no reason to not look forward to that time.  At least for most people.  Tally's friend Shay has decided instead to run off to a secret place where no one has the surgery.  Tally doesn't understand why Shay would want to do something like that, but when the government forces Tally to go look for her friend or not receive her surgery, she is taken to a world where things are not always what they seem.  Tally isn't sure whether spying is the right thing to do at all.<br /><br />Tally isn't wishy washy like some characters can be.  Sure she changes her opinion a bit but its done in a very believable way.  She has a lot of growth in the novel and while she has superficial tendencies, she's a good person.  Shay on the other hand I think gets all the bad luck.  I couldn't help but feel sorry for her throughout the whole novel.  It was interesting to see the comparison between the \\"uglies\\" and the \\"pretties.\\"  Something very different is there and its fascinating to read about.<br /><br />For a plot I think this one had a really good premise.  The book starts out a bit slow in the beginning but you're quickly enveloped in the storyline, and if you're like me, can't set the book down.  Westerfeld has also done a great job of incorporating new language and slang for the time his book is held in.  The little nuances make everything believable and he treats the new technology like something that's been around forever; which in the character's eyes, it has.  Since this book was written for young adults, there isn't strong language or heavy adult themes, but it is still not a book I picture a younger child being able to read just because the writing is more sophisticated.<br /><br />I can't wait to read the next book in the series.  An extra trip to the bookstore is in store for me I believe.<br /><br />Uglies<br />Copyright 2005<br />425 pages<br /><br />Review by M.
